name: Othmar KARAS
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Turkish military operation in north-eastern Syria and its consequences (2019/2886 (RSP)). As you know, we have a new system for ad hoc speeches – the blue cards and spontaneous speeches. I do not need to repeat this on an ongoing basis, but you can use either the traditional form of the blue card or the electronic form. You do not have to wait for the end of the debate for the spontaneous speeches.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the Turkish incursion into north—east Syria seems to have slowed down. We acknowledge the contribution made by several international actors to ensure that this is the case. We have seen high—level diplomatic efforts aimed at de—escalating tensions, firstly a few days ago by the United States’ Vice President Pence and Secretary of State Pompeo, who negotiated a temporary truce with Turkey. We also know note the memorandum signed only yesterday between President Putin and President Erdoğan in Sochi.  The High Representative was in the Parliament with you on the first day of the offensive and she immediately made clear our request that Turkey immediately stop the attack. Turkey’s concerns must be addressed diplomatically, not through military action that can only further destabilise the region and bring more suffering to the Syrian population. We are also relieved that humanitarian agencies have not had to suspend their response – at least not entirely – and that those displaced from their homes for fear of the fighting have begun to return. Yet there can be no excuse for the nearly 200 civilian deaths that have occurred, nor for the bombing of hospitals, ambulances and water stations. We care about the fate of Syrian Kurds and indeed for all the civilians in the zone of hostilities. The only way to address their aspirations and recognise the sacrifice made by the Syrian Democratic Forces in the fight against Daesh is to help build a democratic and inclusive Syria – a country that all its citizens can home. There can be no military solution to the Syrian conflict. It is crucial that instead we support the political process and that a lasting solution is found for all parties involved. Thus, we have a duty to support the work of the Constitutional Committee due to meet for the first time at the end of the month in Geneva. Despite recent events – or rather, all the more so because of them – the time is right for that Committee to meet. We have full confidence in the United Nations Special Envoy, Geir Pedersen, and we believe that a step—by—step political solution can be found. Launching the Constitutional Committee can set a positive cycle of trust and confidence and eventually bring about the changes necessary for a peaceful and stable future for Syria.  We all know that the path towards a negotiated political transition will not be easy. Yet we must agree with our international partners – and yes, Russia and Turkey too – that changes must be made to the way Syria is governed. We must agree that justice and accountability must be brought for the crimes committed by all sides during the course of that conflict right up to Idlib and the most recent offensive. This is for the sake of the peace, stability and reconciliation that we all crave for Syria. Let me turn now to Turkey and its responsibility for the current situation. Turkey’s security concerns at its border with Syria will not be answered by military intervention. This offensive instead undermines the fight against Daesh and threatens our common security. Turkey has made tremendous efforts in hosting several million refugees for many years – there’s no doubt about that – yet Turkey’s military action is only making an already highly complex situation in the region even more difficult to resolve. It only adds to an already complex and dramatic situation. This is why the EU leaders and EU Foreign Ministers have condemned Turkey’s incursion and this is also why Member States have decided to halt arms exports licensing to Turkey. They insist that the incursion must not just be stopped temporarily, but it must cease altogether. The Foreign Affairs Council has also made clear that we will not provide stabilisation or development assistance in areas where the rights of local populations are ignored or violated.  The European Union has been clear and united on all this from the very first day of the incursion. We are glad that the Council, the Commission and Parliament have passed the very same messages and we thank the European Parliament for its continued support to ending the war and supporting a political solution under the auspices of the United Nations.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you very much for the opportunity to update you on the recent humanitarian developments in north-east Syria. The crisis that unfolded on 9 October has led to civilian casualties, displacement of people, destruction of civilian infrastructure. Heavy fighting took place, including in highly populated areas. There are reports of nearly 200 civilian deaths. At the height of the hostilities, nearly 200 000 people have been displaced. Some have now started going home, but the remaining over 150 000 displaced people come in addition to over 200 000 people that were already in camps and informal sites or hosting arrangements before the crisis. Humanitarian staff were denied safe and unimpeded access to people in need due to shelling and airstrikes, or uncertainty regarding territorial control. International NGOs and UN agencies had to evacuate staff to Iraq. Let me underline what the EU Presidency just said: there can be no excuse for these civilian deaths, damage to civilian infrastructure, absence of protection of people and those who are there to help them. I am particularly concerned about the horrific situations faced by healthcare providers. Hospitals in Tell Abiad and Ras Al Ein are out of service due to heavy bombing and shelling, Kobane hospital was temporarily out of service because the electricity line and the generators were cut by mortars and because of shelling; ambulances have been reportedly targeted, preventing the evacuation of patients from the front lines; medical staff have been killed and even kidnapped. To make matters worse, the emergency is affecting the provision of basic services to a population that was already suffering before the crisis.  While the international staff were evacuated, this does not mean that the humanitarian community is no longer assisting the people in need. Life-saving assistance continues to be delivered. We are supporting our humanitarian partners in north-east Syria with EUR 38 million and we will continue to support them for as long as it is needed. But the fighting must stop. And it remains paramount that International Humanitarian Law is fully respected and that civilians are protected. Humanitarian workers must be allowed access to those in need. All precautions must be taken to mitigate the risk of harming aid workers, their facilities and assets, including convoys, and the people they serve. Humanitarian workers should not be any sort of target. Let me also take this opportunity to recall the EU’s line with regard to the return of refugees to Syria. All returns should be safe, voluntary and dignified, and only once the conditions are in place – otherwise the EU will not be in a position to provide support. The same applies to the so-called buffer zone that Turkey is seeking to establish in the north of Syria with a view to eventually sending refugees back. And let me also recall the recent EU28 Statement that any attempt at demographic change would be unacceptable. At the same time, the European Union will not provide stabilisation or development assistance in areas where the rights of local populations are ignored. The European Commission has recognised and supported the efforts of Turkey to host millions of refugees in its territory. But Turkey’s military action in north-east Syria has aggravated an already dramatic situation on the ground. I am glad that the European Institutions have been united in their reaction against Turkey’s military action. But there should be no time for complacency. The brokered ceasefire was only partially respected. We must use all our power; all our leverage to stop hostilities, to put an end to this humanitarian tragedy and to allow our assistance to fully resume, and of course reach in parallel a political solution under the UN.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the There is a broad consensus in this House: we condemn Turkey's incursion into northern Syria, which is contrary to international law, and we are consequently calling for these troops to be withdrew from Syrian territory. We are not naive, we know what was agreed yesterday in Sochi. It is all the more regrettable that this behaviour was made possible only by a unilateral withdrawal of troops by the United States. Turkish behaviour, moreover, further distances the country from the European Union politically. That is why we also recalled in our resolution that this Parliament called for the formal suspension of the accession negotiations as early as March.  We call on the Council to consider appropriate, targeted economic measures that do not affect civil society, which does not reduce the possibility, for example, of Turkish people continuing to participate in the Erasmus+ programme and study with us. For example, we have an agreement on agricultural products. One could think about whether something should be done there. Or we have also mentioned that the final step could be to suspend the customs union. The people of this northern Syrian region do not want to see Turks, Russians or the Assad regime there. That is why we have included a demand in our resolution and I quote in English: 'Calls on the Member States to turn again to the UN Security Council to obtain a resolution which will allow the Council to act in a targeted manner, ultimately aiming at a UN-led security zone in northern Syria for the benefit of the people living there'. 'Calls on the Member States to turn again to the UN Security Council to obtain a resolution which will allow the Council to act in a targeted manner, ultimately aiming at a UN-led security zone in northern Syria for the benefit of the people living there.'

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, two weeks have passed since our last plenary session and our debate on this crisis. The establishment of a so-called safe zone has de facto become the establishment of a war zone and the Turkish invasion of north-east Syria. The winners are Putin, Assad, Turkey, Iran and Isis, and the losers are the citizens of north-east Syria and the credibility of the West. A total of 218 civilians and 600 SDF fighters have been killed. More than 300 000 civilians had to leave their homes and are now displaced, struggling to find safety. They are caught between advancing Turkish troops and Syrian forces moving in from the south, and hundreds of IS fighters, including EU citizens, have escaped guarded camps. The summary execution of Kurdish politician Hevrin Khalaf, one of the many courageous women in north-east Syria, is an absolute outrage. The latest reports refer also to the alleged use of white phosphorus against civilians by Turkish-backed forces in Ras al-Ayn. The perpetrators of these heinous acts must be prosecuted, and while the US President hails the cease-fire as great news that will save millions of lives, I can only reject, on behalf of this House, its very basic premise. Yesterday’s Russia-Turkey deal legitimises the Turkish presence of a 10-kilometre zone along the Syrian border, the refoulement of two million refugees and the displacement of the local population. All of these are grave violations of the most basic principles of international law, refugee law and humanitarian law. We have called for targeted sanctions against Turkish officials, restrictive economic measures and a full weapons embargo, and beyond any legal and political consideration, I wish to underline that abandoning all those who suffered from Isis and who fought against Isis making the ultimate sacrifice for our own security is not and should never be an option.

name: Malik AZMANI
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, the Turkish military operation in north-eastern Syria is cause for a great concern and is leading to chaos in the region. Reports speak of hundreds of casualties, hundreds of thousands of displaced people, and even of executions. ISIS terrorists have escaped prison and as a direct result of the Turkish move and the US withdrawal, revival of ISIS and the possible return of these terrorists to European soil presents also an immediate safety threat to our societies, for our citizens. By asking questions to the European Commission, by sending a letter to the High Representative Ms Mogherini, which was widely supported by more than 250 colleagues – and I am grateful for that – and by engaging with the Turkish authorities, I have in the past weeks attempted on behalf of Renew Europe to contribute to ending this violence. But so far, the EU’s response has not been strong enough. We cannot just stand by and see how others interfere, for example, Russia, Assad, Iran. It’s also our safety that is at stake. For Renew Europe, the road does not end here. Tomorrow, the European Parliament has the unique opportunity to speak with one clear voice, one voice to make perfectly clear to Turkey that we do not accept this, and to call upon the EU to take a strong stance now.  I ask my colleagues in this House to support me in urging the High Representative to set up an immediate dialogue with the Turkish authorities, to reach a sustainable solution, and to hold Erdoğan to his promise of keeping ISIS prisoners in detention. However, we must be prepared for firmer action. Arms, economic and targeted sanctions are also on the table. Let us combine our strength and show unity and bring an end to the violence now. We owe it to the people in the region and to our European citizens. Please, Commission, get off the side-line and act.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Mr President, exactly two weeks ago Turkey began a planned military offensive in north-east Syria and two weeks in which many civilians have been killed, nearly 200 000 Syrians were forced to flee their homes and among them are 80 000 children in desperate need of aid and shelter, while humanitarian organisations were forced to leave the country. The situation in Syria is again a humanitarian tragedy which should not continue another day. The withdrawal of the US troops has left the Syrian and Kurdish people with no other option than to wait for the solution Erdoğan and Putin will come up with. Although the EU should use its power to de-escalate the conflict and stop the violence, it seems to be invisible on the world stage and therefore today the Greens call upon the EU to take up its role as a proactive actor to force Erdoğan to withdraw his troops and refrain from deporting Syrian refugees back to Syria, by placing targeted sanctions and visa bans on Turkish government officials, imposing a full arms embargo and by working on suspension of the trade agreements. At the same time we should proactively protect the Syrian refugees by stepping up their resettlement and take our fair share in their protection. We cannot wait any longer with action and we therefore urge the support for the proposed resolution. Mr President, ISIS terrorists escape displacement camps posing a risk to the Syrian people and leaving us with no control over the persecution. The Greens therefore urge the EU Member States to repatriate their nationals and their family members to prosecute them at home and take care of their children. It’s our duty to reduce the security risk and also to prevent children from being the victims. And as we all know one of the goals of Erdoğan’s invasion is to deport Syrian refugees to their country. However, even a so—called safe zone cannot protect them against violence and persecution, as deportation would violate the Refugee Convention the EU must refrain from returning Syrian refugees to Turkey as long as this risk of deportation exists. But deportation would also mean a demographic change of the population in north-east Syria, which is also a crime against humanity. As the Kurds, who fought on our side, will probably lose their autonomy the EU should at least make all efforts to ensure that their rights are upheld. So high time to be pro-active. (Applause)

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the I am sad, if not surprised, that the ceasefire has not been observed. Hundreds of people have died as a result of this Turkish aggression, and the Kurdish people have been betrayed. Since Kurds have also fought ISIS for us, the EU has also bitterly let these Kurds down in the hour of need. Of course, we have heard the usual threats from President Erdogan, including the threat to send millions more asylum seekers to Europe, thereby causing destabilisation in the EU states concerned. We must now show a clear edge: no more accession talks for Turkey. It is obvious that Turkish behaviour is contrary to peace and the rule of law. Turkey has weakened NATO, and therefore all of us. Turkey's actions have led to the release of extremists and terrorists, and that, in turn, puts the whole region and, subsequently, the European states at great risk. Turkey, along with Qatar, is actively supporting ISIS, one of the most dangerous Islamist groups that threaten peace, freedom, and security – our Western way of life. And that is why we are sending a clear message to President Erdogan: Turkey does not belong to the EU or to Europe.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, numerous mistakes have been made by the international community in Syria since 2011. We have to remember the atrocities of the Assad regime – Aleppo, the presence of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard backing the Assad regime, and the cruel Wagner Group of Russian mercenaries that was so well known in eastern Ukraine. We are concerned by the recent operation, the third in line of Turkey in north-eastern Syria. I would like to quote Stoltenberg’s statement as probably the most balanced one: ‘While Turkey has legitimate security concerns, I expect the country to act with restraint’. And to all of us, we expect this restraint, certainly. Yet we have to know that equal measures should be applied to all actors in the region, and we have to find adequate tools to stabilise the region and influence activities that ease the tension.

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the "The kids wanted to argue, I let them fight and then separated," U.S. President Donald Trump said. This phrase from the White House is simply disgusting and shows the spirit of child speaking here. People died, some are on the run again. The invasion of the Turkish army is to be condemned without any ifs and buts, no country can invade another country. The Erdogan government is concerned with domestic and geopolitical motives, and the so-called security zone is not about security, but about reshaping Syria. The fact is, however, that all the world powers, all of them, including the EU, have watched for their own economic and geostrategic interests, how international law has been broken and war crimes have been committed. Not even a real arms embargo has been adopted here. All the world knows that Mr Erdogan cannot continue his war if the international community speaks a clear language and exerts consistent economic and political pressure on Erdogan. And that is what we are calling for: a genuine arms embargo, no more economic business with the ACP, recognition of the self-governing structures in Rojava.  What is needed is a political, peaceful solution for the region, for Syria, and not for a military one – I stress: no military solution! Rojava is an example of this. The Kurds and the Syrian Democratic Forces are the progressive forces. They deserve our support. And even if the heads of state in the EU pursue their own geopolitical interests, the population stands for equality, democracy and peace. (The speaker concluded her speech with a few words in Kurdish))

name: Miroslav RADAČOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, I condemn Turkish aggression in northern Syria. This invasion does not have the mandate of the UN Security Council, nor the consent of Syria, which is a full entity of international law. This Turkish aggression must be confronted with strong opposition from the European Parliament. The consequences of this aggression will be borne by the Countries of the European Union, including the waves of migration and the arrival of various terrorist groups in Europe. If the European Union does not want to be a political dwarf, it must, firstly, inevitably lift the sanctions imposed on Syria by the European Union; If we want to be fair, let us condemn the presence of all foreign forces in Syria that are there in violation of international law. In such a simple way, we will prevent the killing of the people of Syria.

name: Andrzej HALICKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We owe solidarity to the Kurdish people, and I hope that we will all unanimously adopt this resolution tomorrow – which is obvious to me. Let us recall that the Kurds shed blood so that we, the Western world, could declare victory in the fight against ISIS by liberating cities like Kobane (we all remember), Raqqa or the multicultural Mosul where I spent several years. I would like to say that these words of solidarity cannot translate into practical action. That is why we are proposing today in the resolution on the 2020 budget an amendment prepared by the EPP concerning the freezing of pre-accession appropriations, that is, paragraph 45, and the transfer of these funds to the reserve. We cannot, of course, limit the resources to help refugees, students and help civil society, but this practical amendment will also express the Position of the European Parliament and the disagreement with the massacre of the Kurdish people.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, while we are again discussing the consequences of the Turkish intervention in northern Syria, the agreement on the withdrawal of Kurdish forces between the United States and Turkey has expired.  But it has already been replaced by a new, similar deal between Turkey and Russia, in principle opposing sides when it comes to Syria's territorial integrity. This appears to be a deal acceptable to all three parties involved. But the question remains what about the Kurdish fighters who have made a remarkable contribution to the fight against the Islamic State? What about Islamic State fighters who are no longer under control and for which member states still do not want to claim responsibility? And most importantly, what about the locals who are in no way involved in this arrangement? The main objective must be to cease military operations, in particular the use of chemical weapons.  But the European Union must not just be a passive observer of the agreements of others. I certainly support the proposed measures prohibiting arms exports, freezing the assets of individuals, as well as specifically targeted economic sanctions, which can all be instruments of our action. However, how can we expect strategic decisions of the European Union on Syria when we failed to reach an immediate neighbourhood last week by opening accession negotiations? Again we open up space more active than us, but to those who do not share our interests and values.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Erdoğan has us where he wants us. He's taken a complete look at Europe. Firstly, because in 2016 we outsourced our own migration policy to him. He holds the keys to the gateway to Europe, which means that he can threaten to open that great gate with waves of migration. Secondly, now, by invading northern Syria, so to speak, to create a safe zone, so to speak for their safety, but we all know that it is to fight the Kurds. "Where is Europe?", people ask themselves. What is Europe doing to bring this bloody conflict to an end? Well, Europe is watching out for work. Europe is watching as Putin supports Assad's dictatorial regime. Europe is watching america take military leadership first and then it leaves headlong. Today, Europe is watching as Turkey, under false pretenses, is exacerbating the conflict. The bad thing is that we have been demoted to spectators, while we have to deal with the consequences of the crisis. We will have to monitor the migration flows. It's our young people who are radicalizing and going there. Ladies and gentlemen, it is high time for action: firstly, we must establish a dialogue with Turkey, secondly we must ensure that safe zone, controlled by the UN. That is what Parliament wants. It is also high time that Europe took control of its own security policy. We will not have to rely on the Americans and the Russians to defend our interests. I would also like to call for account to be taken into account for the more than 700 European children in the camps. They deserve our attention. They shouldn't pay for their parents' sins. And let us really work on a European defence union and a real European asylum and migration policy. Thank you very much.

name: Sergey LAGODINSKY
text: – Mr President, two grey-haired, elderly men got together in Moscow and decided to divide a region.  Two grey-haired, elderly men could only do so because we failed. Because our institutions have failed. Because this Parliament has failed its purpose. Because the Council has failed its purpose, and the Commission as well. Where are the comprehensive arms embargo measures? Where are the targeted sanctions that we are talking about? We were not able to take responsibility for this region, and others took it. But it’s not too late. We still can develop into a political actor. Abolish unanimous decisions and foreign policy, invest in more diplomacy and more foreign policy ability of the European Union. We have five years to do so. Maybe not now, not to help those people – and we are ashamed of it. But let’s change in the upcoming five years, and if you want to prevent elderly, grey-haired man deciding about the fate of the world, let’s invest also in a feminist foreign policy, so that we have more women to decide about the future of the world. And one more thing I want to mention: there is a consensus here, as Mr Gahler said. There are various political powers and political forces voting for a very harsh resolution, but they are doing so for various political reasons, and I can tell you what our reason is to vote for those harsh words. We want to secure a European future for Turkey, and in order to secure a European future for Turkey, we must tame Turkish imperialism of the government and we must tame the Turkish anti-humanitarian militarism of this government, because the European future of Turkey are the civilians, the artists – many people who are in prison now, and for them it is worth fighting for this future. For those who are saying that we want to prevent it, that they want to vote for this resolution to prevent a future for Turkey in Europe, we are saying quite clearly: we are voting for this harsh resolution in order to allow a future for those people. A future in democracy and a future in Europe, against Erdoğan but for Europe. (Applause)

name: Ivan DAVID
text: – Mr President, I am reluctant to vote in favour of the resolution as it is being prepared, because what was strong in it has been removed from it and articles have been delivered that are difficult to agree with. It could be summed up in words — too late and too little.  They were Kurds, and it will be the Kurds who will suffer and be victims again, and the worst part is that it is based on and according to the model of the Adana Treaty, where they are viewed or viewed as terrorists by both the Syrian and Turkish parties.  It was the Kurds who played a large part in destroying the Islamic State the way it operated. Once again, Europe is showing its extraordinary weakness. Only an economic blockade could achieve substantial changes, and there is no willingness to do so.

name: Assita KANKO
text: – Mr President, when I was a child, if someone would say that the Americans would come and save us, I actually tended to believe it because of American movies. I don’t know if it was right and I don’t know if today it would be wrong. If I was a child again and someone were to say, ‘wait, Europe will come and save you’, maybe I’d start saving myself.  Europe has chosen diplomacy as a powerful tool and I think this is very beautiful. Diplomacy is indeed a powerful tool, but only when the person across the table knows you are willing to act. We must show that, when it comes to ensuring global stability, the EU is not a talking shop but a beacon of hope for those fighting for freedom, for their lives.  We should halt licenses for arms exports to Turkey and consider putting in place economic sanctions. We must push for a no-fly zone in north-east Syria and call for peace talks to be resumed with the involvement of Kurdish representation. We should put an immediate block on European pre-accession aid and guarantee humanitarian assistance in the region for those displaced and in harm’s way. While some world leaders seek to retreat from their responsibilities in the Middle East, this is the time for the EU to step forward and also pay special attention to women suffering a lot of abuse over there.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: Mr President! Aminah Mahdini, 73 years old, killed by grenade. Muhammad Yussuf Hussein, 11 years old, killed by grenade. Ibrahim Al-Mussah, 3 years old, badly wounded in the leg. Hussein Ali Klai, 2 years old, severely incinerated. The list of victims of Erdogan's invasion of northeastern Syria is long, indeed terribly long. Turkish military and Islamist militias have bombed civilian areas, executed civilians on the open street and accused of using chemical weapons.  We've seen how Trump has failed our pro-democratic and Kurdish allies in Syria. We have seen how Erdogan has continued with his business while the EU has failed. And yesterday we saw how Putin and Erdogan decided at a meeting in Russia how they would share the spoils in Syria. As we stand here speaking, the Turkish and Russian militaries are preparing to move into the largest Kurdish and Christian population centers in Syria. Erdogan's stated goal is ethnic cleansing.  Ladies and gentlemen, if we suspend the customs union between the EUROPEAN Union and Turkey, Erdogan's economy will collapse. Erdogan will thus be brought to his knees and the Turkish invasion will stop. Ladies and gentlemen, we can stop Erdogan. It is a question of political will. Ladies and gentlemen, it is time to act.

name: Athanasios KONSTANTINOU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, following the previous briefing on Turkish operations in north-eastern Syria and on the basis of the international media's news reports, I would like to point out the following: Turkey's military operation against Kurdish forces has already caused a mass displacement of the population. There have also been a variety of reports of indiscriminate attacks on civilians. If this evidence is confirmed, it means that these attacks will constitute war crimes. This possibility was also highlighted in the statement by the US Secretary of Defense Esper. I must also stress yesterday's statement by James Jeffrey, the US President's special envoy for Syria, that dozens of Islamic State jihadists were released after the Turkish army began its invasion of northeastern Syria. For the two elements mentioned above, the institutions of the Union must be systematically active in dealing with them.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Madam President, the Turkish military operation in north—eastern Syria is yet another devastating event in an extremely tragic conflict. It has serious humanitarian, military and political repercussions, it causes suffering for the local people and it may contribute to a resurgence of Islamic terrorism. I would like to underline what colleagues, especially the group coordinators of the EPP, S&D and ALDE, have mentioned this morning. I would like to inform you that this week in my capacity as Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) I published, together with the Chairs of the Foreign Affairs Committees of Germany, France, the United Kingdom and also the US House of Representatives, a joint statement on the Turkish invasion. In our letter, we consider the abandonment of the Syrian Kurds to be wrong as the Syrian Democratic Forces massively contributed to the successful yet unfinished fight against Daesh in Syria. We deeply regret the decision of the President of the United States to withdraw American troops from north-eastern Syria and we call upon the European Union and the Member States to take responsibility and engage in the conflict resolution. In our draft resolution that will be voted tomorrow, we also call for a strong and comprehensive EU reaction to this ongoing crisis. A final remark – I welcome initiatives to establish an internationally controlled security zone in north-east Syria. Such a zone could stabilise the region and make sure that rebuilding civilian life is possible again.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: – Madam President, as the Council has stated — and it is my group's position — the Turkish military operation on Syrian territory constitutes a clear violation of international law. Moreover, there are all sorts of political contraindications, but this is the one we need to put first.  International law is the framework for all and it is the one that the European Union has used to establish a path for peace and reconstruction of the country with a plural Constitutional Council. Therefore, none of the security concerns that Turkey can claim justifies militarily invading a neighbouring country; that's not a solution, but the prologue to the next problem.  Turkey, as a member of the Atlantic Alliance, may seek solidarity from its allies, but cannot act outside the multilateral legal framework.  Maintaining a huge number of Syrian refugees is also not a passport to militarily invade a neighbor, and claiming that the sovereignty and territorial integrity of that neighbor, having its soil and its population, is defended, is contradictory in itself.  No one can go to a neighboring country to interfere with its complex ethnic or demographic balances, whatever military force is leaving and the military force that comes to fill that unexpected and dangerous void. No one can have a territory and the only possible resettlement is that of Syrian families in their places of origin on a voluntary basis.

name: Irina VON WIESE
text: – Madam President, at the time of the Turkish invasion about seven thousand children of ISIS fighters lived in camps in northern Syria. Among them about 700 EU citizens. Many were forced to flee and their fate is now unknown. We cannot abandon these children, or punish them for the crimes of their parents. No child under 10 is criminally liable in any EU Member State. I call on Member States today to comply with international, European and national laws and repatriate these children now, before it is too late.

name: Saskia BRICMONT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I invite you to turn a blind eye for a moment while I have made my speech. You have children and the eldest, your beloved son, leaves Belgium or your home one day for a fight that is not yours. You're fighting like a lioness to get him back. Nothing helps. Only the political will is lacking.  Your grandchildren are born in this context of war in deplorable humanitarian conditions, in a situation of chronic malnutrition. The conflict will not spare your son who dies for the cause, the very one you are fighting from your seat in the European Parliament. Once again, you are fighting like a lioness so that your grandchildren, who are in no way responsible for the situation, victims of a war they did not choose, are repatriated to Europe, to a safe place.  Today, as politicians, you have the power to repatriate these European children, and the European Union can coordinate this action, in the name of the best interests of children enshrined in the International Convention on the Rights of the Child, which we are all committed to respect.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Madam President, a year ago I wrote on Twitter: "And at the end of the story, the only one who will protect the Kurds of Syria from the risk of extermination by the Turkish army will be the legal government of Syria of President Assad." This position may surprise, but yet it was so predictable!  Indeed, how could one doubt that the Kurds would be abandoned by those who shoutled that they would remain faithful to them, encouraging their autonomist desires? How could one doubt the will of President Trump, who had already announced long in advance that before the election there would no longer be an American soldier? How could we also forget that the Turkish reaction would inevitably be what it was? I am not here to defend Turkey, I strongly condemn its incursion into Syrian territory, but which State would agree to have terrorist groups on its borders that regularly make excursions on its territory?  So what is the solution today for peace in Syria? Regaining international law, respecting Syrian sovereignty over the entire territory and encouraging the government's policy of reconciliation? How can we justify, for example, the sanctions that the European Union still imposes on medical equipment? The conclusion of this story, what is it? We had a security, humanitarian vision, whereas we should have had, as other states have had, a strategic vision and a vision that takes into account the specifics of the region. As a result, we are spectators, commentators, we regret, we vote motions, but in this text we have never been actors. Perhaps it is time for the European Union to take into account the realities and finally have a strategic vision of its international policy.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Madam President, the Turkish invasion of Syria is certainly a tragedy. But it is a foreseeable tragedy, because Turkey has interests in the region — it has serious interests — and the three and a half million refugees it has there are an absolutely incontrovertible fact, which weighs like a snout, and which we have not listened to until what is happening right now has happened. I believe that Turkey should certainly be pressured to restrain itself and to create exclusion zones and protected areas. But, in fact, Turkey is not interested in a long-term "pax Putin" in Syria, because it would only be of benefit to Putin himself and Iran himself, nor can Europe do anything else right now than mourn and mourn wounds because we have done absolutely nothing. And to think that Americans are always going to be everywhere, putting money in and putting the dead, is a perfectly unrealistic thing, that in Europe it is continuously seen and that it certainly has no future.

name: Giorgos GEORGIOU
text: Madam President, and political leaders of the European Union, do you remember bringing the Arab countries with others in the spring? Now that the heavy winter has come, you cry with crocodile tears over the ruins. Eight years ago, a foreign invasion was launched against the Syrian government to overthrow it and dismember the country. The United States of America, NATO, Turkey, European Union countries and Gulf monarchies have armed, through the Syrian opposition, hordes of jihadists and the Islamic State.  Now, with the tolerance of Russia and America and with the verbal condemnations of only the European Union, Erdoğan has been set free as a beast to drink blood and to re-attack a long-suffering people, the Kurds. No hesitation, no moral inhibition from anyone! As long as the area is divided again, weapons are sold, the oil comes out! In the end, I think that all this sounds tragic and that we are rather tragic. (applause)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in less than a month, Erdogan has violated international law by invading Syria, starting ethnic cleansing and showing, as Amnesty International points out, a shameful disregard for civilian lives, committing serious human rights violations and war crimes.  I therefore welcome the decision of many Member States, unfortunately not all of them, to suspend arms supplies to Ankara, but that is not enough; The premises have not been in place for a long time.  At the same time, any European funding that may end up in Erdogan's pockets must be blocked. We are paying dearly for the decision to hide under a Turkish carpet, with all due payment, the problem of migratory flows, which are now being used as a constant scarecrow to silence us.  Thirdly, we must not be afraid to use the full range of options at our disposal: targeted economic sanctions, suspension of trade preferences and suspension of the EU-Turkey customs agreement. Ladies and gentlemen, the consequences of our past mistakes are painfully clear to everyone. Let us not abandon the Kurdish people, for the umpteenth time, at least we Europeans.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, the Turkish invasion of northeastern Syria has two components: a security component, which is based on Ankara's belief that it has to do with Kurdish militias as terrorist structures, and a migration and humanitarian component. The effects of this invasion are extremely harsh. Among them, we note that the Syrian army is, for the first time in many years, in northern Syria, which has also prevented Turkey from obtaining all 440 km of border control, having to settle for 120 km. On the other hand, the invasion resulted in the displacement, in just five days, of 170,000 Syrians and 200 deaths. Last but not least, the Turkish invasion gave Putin the opportunity to pose as the guarantor of Syria's future independence, Syria's territorial integrity and, in other words, total influence in Syria. Our position... (The President interrupted the speaker)... limited to announcing that ... (The President interrupted the speaker)... we no longer export weapons. All right, we're not exporting weapons anymore, the Europeans, taking the armaments from Putin. The solution is... (The President interrupted the speaker)... supporting UN representatives to guarantee... (The President interrupted the speaker)... security zone on the Turkish-Syrian border.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Madam President, this is one of those moments which does not accept half words or silences. The Turkish military offensive in northeastern Syria represents a serious violation of international law, threatens the stability and security of its own in the region, led to the forced displacement of populations weakened by a long conflict and opened the door to a possible resurgence of Daesh. You can't go without a firm condemnation.  The European Council's initiative to ban the supply of arms, although welcome, is not enough. It should extend to all ongoing supplies and further should be taken by adopting sanctions directed at individuals directly or indirectly implicated in human rights violations and economic interests.  It must be made clear that the European Union will not be blackmailed, that we will continue to provide humanitarian support to Syrian refugees and the neighbouring countries that welcome them, but we reject any forced return operation. The return of these citizens to their country can only be done freely and once they are able to do so with dignity and security.  The European Union cannot support any social reengineering operation. At this difficult time we cannot fail to signal the courage of the Kurdish people and the democratic forces of Syria, fighting alongside the international coalition against Daesh, and to draw the consequences from it while maintaining our solidarity.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: Madam President, what is happening today in north-eastern Syria is not just another episode in the tragedy that has plagued Syria for the past eight years. This tragedy is also ours. The Turkish offensive targeted Kurdish troops fighting Daesh alongside us. The militias, backed by Ankara, brutally executed political leaders. I think of Hevrin Khalaf who shared and promoted our values. The camps, where European terrorists were detained, were left unattended.  The international law we have built has been flouted. The Atlantic Alliance, which serves as a foundation for our security, has been taken by surprise and has appeared paralyzed. But above all, where is the European Union?  We cannot be pleased that Russia's role in the Middle East is being strengthened. We cannot be satisfied that our American ally has considered us to be negligible in its choices. If we do not react, history will be without us and perhaps even against us. We have never needed strategic autonomy so much. We have never needed so much Of European defence that allows us to protect ourselves, to be respected and to uphold our values when our alliances fail.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, we are witnessing the shame of abandoning those who fought ISIS on the front line. It is a real shame that these 300,000 displaced persons – 70,000 children, according to Unicef – who are suffering from an illegal Turkish military operation from the point of view of international law. That Trump tolerates this is expected; that the European Union does nothing, it is absolutely shameful.  We must not only condemn the Turkish military operation, but we must certainly demand a withdrawal and we must demand that the mandate of the United Nations be fulfilled, that multilateral dialogue in the region, the Geneva framework, be resumed, and that Security Council Resolution 1325 be respected, and above all, we must promote a United Nations mission in the region.  We must also assume our own responsibilities: we cannot tolerate, in any way, that Erdogan intends to return Syrian refugees to that area. We must open avenues of resettlement, because this is also our responsibility and we have been blind to this for too long.  What about weaponry? We have not been able to make a decision that goes beyond the new arms export licences to Turkey. We must also curb the export of armaments that are taking place under licences already granted.  Look: in Syria Europe has failed, out of pragmatism, out of misdidity... And we must stop being spectators, we must assume our responsibilities, because the humanitarian crisis is also our responsibility.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Once again, Turkey is up for debate here, and once again President Erdogan is up for debate – this time not because of a lack of freedom of the press, the lack of human rights, Turkey's internal situation, no, this time because of a war of aggression in northern Syria. The entire region is destabilized. There is also a big loser: once again, these are the Kurds, who, even in recent years, have never received the necessary support from the international community – by the way, the largest people on this planet without its own state. I call for the consequences to be drawn at last. I do not know how many IS fighters can now also free up in the region and head for Europe. The consequences to be met: finally end Turkey's candidate status with the European Union, continue to end pre-accession aid at last, consider imposing sanctions here, and finally impose an arms embargo, because this situation, as it now stands, is unacceptable. I would ask you not to bury your heads in the sand here.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The operation launched by Turkey in Syria illustrates the relationship between border control and foreign policy. Because of the naivety of the left, Europe's leaders have had to entrust our border guard to Turkey. We cannot pronounce what we want and not do what we want because of the constant threat of Turkey opening the border to migrants. Erdoğan is allowed to hold Europe hostage.  What the EU High Representative should say is that Turkey has destabilised the region, caused civilian casualties, undermined security and stability, increased the risk of terrorism and damaged the coalition against Islamic State. She should add that we will never accept demographic changes in the area. But she won't, because we have no control over our own borders.

name: Konstantinos ARVANITIS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the facts show that there is a clear agreement between Trump and Putin, with Mr Erdoğan as the main player. It looks like the whiskey company ad, known here in the West, "one leaves, the other comes." Yesterday's agreement between Mr Erdoğan and Mr Putin proves the truth. The Union is once again playing the role of 'participatory abstention', with the inemitable of course for some of its countries. In response to a question from the German left, the German Government replied that until the embargo, until the day before yesterday, sales to Turkey amounted to EUR 250 billion for military hardware, i.e. weapons, in the first eight months of 2019. From this carnage it seems that everyone wins, establishing Mr. Erdoğan as the dominant player in the Levant.  But there are some questions we want to ask: who will protect the Kurds, a million souls in the region, the Union? What are we going to say, who will do anything about the new wave of refugees that will take the road to Europe and the Greek islands, the Union? Are we going to send our compassion? Will we make a new European Union-Turkey agreement, see Mr Orbán close his borders? The political majority of the Union, day by day, is making the Union increasingly unreliable in the international game.

name: John David Edward TENNANT
text: – Madam President, I find myself wondering what on earth Turkey thinks it’s doing with its military aggression in north-east Syria. Haven’t they an ounce of humanity? Don’t they recognise the huge suffering that nation has already seen through civil war, through ISIS, through bombing, and yet here we stand debating Turkey, which is still, on paper, a candidate for EU accession. When Brexiteers pointed out the instability of the Erdoğan regime, we were smeared by this Chamber. We were accused of all kinds of awful things for pointing out that Erdoğan’s world view is incompatible with modern democracy. Those who have turned a blind eye can do so no longer and you should look in the mirror when you see what you have enabled. I’m going to sit back down now and resist the temptation to say I told you so.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, in a conflict as lasting and complex as the Syrian we did not need any more crises or more unilateral interventions. Turkish action has involved suffering, loss of life and displacement of many people. It could also have involved advantages for the Dáesh by facilitating the evasion of those currently detained. And it also leads to a greater presence in the Russian area, which is becoming the arbiter of the situation, more after the agreement yesterday in Sochi.  The exit of the United States from Syria and the absence of the European Union have created a vacuum that is now occupied by Russia, Turkey and Iran. America's decisions have important consequences: they remain the indispensable power, even if they do not want to be.  On the other hand, the European Union needs to be more present externally. It cannot be limited to humanitarian aid and contribute to reconstruction. The Union must prevent, provide solutions. We need a much more active foreign security and defence policy. Global governance instruments, such as the Security Council, are under-operational and Washington follows an external retreat line. The European Union needs a more active, more ambitious foreign and defence policy, I mean, and the Syrian case unfortunately proves this to us.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I am ashamed of the international community and the EU's so far inaction in the fight for democracy and human rights and in the defence of international law in Rojava. I had hoped that in the motion for a joint resolution we would also have seen, among other things, measures such as the no fly zone in Rojava and that the EU would take the initiative to guard the Turkey-Syria border through a peacekeeping force.  The current proposal is good but not enough. We must also call what is happening by its proper name: an invasion with the aim of an occupation, not an operation and not an intervention. I was in Iraqi Kurdistan over the weekend. There I met Mohammed, 12, one of the many children from Rojava who have been hit by what is suspected to be white phosphorus. Mohammed's only crime is to be born a Kurd at a time when dictator Erdoğan rules in Turkey and the world remains silent. A hundred years ago, Ismail Enver Pascha committed one of the worst genocides in history against Assyrians, Syrians, Greeks, Armenians and other Christians. A little less than fifty years ago, northern Cyprus was invaded on behalf of Bülent Ecevit and two weeks ago Recep Tayyip Erdoğan decided to invade Rojava. We must not remain silent every time.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, using military force is not the right approach to solve the strategic security challenges faced by Turkey within its southern border. On the contrary, it only adds new ones.  While fighting the Kurdish military forces, Turkey hurts Kurds, Syrians and its own citizens. In addition to civilian casualties, the old wounds and anxieties of a deeply traumatised population along the border are being reopened. The unfortunate US military withdrawal, unnecessary Turkish military invasion and destructive Russian military and political presence in Syria have created a new geo-strategic shift, which can hardly be balanced or sustainable. The EU must play an active role in ensuring Turkish accountability and, at the same time, do everything possible to pursue a critical dialogue with Turkey.  Speaking of Syrian Kurds, we must seek ways to relinquish their long-time suffering.

name: François ALFONSI
text: Madam President, the aggression of the Turkish army in Rojava or Syrian Kurdistan raises fundamental issues for the future of Europe.  The first issue is the stability of this part of the world. The Kurds opposed energy and courage until victory against Daesh, even though Turkey has shown and is still duplicious. Attacking the Kurds is compromising the only real bulwark against terrorism.  The second issue is the democratic values to be promoted. With regard to women's rights, in particular, Kurdistan offers a new model to the entire Muslim world, which is at odds with what exists in most Muslim countries. This is crucial for the future of the world.  The third issue is the security of Europe in an increasingly dangerous world, where we will need allies. How will Europe find allies tomorrow if it does not protect its allies today?  The European Union can act strongly on its own by deciding on strong and immediate effective economic and diplomatic sanctions. Trade between Turkey and Europe is the most important, far more important than that with the United States. Our responsibility is therefore to impose deterrent sanctions against the dictatorship of Mr Recep Tayyip Erdogan today.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Van Rompuy, for his excellent work I fully agree with all the previous speakers who say that the Turkish aggression in northern Syria and against the Kurds is completely unacceptable, but at the same time I am asking questions about these counter-steps. We are calling for counter-steps and we must respond, I fully agree with it, but what are these countersteps specifically? At the moment, I have heard concrete proposals for economic sanctions from the previous speaker - a good colleague from the left party. I totally agree. At the same time, it must be borne in mind that Turkey has consistently used extortion tactics in recent years and continues to threaten the European Union that if, for example, the European Union does not pay new amounts, turkey will basically open its border, which is unacceptable. The European Union has paid EUR 6 billion in the last four years. For what? To submit to pressure from Turkey! And the second thing - whether we like it or not, the United States has played a very important role in maintaining stability, and if the Americans pull out, there will be too much opening for Russia and Turkey, which is unacceptable to us and means a greater need for cooperation between the European Union and the United States. Thank you and hopefully everything will work out.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: Mr President, what happened is unacceptable. The peaceful coexistence between Kurds, Christians and Yazidis under democratic self-rule in northeast Syria has been cruelly disrupted by the Turkish advance with the Orwellian name "Peace Spring". Our allies who have sacrificed themselves in the fight against IS in the interests of our European security are being brutally dispersed, leading to a new humanitarian crisis and further destabilisation. Where is Europe, or better, where is Europe? Earlier this year, EU member states refused one by one when the US requested military support for the Syrian Democratic Forces. Speaking of honesty. But it is clear that Turkey has crossed a border. That requires a strong backlash from the EU, more than the weak condemnation so far, held hostage by the Turkish stranglehold of the refugee deal. How credible is Turkey as a candidate country? It is time to end the accession negotiations. Or does the EU give in to Turkish Kurdphobia and Erdoğan's Ottoman aspirations?

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Madam President, just a week ago, after meeting with Turkish authorities, the European Commissioner for Migration stated that Turkey remains a key partner in migration management and reaffirmed the validity of the 'agreement of shame' between the European Union and Turkey. These statements were made while the Turkish Army invaded Rojava.  It seems that the European Union is not only determined to look the other way, but even to legitimize Erdogan in its war against the Kurdish people, as long as it continues to act as a border police officer of the European Union, of the 'Fortress Europe'.  From here, we want to show our internationalist support and solidarity with Rojava; we condemn the Turkish invasion and its ethnic cleansing targets on the Kurdish people.  The European Union cannot be complicit in this massacre. Agreements with Turkey must be frozen. We call for the use of all the popular and institutional pressure needed to end the war.

name: Martin SONNEBORN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which When I'm asked somewhere what I'm doing professionally right now, I explain that I'm just coming out of prison and I still have to orient myself. The fact that I have something to do with the EU is too embarrassing for me at a time like this, when the madman from the Bosphorus is waging wars of aggression with impunity, killing civilians with German weapons and the behaviour of the EU, NATO and the Federal Government can only be regarded as aid. The Turkish dictator must be spoken in a language that he understands, it is said. And that is why I say that if Erdogan threatens three million refugees, we are threatening three million Turks from Kreuzberg – Zwinker-Smiley. And if that is not enough, we will send three million German pensioners behind. Both measures are also expected to ease the housing market, relieve the German pension fund and give the CDU a delicate electoral defeat.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, much has already been said about the conflict in Syria and its geopolitics. But let me also stress: it is not just about geopolitics, it is also about our security. Thousands of Europeans have travelled to Syria in recent years to join IS. Many have died, but a significant proportion are still in that region. Many of these terrorists and genocide perpetrators will be able to take advantage of the chaos to get out and return. We have to be prepared for that. A lot has happened in recent years. We have better controls at the external borders. We have better criminalisation of travellers and we have better information sharing in the EU. Yet here I miss a little bit of the sense of urgency. I therefore ask the European Commission, agencies such as Europol and the Member States to redouble efforts in this area, because security must be our absolute priority. Finally, this. Our ally in Turkey says, "Europe, it's your problem." Nevertheless, we are not addressing it here as a European problem, but each country is struggling individually with this problem. It seems clear to me: we must tackle these terrorists together. Thank you.

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the smiles of victors yesterday of Mr Erdogan and Mr Putin are mirrors of all our cowardice and Syria has become the name of all our renunciations.  We first abandoned the Syrian revolutionaries, in the name of the fight against jihadist terrorism, and then we abandoned our best allies in this fight against Daesh, that is, the Kurdish forces. So today we're all going to blame Donald Trump, and we're going to be right. But what are we going to do? Sanctions? Yes! 1,000 times yes! But when? When? It's already dark in Syria and we're still talking.  So we must learn from our powerlessness. Let's put it this way: NATO no longer makes sense. Not because we no longer have adversaries, but because we no longer have a reliable ally. So let us make our mandate the mandate of the emergence of a credible European defence. From the transition from the Union to adulthood. Victor Hugo wrote: "Those who live are those who struggle; those whose firm design fills the soul and the forehead." Our friends are dying and we are not living yet.

name: Bernard GUETTA
text: Madam President, let's see it and say them. The possible creation of a Syrian Kurdistan on the border of Anatolia can be seen from Ankara as an intolerable threat to Turkey's territorial integrity. If we did not understand it, the entry of Turkish troops into Syria would remain totally inexplicable, but is this military adventure permissible? It is not, Mr Erdogan, because it only multiplies the pain and resentment of the Kurds, the Kurds of Syria and Turkey. It is not, Mr Erdogan, because what are you going to do now? Stay in Syria and become an occupying power? To leave and leave behind hatred and desire for revenge? It is not, Mr Erdogan, because you are giving strength to Daesh, weakening the Atlantic Alliance and fuelling the power rivalries of the Near Eastern powder store.  There is no wisdom and no reason here, Mr Erdogan.

name: Catherine ROWETT
text: – Madam President, a serious humanitarian crisis is rapidly developing in north—eastern Syria. Erdoğan will not tolerate the existence of a Kurdish Democratic Society in the region and seems set on a brutal offensive. Within the last two weeks, more than 176 000 people, including 80 000 children, have been displaced. We have heard from other speakers about the many reasons why we should protect these children and the Kurdish population who live there by right.  Yet it is not only lives and homes that will be lost if Turkey’s invasion is prolonged. Academics and political idealists the world over have admired Rojava’s democratic society, where women are empowered and humans live in harmony with the earth. Let us remember that the EU itself was born as a collaborative political experiment to combat authoritarianism and militarism. It is our task to support our nearest and weakest neighbours in resisting those same threats. The world is watching. What is needed is not just words but the kind of sanctions that work.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, crazy, unacceptable! You think, at the last plenary session, here in Strasbourg, the Turkish authorities dispensed Turkish chocolate to ask the European Parliament to resume negotiations, turkey's entry into Europe. A few weeks later they no longer dispense chocolate but dispense missiles and bombs.  The League said this earlier and keeps saying it: no to Turkey's entry into Europe! No to continuing to give European taxpayers' money to Turkey!  We have a Europe that has not been able to govern economic wars, trade wars, and today we see that we have a Europe that even finances the Turkish war. That is unacceptable! It is also unacceptable in memory of Antonio Megalizzi. A minute's silence is not enough! It is not enough to name a Chamber of Parliament, if we then decide to finance a war that is with Isis, against precisely those who fought terrorism.  I therefore very much hope that all the Members who have received this box of Turkish chocolate will have the courage to return this chocolate to the Turkish authorities with blood- dirty hands, which I come there. (incomprehensible words) No to this Turkey! No to this Turkey!  (Mr President, I should like to make a very important Ciocca shakes a box of chocolates in the Chamber and at the end of the speech approaches the presidency benches and throws the box to the ground)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Excuse me. Would you please resume your seat. This is a House where we debate. We don’t throw things around and we are not violent. That is outrageous behaviour in a Chamber. I’m sad to say, colleagues, that sort of thing is becoming far too common. This is a Parliament where we debate. It is not necessary to roar and shout or throw items about. I hope you all agree with me in that ruling. I am appalled by what you just did, Sir. (Applause) Excuse me, you had the floor. Please listen. Would you please listen for a moment, Sir? Because sometimes when you listen, you learn. It is my job to keep order in this House, and what you did was appallingly disorderly and disrespectful to the House. You can make your political points without being disorderly and abusive to other colleagues in this room. We will move on.

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: – Dear Madam President, I have read the proposed resolutions on Turkey. They are weak and rachi. These resolutions are a sign of weakness. There are correct findings in them, but unfortunately, only half-measures that will lead to nothing. I propose to freeze absolutely all European investments with state participation in Turkey. I am convinced that this will act soberingly on Erdogan. Economic interests cannot always prevail over universal human values. I know such a measure will lead to some economic losses, but they are a negligible cost when it comes to saving thousands of innocent people. Furthermore, I believe that if these measures are not sufficient, a total embargo should be imposed on Turkey, a screw should not come out of there. Thank you.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Madam President, what are our empty protests worth today? We exalt the heroic struggle of the Kurds against the Islamic State, we emphasize on all the benches the community of destiny that binds us to them. But the truth, the sad truth, is that we Europeans have abandoned them and we do not do much. The Turkish aggression two weeks ago was made possible by American inconsistency and imperialism. Today we are spectators and we see Mr Erdogan and Mr Putin deciding the fate of the region and consolidating, that is really the cruelest irony, Mr. Bashar al-Assad. For the Kurds, it is a tragedy, it is a human disaster, but for the Europeans it is a doubly humiliating defeat. We have been unable to respond to unilateral illegal aggression and have been unable to defend our allies. The consequences must be drawn!  Today, we are subject to NATO in a totally absurd way. NATO makes no sense. You talk all the time about an independent Europe and a Europe-power, but we are not going down the road because we are stupidly behind the Americans who are making totally absurd decisions. Frankly we have to react, we have to stop shedding crocodile tears. And if you really want a Europe worthy of the name, let's make decisions that are wise!

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Erdogan's government has exceeded all limits of human decency. An unacceptable massacre, a senseless destabilisation, a tragic humanitarian crisis is taking place in the Middle East.  The highest price is paid by the Kurdish people, to whom the international community should be grateful for its contribution in the fight against Isis, which is now being compromised. We are talking about hundreds of thousands of displaced persons and hundreds of terrorists who have escaped from Kurdish prisons. We have violations of international law and the bombing of civilians, which have been carried out by a country that claims to join the European Union and which receives European funding and which is our trading and political partner.  Well, then, condemning is not enough, we must act, act with effective measures. The Italian Government immediately announced a halt to arms sales to Turkey and it is important that all other countries of the European Union do the same. Let us stop all funding and abolish the process of accession to the European Union of those who prove to be the negation of a prospect of peace and the values on which the European Union is founded.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Dear Chairman, Distinguished Commissioner, it is extremely difficult and emotional to talk about what Turkey is doing on both sides of its border for so many years after the great massacres that were happening in the Western Balkans and after the news we received that there would be no further peace and stability in an area where Turkey has a strong influence.  Frozen funds are not enough, we can punish civil society itself, Turkey does not need it, funds. Turkey needs one strong and moral warning that what it is doing is not good. What he's doing is not morally good. Erdoğan must be held accountable before the International Criminal Court. All those who commit the massacre, all those who ethnically displace the population after it was also done in Srebrenica and Vukovar and wanted to be done in Bihać, must be held accountable in front of those who will try them. So the International Criminal Court must be established for the crimes they commit.

name: Dietmar KÖSTER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The war of the Erdogan government in northern Syria is contrary to international law and destabilizes the entire region. By withdrawing its soldiers, the US has cleared the way for the Turkish government. Erdogan's geopolitical strategy is to destroy the Kurdish self-governing Rojava region and expand its own territory. For years, the Kurds have been successfully fighting AGAINST ISIS, including for the safety of its citizens in Europe. Of the Kurdish fighters, 11,000 have already fallen against ISIS. We in Europe are deeply to blame. I welcome yesterday's extension of the ceasefire, but the Kurds, whose interests have not been taken into account, are paying a heavy price. The region is a long way from a sustainable peace order. The inhumane resettlement plans of Erdogan must be taken off the table, and the Kurds must be given a perspective for a dignified and self-determined life. This is where the European Union and the international community must finally shoulder their responsibilities.

name: Dragoş TUDORACHE
text: – Madam President, I join my colleagues who have condemned in the strongest terms the unilateral aggression of Turkey, not Russia. As the European Union, we must act on three fronts.  The first is humanitarian. We are witnessing a new tragic phase of a humanitarian crisis that had already reached historic dimensions. Millions of Syrian refugees already deployed inside and around Syria were added several hundred thousand years ago. The second plan is security. We risk a regrouping and resurgence of Islamic State, taking advantage of the chaos created in northern Syria and the release of many ISIS fighters from camps guarded by Kurdish troops. Finally, we must act diplomatically and geostrategically. Erdoğan must feel the European pressure, and not us to feel we owe it to Erdoğan for keeping our hands on the refugee tap.  A Turkey acting as it pleases, systematically violating the rights of its own citizens and the values of the rule of law, a Turkey that only dialogues politically with Russia is a Turkey to which we, as the European Union, must give clear messages: effective arms embargo, targeted and serious sanctions, encouraging Turkish civil society by all means and supporting a process of re-establishing Syria , removed from the trio Russia - Turkey - Iran.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Madam President! In many of our countries there are a large number of Kurds. They've been here for many years, they have citizenship here, they're part of us and they're our constituents. I think this time we have come to experience heartbreakingly close to what is happening in Kurdistan right now. Of course, the Kurds also have, like us, heart ties to their family members down there.  It is not because it is worse when it affects oneself and one's own than when it affects others, but it is really healthy for us in Europe that we see both how violent human disasters are and how great our failures are. The other day I received a moving letter from Kurdish Mothers for Peace, writing to us: "We want to build the Museum of Peace, not of war and genocide. And we don't want our children to die anymore." It is usually said that the Kurds only have the mountains as friends. This time, let's show them that they have real friends, too. I hope that the resolution we are adopting today will help to make things different from what it seems to date. 'We want to build a museum of peace, not of war and genocide. And we don't want our children to die anymore.'

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Madam President, I hear on all our benches a unanimous condemnation of the violent aggression that Turkey has been engaged in on the territory of Syria for several days. Of course, we must condemn this war waged by Mr Erdogan's government and the atrocities that accompany it, but let us not settle for these few hours of debate, let us attack the evil at its root.  If Turkey, since 2011, in the wake of the Arab Spring, destabilizes the Middle East, it is because the majority of this Chamber has long since fallen back to the blackmail of the Turkish President and accepted everything. In our countries, you, members of the EPP, in particular, say that Turkey will never enter Europe here in Strasbourg. You are constantly voting on the billions of accession appropriations, you are paying more and more money from the European taxpayer so that Mr Erdogan does not open a border that our free trade treaties are unable to protect. It is your cowardice and hypocrisy that drives the Turkish president to go even further. It is your double game that excludes Europe from the solution to this conflict and puts President Putin in control of the game.  It's time to put an end to this piece of dupes. The accession process must be permanently halted and the flow of billions to Turkey finally dried up.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the tragedy of the Kurdish population in Syria has revealed several European hypocrisies.  The first, while the Kurds were dying fighting Daesh, Europe stood on the sofa watching television, and now it is also said to be concerned about the return of the foreign fighters it raised at home.  Secondly, in the years when Turkey was turning from a secular nation into an Islamic sultanate, Europe gave EUR 58 billion to facilitate its accession to the European Union.  Thirdly, Erdogan's threat to unleash the 'refugee bomb' is the result of the European Union's decision to contract the management of its borders to Turkey, and this contract cost six billion euros, not a generous effort as Commissioner Stylianides said just now.  In conclusion, therefore, selective sanctions against Erdogan and his clique are a good thing, but above all, stopping Turkey's accession to the European Union.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, this is not unilateral military action, as the European Union claims, but the invasion of Syria by its strategic partner, Turkey, a NATO Member State, with the aim of sharing control of the region. Both the American-Turkish agreement and the one with Russia, in terms of imperialist peace, with a gun to the head, mark a new cycle of haggling and antagonism on the backs of the people. They are fuelling uncertainty for the people in the context of military escalation in the region. The so-called European Union sanctions, both for the invasion of Syria and for violations in the Aegean and Cyprus EEZ, are hypocritical, at the same time as economic, trade and other relations of powerful Member States of the European Union are being upgraded and strengthened.  The European Union, the US, NATO, imperialists as a whole, are not friends, as the New Democracy government and SYRIZA claim in Greece. Their alliances are at the expense of the people. Solidarity with the Kurdish population and the Syrian people as a whole! End the offensive by the Turkish military forces! Developments in Syria are a matter for its people.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: "Dear Madam President, the events in northeastern Syria are of great concern and are a signal of what the lack of a single, strong, effective foreign and security policy of the European Union, as well as the capacity to act in our neighbourhood, leads to. We're very good at talking, but we're not. The US withdrawal from the region has created a vacuum that we have not filled, and Russia has been able to exploit. Turkey's military operation undermines regional security .... (The President interrupted the speaker). Turkey's military operation undermines regional security and threatens the Global Coalition to Fight Daesh.
