Any security concerns of our neighbours must be addressed by political and diplomatic means, while respecting international law and in coordination with OUR partners, not unilateral action. The temporary cessation of hostilities, unfortunately, has not led to a permanent cessation of the suffering of people in the region. And yes, really want it or not, Turkey is our important neighbor. We are mutually needed and therefore dialogue and cooperation on migration and security must be maintained. It is in our interest that Turkey remain on the European track, democratise itself, honour its commitments, including respecting the terms of the Customs Union, and countries that are at the European-Turkish border must receive European solidarity to preserve and ensure the security of the Union's external borders – Cyprus, Greece and Bulgaria. Thank you!

name: Andreas SCHIEDER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The military offensive by Turkey is, firstly, contrary to international law and, secondly, clearly motivated by Turkish domestic policy, because Erdogan has recently lost many elections. The consequences of this are mass exodus of civilians, Kurds, Christians, Syrians, Armenians and Yazidis. More than 200 000 are already on the run, 70 000 of them children. There is a danger that the 'Islamic State' will re-energise, and we must state quite clearly that the YPG are not terrorists, but freedom fighters who have also freed Europe from the epidemic of Islamic terror. What does it take now? What is needed is a genuine ceasefire, a diplomatic offensive, a demilitarised zone, humanitarian aid, an arms embargo, sanctions against Turkey, the debate on whether we should not put the accession negotiations on hold and, above all, solidarity with the Kurdish self-government in Rojava.

name: Phil BENNION
text: – Madam President, the American withdrawal may be one of the greatest betrayals of modern times. A year ago, Donald Trump said of the Kurdish militias: ‘They fought with us, they died with us’, ‘They are a great people’, ‘We do not forget that, I do not forget that’. The Kurds unfortunately now stand as the useful idiots of the Americans. The American withdrawal is not only a betrayal. It is in geopolitical terms highly irresponsible.  Now the vacuum may have left Turkey with what it sees as a difficult decision to make, but Turkey would do better to look to its own territory and give more political space to opposition parties supported by the Kurds, and to journalists supporting their rights if it is to successfully address terrorist threats. We now urgently need a political solution that allows rapid return of displaced persons, but also minimises the strategic ground conceded to Russia, Assad and Iran.

name: Susanna CECCARDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, only a hundred years ago the Armenian people were mercilessly massacred. Today, the same executioners are attacking the Kurdish people in Istanbul, they still crave an empire, and it does not matter whether the blood of innocents, such as that of Hevrin Khalaf, the Kurdish women's rights leader massacred in silence throughout the world by pro-Turkish and Islamist militiamen, should flow for this. The fearsome head cutters, after the Turkish invasion of Syria, are sharpening their scimitars in front of our doors. Erdogan blackmails Europe with terrorists held in Kurdish galleys, threatens to open up borders, and does so after cashing in six billion euros from Europe. This is unacceptable!  Faced with all this, while the United States and Russia are acting as international players, Europe is mocked, silent and immobile, and it is doing so with the High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Federica Mogherini, for whom I apologise as an Italian. Today, those who are not prepared to condemn the Turkish regime and take the actions that follow those who continue to want Turkey in Europe are complicit. No to Turkey in Europe, now and always!

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Just on the sidelines and in advance to Mr Sonneborn: personally, I find it very nasty how you are abusing this Parliament. Her cynical speech at the expense of the mistreated people in Syria was more than disgusting. Please reflect on your own speech!  The Kurdish people have been betrayed. As aides against ISIS, the Kurds were left alone by us Europeans, and the Americans, by their withdrawal, cleared the way for the invasion of Turkey. Everyone knew that Turkey would invade as soon as the Americans withdrew their troops. The suffering of the people of Syria, of families, women and children, seems endless, cruel and urgently needs to be brought to an end. The Nobel Peace Prize and our values oblige us to act and also to take a very clear stand by saying quite clearly: no, Mr Erdogan, this invasion is not a 'source of peace', it is a violation of international law and it is murder. There is no place in our EU for warmongers, aggressors and barbaric dictators. We must make that very clear. There is no room in our European house for states that disregard human dignity, freedom of expression, freedom of religion and freedom of the press and whose prisons are increasingly filled with political prisoners. Diplomacy is always necessary – no question – but sanctions at all levels, the freezing of funds and very clear statements from the EU must underpin and accompany diplomacy. And that is exactly what I lack in our proposal. It is important that Europe speaks with a strong voice here, unequivocally ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Madam President, many references here were made to the lack of unity in the European Union and the failure to even release a common resolution, a declaration condemning Turkish aggression. Firstly, as it was Hungary that vetoed this common declaration, as a Hungarian I think I must apologise and make it extremely clear that, when Viktor Orbán speaks on behalf of Hungarians, then it must be rejected. I can assure you that it is not in the interest of Hungarians or of Hungary to support any aggression, wherever it may be. No, it is not in the interest of Hungarians, and as far as the Turkish military action is concerned, we must understand Turkish security concerns, but we also have to make it clear that there is no military solution to this problem, only political and diplomatic. This aggression only further destabilises Syria, diverts attention from fighting terrorism and exacerbates the migration crisis. There were questions asked about where the European Union is. We have been standing by and watching as our neighbourhood was destabilised in North Africa and in the Middle East. We must place Europe back on the map and make it more visible before other dominant powers take over control. (Last sentence inaudible)

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, indignation is widely shared here, but outrage is not enough! What is at stake is peace in the Middle East, of course, but it is also our own security because Mr Erdogan is now the first ally of Daesh, and the attack he is carrying out will have consequences on European soil. Yet we remain unable to respond. Let us be clear, this silence is the effect of Europe's impotence because our countries have not been able to give themselves the means of their strategic autonomy in defence, because our Europe has built a market, instead of sharing principles from our common civilisation and, of course, because we are unable to freely determine our migration policy. The migratory blackmail that Mr Erdogan is putting on us is an opportunity to experience concretely europe's inability to control its external borders, which makes us unable to contribute to the balance of the world.  We urgently need to give ourselves the means to act so that we never again remain spectators trapped in this guilty impotence, and from now on we will have to break with cowardice by putting all our forces in the balance. In order to force Turkey to negotiate, we must urgently suspend the funds paid to that country by the European Union, which have nothing to do with an accession programme.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, Turkey is carrying out ethnic cleansing with a view to the disappearance of the Kurdish element from the region, taking advantage of the space given by the Americans with their withdrawal. Everyone is present in the region, with a great deal of support for the European Union, which, in the end, apart from the victims of the Turkish atrocities, is the one who pays the bill, without being able to take any initiative and stop the Turkish invasion. Obviously, the economic transactions of European countries are more important than the protection of the Kurdish people who fought Daesh. It is not possible for the entire European Union to continue to be held hostage to Erdoğan's blackmail. (applause)

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Madam President, the Kurdish, Christian Arab and Turkmen fighters fought for the honour of humanity. What exactly has our humanity gone? These words are those of Bérivan Gozel, a Belgian, European and Kurdish citizen, who is speaking to us this morning. We are Kurds today in the face of the illegal operation launched by Turkey in Kurdistan.  An American president who makes the worst decisions, a Turkish president who bombs the Syrian Kurds - the most determined resistance fighters against the barbarity of Daesh - those men and women who fought for us, who fought for their freedom, who fought for our freedom. The irony of all this is that, at the end of the day, these enemies of democracy are strengthened. Bashar al-Assad, today, almost legitimate, is a climax! So where is Europe in all this? A European arms embargo rejected by our ministers is incomprehensible, and then - and this is our paragraph 13 - we reduce the pre-accession credits paid to Turkey, we stop asking the question, we freeze without affecting the civilian population. To regain our lost dignity is at this price.

name: Peter KOFOD
text: Madam President! I'm incredibly worried. Erdogan is directly threatening Europe with sending millions of migrants towards the European continent. Let me say it as it is: the EU system has failed, effectively handing over control of the external borders to Erdogan. At the same time, the EU system fills Turkey's treasury with billions of euros, which is taxpayers' money. Moreover, the European Union has failed in an equally disastrous way when it comes to protecting the external borders, which are hollow as a sieve.  Now Erdogan is directly threatening us with the same chaos we saw in 2015, when Europe starred in migrants. Before we look around, we risk a situation where jihadists equipped with European passports travel to Europe for Christmas, so peaceful European citizens have to jump for their lives at the Christmas markets. The EU elite seems to be up against it. It's weak, ridiculous and grotesque.  To make matters worse, a large majority in parliament recently refused to slam the coffers for Erdogan and forever rule out Turkish membership of the EUROPEAN Union. It's a joke. And that is very much the fault and responsibility of this Parliament.

name: Lucia ĎURIŠ NICHOLSONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to say that I used to be very proud of the European Union project, but I am now ashamed of how alibiistically the European Union has behaved in the conflict in northern Syria and how we have thrown the Kurds literally overboard. We criticize Trump for withdrawing his troops from northern Syria, but the Middle East is close to the Territory of the European Union, not the US. So I'm asking: where are our troops? Let us look into the glam weakness of our foreign and security policy. We stayed at the statistics level. The Kurds are consulting with Assad, the West is completely out of the game with its own cowardice. Erdogan consults with Putin, not nato allies. Putin is mocked and we are quietly shaking in front of a new wave of refugees and being blackmailed by Erdogan. Where are all those forces now, including the leaders of the V4 countries, talking about how problems need to be tackled where they arise? They are quietly waiting for the new refugee wave to become a topic for them to populistly win new national elections. Shame on us, shame on the European Union for the alibiist we are behaving in the Kurdistan conflict.

name: Alexandra Lesley PHILLIPS
text: – Madam President, the UK has finally suspended arms exports to Turkey: too little too late. We now want economic sanctions, but our intentions are futile when the EU continues to pay this rogue state to further commercial and expansionist ambitions. The Kurds, in their tens of thousands, stood shoulder to shoulder with Europe to protect us from brutal terrorists. Thousands laid down their lives. They should be rewarded. Instead, the EU does nothing, while Erdoğan uses EU bribes to fund his war and commit human rights atrocities, from the murder of civilians to chemical weapons. What price the life of a Kurd? Based on the EUR 1 500 a day the EU gives to Turkey and the 160 000 Kurdish people now displaced, apparently one cent. This is not only a tragedy but a major historical betrayal, and I implore this morally bankrupt political bloc to change course. It’s funny: everybody in this Chamber is in agreement on this. So the executive must take heed or they prove this Parliament is pointless. (Applause)

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, I would first like to say that I am following much of today's speeches in condemning, without any, I would say, reservation, of the Turkish offensive in the northern part of Syria, which is causing hundreds of thousands of refugees, has certainly caused many victims and represents not only a violation of international law, but also of human rights. I must say that the European Union, and in particular the European Council, must take more drastic and firmer measures against Erdoğan's offensive. And I must say that I am very concerned, even by the similarities with some historical precedents, this Erdoğan-Putin pact.  We cannot deliver Syria's fortunes and fate to a deal between two autocrats: one, Erdoğan, and the other, Putin. We have seen this more than once in history and we have seen that the result has been a tragic result for the people, but also for world peace.

name: Giuliano PISAPIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we all live with anguish and anger the Turkish invasion of Syria, not a peace operation against terrorism, but a two-way war operation, a crime against humanity.  The Kurdish people have been betrayed, the international community has shamefully turned their backs on them, the Putin-Erdogan agreement is yet another piece against peace, against freedom, against democracy. It is not enough to restrict the sale of arms, we must have the strength and the courage to stop a real criminal madness.  "Hope", wrote Pablo Neruda, "has two daughters: outrage and courage. Outrage at the reality of things; courage to change them." The resolution we are going to vote on tomorrow is an important step forward. But then we have to move on from words to deeds. I believe that we urgently need a no-fly zone, an intervention army to protect the Kurdish people, humanitarian corridors and economic sanctions against the Turkish regime. If not now, when?

name: Antony HOOK
text: – Madam President, Turkey’s offensive against Kurds in northern Syria has devastated medical facilities, civilians, and deprived thousands of people of access to clean water. This is helping ISIS to revive and further destabilise the region. Some Member States promptly banned arms sales to Turkey. Liberal Democrat MEPs wrote to the UK Prime Minister to demand we also stop enabling genocide. The UK has now promised to issue no new export licenses, but will not review licenses already granted. This is a moral halfway house that is not acceptable and Donald Trump supporting actions in this matter underlines the need for a strong, effective Europe. If we give arms to those who commit crimes we are responsible as those who pull the trigger. There has been no real prospect of Turkey joining the EU for many years. The time has come to formally end Turkey’s status as an EU candidate country.

name: Elena LIZZI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is not only the Kurds, to whom our solidarity goes, who are at risk. The Turkish offensive threatens to make the Christian community that has been present in Syria for two millennia disappear and an essential part of its social fabric disappear. The defence of Christianity outside and within the Schengen area is an obligation that the European Union cannot shirk. Europe must play a leading role in defending peace in the Middle East and guaranteeing human rights, without bowing to arrogance, blackmail and the explicit threat of being invaded by 3.6 million immigrants. However, when someone fills their mouths with sanctions, then some people cannot forget that the European Union itself has financed Ankara for years through various channels, such as the Pre-Accession Assistance Instruments, the financing of the European Investment Bank or contributions in the form of refugee assistance to Turkey.  Now, more than ever, it must be clear that turkey's accession to the European Union must be stopped. Its entry would be behind the Islamization of our continent that would reduce Christians to a small persecuted minority as is currently the case in Syria ....  (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, Turkey's invasion of Syria is a heinous crime, a crime against the European Union, against Europe and against humanity. I believe it is time to end the words in the European Union and take action. Zero tolerance in Turkey, which is not just attacking the Kurds, it is attacking humanity. It was the Kurds who stood as a shield, who fought for the dissolution of ISIS to keep Europe quiet, and yet Europe, at the moment, is essentially, because of its tolerance, among those who will be considered complicit in this historic and criminal mistake against humanity.  Turkey always comes back: 1915 was the extermination of the Armenians, 1918 was the Greeks of Pontus, 1922 the Greeks of Izmir, 1955 Istanbul, 1974 of my homeland, Cyprus, last year it was Afrin, this year is the genocide of the Kurds. We can't wait any longer. I consider myself a proud European, but I feel ashamed when the Turks, with European weapons, attack the Kurds and we still do not take decisive steps to stop this invasion of Turkey. (applause)

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Madam President, in the north of Syria, the ceasefire is very fragile and Erdogan can threaten it extremely quickly with his impulsive preteas and threats also because of the disunity of the European Union.  The Turkish attacks are a violation of international law. European leaders must take a united stance on ending arms sales to Turkey, including on economic sanctions, which could be a significant lever of ankara's influence.  We also forget that the Kurdish issue is far from over by ending turkish attacks, and on the contrary, linking the Kurds to the Assad regime will not satisfy their aspirations. The north of Syria, along with the north of Iraq and the southeast of Turkey, where Turkey often carries out military operations against the Kurds, will unfortunately remain a time bomb, causing new deaths, new refugees and humanitarian catastrophes as well as a source of conflict outside the region.  Where did she go, colleagues, our humanity? We can be really ashamed.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to this long debate. We feel frustration, but we cannot say that we feel anguish, because anguish is felt when you try to survive under the bombs. Nor can we say that we did not know that the United States was going to leave the area: we knew, we were warned. We knew that Turkey was going to attack, and we also knew that dangerous jihadists were going to escape and that a whole spiral of revitalization of the world of Dáesh and terrorism could be generated: we knew that because we were warned.  We Europeans have missed the opportunity, before the United States escaped, to be able to act with an international criminal court, to be able to avoid impunity, to be able to act on the European minors in the area: we have missed all those opportunities. And the reason is, we're a commercial giant, but we're not a political giant. In a globalized world, violence, catastrophes and such geostrategic conflicts affect us. How they're not going to affect us! We are still trying to regulate a migration crisis that comes from these hornet-goers. Now, if we don't end the contradictions we have and if we don't have a security and defense policy, we're not going to be able to face the future.

name: Alexander ALEXANDROV YORDANOV
text: – Dear Madam President, as of yesterday we have a new situation. Putin and Erdogan achieved what they wanted. The culprit of the Syrian tragedy, Bashar Assad, agrees with their agreement. The action of Russia and Turkey is not just anti-Kurdish, it is also anti-European, because it comes in response to our positions. What should worry us most is the ongoing rapprochement between Ankara and Moscow, between Damascus and Moscow. Authoritarian leaders from diplomatic European flirtations do not understand. We are not a world military leader, but we can offer ideas and solutions to problems. This means offering a vision to solve both the Kurdish people's and national issues, but that does not mean supporting left-wing nationalist parties of the Kurds, as they operate on Turkish territory. Thank you!

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: – Mr President, Turkey's action is clearly contrary to international law and is totally unacceptable. Unfortunately, the European Union has remained a bystander, a successor, as Turkey, the United States, Russia, Syria and even Iran organise things in the region and the affairs of the people in the region. Syrian oil now has more protectors and rights than refugees or Kurds – kurds to whom we owe so much. The European Parliament must send out a very clear message from here. We expect decisive – more decisive – action from the High Representative, the Council and the Member States to put an end to this tragedy and to ensure that Turkey understands the limits of its activities. This means sanctions, and that means a common European Union policy to stop arms exports as well.

name: Christophe GRUDLER
text: Madam President, this new war in northern Syria, on the initiative of Turkey, is a violation of international law. It is an inhumane decision that displaces 300,000 people, including 70,000 children, with 120 civilians already killed. This is not a fight against terrorists, but against peoples, including the Kurdish people, the vast majority of whom aspire to only one thing: to live in peace and freedom. We are much more powerful in turning to each other, rather than turning against each other. Mr. Erdogan should ponder that sentence. The 30-kilometre safety zone it imposes, manu militari, does not provide a lasting solution. How many Syrians from Turkey will really want to settle there voluntarily? And I would remind you that international law prohibits sending refugees back across the border.  Eight years after the beginning of the war, the ordeal of Syrian refugees and peoples, especially the Kurdish people, is, alas, still not over.

name: David LEGA
text: – Madam President, it should now be beyond any doubt to everyone that Erdoğan’s Turkey does not belong in this European Union, and by invading Syria and using his war on terror as a pretext to displace and slaughter civilians, Erdoğan has made it perfectly clear that the international rule-based order is not to his liking – just like he is illustrating by occupying Cyprus, drilling off its coastline and repeatedly violating Greek airspace and territorial waters. And by persecuting and harassing political opponents and Kurdish and Christian citizens on a massive scale, Erdoğan has also made it perfectly clear that he detests everything that this European Union stands for. Erdoğan detests our European way of life. He detests our democracy, our fundamental freedom, our human rights, our liberty and our rule of law. There cannot be a place for Erdoğan’s Turkey in the EU, and now is the time for this European Union to terminate accession talks with Turkey. (Applause)

name: Attila ARA-KOVÁCS
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support There are certainly many people in this room who have read the book musza dagh, born in the last century. The horrific genocide presented there now seems to be a repeat, which we cannot leave unans forth. At the same time, it is unacceptable that an EU government, I am talking about the Hungarian government, is supporting an autocratic regime that is waging war against the Kurds in Syria, which is destabilising the region and causing a humanitarian crisis. So let it be clear: Viktor Orban, who has declared refugees enemies and alarmed them, has acted in the service of an aggression that has forced hundreds of thousands of people to flee their homes. The system in which the Union's foreign policy operates today is also untenable. We must not allow unscrupulous and unscrupulous politicians to prevent the European Union from taking joint action on foreign and security policy issues over and over again. I therefore call on the Council to finally move from a unanimous vote to a decision based on a qualified majority.

name: Klemen GROŠELJ
text: – Madam President, the Turkish invasion of Syria is a new circle of hell in this tragedy of the 21st century. We are witnessing the trampling of the fundamental rules of humanitarian and international law, the rules on which modern regulation of the world is based, and this is what the military of a NATO Member State and its direct subordinate militias and armed paramilitary formations are doing.  Although Turkey claims that this is about guaranteeing its security interests, let us not be naïve. The Sochi meeting clearly showed what it was all about. This is a brutal and uncompromizing exercise of geopolitical interests in the context of Syria's so-called post-war regime.  It is also not about fighting terrorism, if it is why Turkey is destroying the only serious counter-terrorism force, the Kurds, who have contributed the lion's share to the victory over the barbarism of the Islamic State, which has directly threatened the European Union.  Erdogan's threat to the new refugee wave has also been signaled. I would have abused the unhappiness and suffering of millions of people, which he partly caused himself, as a means of brutal political blackmail by the EU.  There is no doubt about the urgency of a common European response. We must be aware that the EU has both the means and the possibility of influencing Turkish behaviour. The only question is whether we also have the will to do so.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A proverb says that the first victim in every war is the truth. The title of this Turkish military action is "source of peace". That was the first lie at the beginning. It is not a source of peace, it is a source of violence and expulsion, of atrocities that Turkey has set in motion here and caused to bubble up. Turkey is whistling at European values; we must take note of this. We must deprive Turkey of candidate status for the European Union. Is it not absurd that a stark minority of Heads of Government should prevent states such as Albania and Northern Macedonia, which have done so much for European values and carried out reforms, from being granted accession status, but Turkey still has accession status? If we send a clear signal, let us continue to cool down the already weak Turkish economy by suspending the customs union, let us send a clear signal to Turkey! We do not reject anyone forever. We know that half of the Turkish population is not behind the regime, but the regime needs a cool head, and a cooleconomy will help. We are speaking on behalf of Europeans. Let us send a clear signal!

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Madam President, about a year and a half ago we were discussing the Turkish invasion of Afrin again in this Chamber. From this particular business, all that's changed is the name. From the "Olive Branch" we passed to the "Source of Peace". But let us be clear, Erdoğan, from the background of destabilisation in Syria, is now a protagonist with the tolerance of the international community and the great geopolitical players in the region and is beating the Kurds, those who have resisted the Islamic State and the crimes against humanity that it has committed. After eight years of bloody civil war, the Turkish invasion is a source of blood and a source of human crisis, not a source of peace, as Mr Erdoğan ironically christened it, who will not respect international law, no matter how much we call it.  That is why real sanctions are now needed, an immediate pan-European arms embargo which will not be limited to new orders but will immediately stop the delivery of arms by all Member States. With targeted sanctions against those responsible for the invasion and, of course, with trade sanctions proving that Europe means what it says. (applause)

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, with the departure of US troops from northern Syria, President Trump is totally abandoning the Kurds and Christians there. The so-called deal that the American leader has struck with dictator Erdoğan in his immeasurable wisdom is not working. Putin and Erdoğan have since taken control of that. Unfortunately, the Council of Foreign Ministers is also shameful: it continues to suspend arms supplies and turkish ambassadors are called to the mat in European capitals. That too is a slap in the face to the Kurds and Christians in the region. It is therefore time for a very firm European position: military and financial and economic relations with Turkey must not be suspended but stopped completely, and Europe must support the Kurds and Christians wherever possible. Thank you.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her One thing must be clear to all of us: there will be no military solution for this region. There can only be one political one, and only with the involvement of the United Nations, which has not yet been mentioned in more than two hours of debate. What we are witnessing at the moment is a Turkish invasion with Russia's approval. We are seeing the abandoning of the Kurdish-led democratic forces, the best allies of the international community. We are seeing Erdogan and Putin meeting and de facto dividing power in Syria among themselves. The EU, if we look at it soberly, is not a big player in this region. We missed the point, but we do not have the powers either, and how the Brexit party is lying, for example, is that the EU should act, but at the same time it is not given powers. Our greatest weight is economic sanctions, a halt to the supply of arms – this must be the response of a strong EU that cannot be blackmailed by refugee agreements and which respects international law.

name: Juan Ignacio ZOIDO ÁLVAREZ
text: – Madam President, it is clear in today's debate that the serious facts of the Turkish military operation in northeastern Syria have dramatic social, political and economic consequences. But today, this morning, I would like to emphasise the release of thousands of ISIS terrorists on a European passport: they can return to Europe, with the consequent security crisis across the Union.  Ladies and gentlemen, we have thousands of uncontrolled terrorists who want to get to Europe and we cannot afford it. In Spain we have suffered the scourge of ETA terrorism for decades, with thousands of victims, but he was defeated by the work of the law enticing forces and law en forces, by the judiciary and by the support of Spanish society.  That is why, from our experience, we believe that, in order to combat terrorism, the European Union needs a more comprehensive and ambitious foreign security and defence policy that prevents these former ISIS combatants from committing terrorist acts in the face of their uncontrolledness.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, today we send a strong and stark message of our absolute rejection of Turkey's military invasion in northeastern Syria; a decision that disparages international law and our United Nations or NATO mechanisms, which has very serious humanitarian consequences, that brings war back to a stabilized area, and which causes, or pursues, not only causes, population displacements to ethnically reconfigure the population, which has been done and is being done with the complicity of the United States and has as victims the Kurds , those allies—so far—to fight and defeat ISIS. And, moreover, with clear benefits for Al-Asad and Putin in the region.  Europe not only has to reject intervention; you have to respond firmly using our tools: banning the sale of arms to Turkey, using our market – from which Turkey benefits – and making decisions about an accession process that has ceased to make sense to Turkey and the European Union.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Madam President, it’s been said already but we need to repeat it: the Turkish invasion into north—eastern Syria threatens the stability of the whole region. It strengthens those who want to ignite a much larger conflict in the Middle East. It is therefore in our vital interest – the vital interest of the EU and our Member States – to fight for the territorial integrity of Syria. We cannot allow the redrawing of borders in a forceful way. We cannot allow the precedents from the annexation of Crimea to be repeated in Syria today. This is extremely important, and we have to resist it. Therefore, an arms embargo, financial sanctions and the suspension of EU accession talks with Turkey is the least we can do immediately, and we should do it now. More broadly, we do need to fight for European values in our neighbourhood. We cannot allow the increasing Turkish and Russian presence in our vicinity. This is our vital European strategic interest.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Erdogan has carried out an act of war, an attack. That is the first thing we in the European Parliament have to say. That is why the answer must be very tough.  Until now, Europe has struggled to make itself heard with a single, clear and strong voice. We do not need general condemnations, we need very clear acts. Turkey's military intervention is a path to which economic and trade sanctions, the arms embargo, so as not to leave alone the main victims, first and foremost the women and men of the Kurdish people such as Hevrin Khalaf. Immediate interventions therefore of direct support, there on the ground, a people, the Kurdish people to whom we must show great solidarity, which was used first in the fight against terrorism and then shamefully dumped. It is also a serious matter to see Erdogan blackmailing Europe on the skin of refugees and displaced persons. For them, too, the conflict must end immediately and the Turkish army must be withdrawn immediately.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: Madam President, Turkey, on the pretext that the Kurds residing in Syria are collective terrorists, has invaded that country and is carrying out military operations on Syrian territory, with civilian casualties and innocent children. It is the same country that in 1974, under a similar pretext, invaded the Republic of Cyprus and since then has held 40 % of the island.  We all endorse the decision of the European Council which unequivocally condemns the military intervention that has caused and caused hundreds of human casualties, undermines the fight against ISIS and poses a serious threat to European security. We condemn the attack in Syria, Turkey, without asterisks and without footnotes. (applause)

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Madam President, in 2016 the European Union signed with Turkey an EU Facility which it had, with the aim of supporting the 3.5 million refugees, 0.7% of the population of the European Union to 28, who are in Turkey. But it is good to remember that it was the closure of borders, the restrictive view of the Dublin agreement, the revision of which some Member States persist in blocking, and the lack of solidarity of some Member States of the Union with the Member States that had received more refugees that created the need for this mechanism.  Since then, Turkey has systematically blackmailed the European Union, threatening to open its doors, and is now doing so once again. Although Turkey claims security reasons, always legitimate, this military operation in north-eastern Syria must be stopped, there is no military solution. The European Union must act with one voice and mobilise its influence by working with the United Nations to achieve peace in this region of the world so massacred.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, ní minic a bhíonn an Pharlaimint seo ar aon ghuth, maidir le haon rud. Ach táimid ar aon ghuth ar maidin ag cáineadh a bhfuil á dhéanamh ag an Tuirc in iarthuaisceart na Siria. Agus tuigimid gurb é an bhunchúis atá leis ná gur tharraing Donald Trump a fhórsaí amach go tobann ar mhaithe lena íomhá féin ag an mbaile, gan féachaint don rud a tharlódh ina dhiaidh sin.  Mar a dúirt an Coimisinéir Stylianides, feicimid cad a tharla – na Coirdínigh ag fulaingt arís mar a tharla dóibh leis na cianta, dhá chéad míle duine ag teitheadh gan dídean, agus ISIS ag teacht ar ais. Caithfimid ár ndícheall a dhéanamh, ar dtús, cosc a chur ar airm a easpórtáil chuig an Tuirc, féachaint ar an gcúnamh airgeadais atá á thabhairt againn dóibh agus, go háirithe, réiteach polaitiúil a fháil faoi choimirce na Náisiún Aontaithe.

name: Kris PEETERS
text: Mr President, it is a good thing that we are sending a clear and clear message from the European Parliament to Turkey. Our motion for a resolution speaks volumes: Turkey must realise that our pre-accession aid is not unconditional, and the financial envelope that Turkey receives to reform itself to European standards cannot and must not be paid any further. The crisis in northern Syria is a clear wake-up call for the European Union: we urgently need a genuine European asylum and migration policy and a genuine European defence policy, and the European Union must resolutely support an international security zone in northern Syria controlled by an international military force. Only in this way can we stop the flight of people, detain the IS fighters, bring the children back and stabilise the region.

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Madam President, we have closed our eyes to a crime. We have left the people who fought ISIS in turkey's hands and we are debating, here today, in Europe, whether we should take action and when. Let me remind you that, 45 years ago, Turkey called the invasion of my country a 'peace operation'. Forty-five years later, we still have 200,000 refugees, unhoused and missing. Then, 45 years ago, the international community fell silent and let Turkey complete its crime in Cyprus. So today, he's silent again. Syria 2019 - Cyprus 1974: the perpetrator remains the same and remains unpunished. Our responsibilities are enormous; Europe is absent. History will judge us. (applause)

name: Hildegard BENTELE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today we are talking about Turkey's military operation in northern Syria, which is contrary to international law, and its consequences. The situation has been so far, and unfortunately for years, that in Syria – in close proximity to the EU, which is directly concerned with European interests – the despot Assad, the US and Russia are in charge and the European Union is excluded, apart from the financing of humanitarian aid. The conclusion that we should draw from this – and here I come back to key EPP demands – is that we in the EU must finally create the decision-making structures – for example, a European Security Council and an EU Defence Council – and provide the appropriate military capabilities, so that the initiatives of individual Member States, such as that of the German Defence Minister, to establish an international protection zone can be immediately treated and evaluated at European level and also lead to joint European action. The consequence of this unacceptable Turkish action should be that the EU finally becomes sovereign in terms of security policy and not only verbally condemns terrorism, expulsion and ethnic cleansing, but actively participates in the fight against terrorism and in peacekeeping. Let us leave behind disunity and discouragement and take a decisive step towards political union in this parliamentary term!

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Madam President, Turkey is once again implementing its illegal plans in defiance of international law. He invaded northern Syria, spreading death, displacing thousands of people, leading them to refugee camps. He's trying to clean up ethnic cleansing, with European funds, he's criminally against humanity. The United States, Russia, Assad are counting gains and losses, while the West appears to be an awkward observer. Our values are shaken and we have a responsibility for that. Over time, the Turkish policy of revisionism has no principles, does not respect international rules, does not count any. We must proceed immediately to the implementation of targeted economic sanctions, with respect for civil society and send a clear message to Turkey that, at its own risk, it is not welcome in the European family. (applause)

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: – Madam President, I’m reading the title, ‘The Turkish military operation in north-east Syria and its consequences’. I think it could have been much better. It could read like this. This is not just a military operation, it is a military invasion and its consequences are not just matters of security, of the betrayal of our Kurdish allies against the scourge of Islamic State. The consequences of this military Turkish invasion are specific crimes against humanity, including ethnic cleansing and the plans for illegal settlements against Syria, just like with the continuing Turkish occupation of the north part of the Republic of Cyprus, just like Afrin, but we can. We can impose an arms embargo, we can crush Erdoğan’s economy and, yes, we can bring the criminals to justice. It’s about time.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, I would like to express here our total rejection of Turkey's unlawful attack on the Kurdish community. This invasion violates international law, is producing civilian casualties and mass population movements. It also seeks to alter Rojava's demographics, relocating two million refugees to an area where Kurds, Arabs, Turkmens and Assyrians lived democratically.  The invasion will overcome Kurdistan's borders, reopening conflicts involving the great world powers. Avoiding this requires NATO to withdraw its support for Turkey and for the United Nations and the Union to combat this violation of international law with effective sanctions.  In addition, it is urgent to sponsor a dialogued solution to the crisis. This diplomatic work should be combined with humanitarian aid and pay particular attention to the repatriation of minors born to European ISIS fighters.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We have European diplomacy, we have instruments, we have tools, we have resources, we have everything and what? Russia is a step ahead of us – it is very sad. We should, as the Europe that is most affected by the conflict in the Middle East, make every effort to ensure that this conflict simply comes to an end and not only on a verbal level, not only at the level of regret, but in making every diplomatic effort to make this happen on all agendas.  First of all, we should also celebrate the fate of the victims. I thank Commissioner Stylianides, because the activities are indeed organised, but it must be remembered that there are still many organisations, missionaries who work, who have not left this country, even though this is a huge threat, including a threat to life and health. Commissioner, I ask you to strengthen these organisations. 38 million is a lot, but we can still do much more. This is my appeal.  (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Madam President, words, words, words. Erdoğan invades Syria, with a green light from Trump, with Putin's backs, closes agreements at the expense of international law and legality, revises the Treaty of Lausanne and the European Union in practice proves to be a political dwarf. Because the words of condemnation are not enough - projects are needed, targeted economic sanctions, an effective arms embargo. There has been a unanimous council decision for a few months now, to which Alexis Tsipras and President Anastasiades have contributed. It is time for this to be specialized and implemented, and unfortunately governments such as Germany and France are preventing it, with cynicism, for their economic interests. Let's be honest. (applause)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, the Turkish invasion of Syria must be condemned. It was aimed at the Kurds who were fighting the Islamic State, some of whose fighters are now at large again because of Turkey. The intervention has created instability and caused another wave of refugees, but above all this intervention has caused the loss of human life and suffering of innocent people. It is good that Turkey has now stopped this offensive, it is also at the pressure of the United States, the European Union. A security zone in the north of Syria would make sense, but only under the supervision of international forces, not as territory cleared by the Turkish army and occupied by the Turkish army. The Turkish invasion cannot be seen only as an isolated act, but unfortunately Turkey has been acting in recent years as a country that does not share the same values as the European Union.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, millions of people from diverse ethnic and religious communities in this region are under threat. Tens of thousands have been displaced. Besides Kurdish and Arabic villages, Christian neighbourhoods have been targeted. It’s obvious these attacks are carried out by Turkish military with the aim of ethnic cleansing and demographic change. As a member of Women Defend Rojava, an international campaign against fascism and patriarchy, I raise my voice here to call for: an immediate end to Turkey’s invasion and occupation in north and east Syria; the establishment of a no-fly zone; an end to the weapons trade with Turkey; political and economic sanctions against Turkey; the recognition of war crimes already committed by Turkey and the prevention of further war crimes and ethnic cleansing by Turkish forces, ISIS, al-Nusra and other jihadist terrorist groups; the acknowledgment of the democratic Autonomous Administration of North and East Syria; and a political solution with representation and participation of women and people from all the different national cultural and religious communities in Syria. We need... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Please, Ms Ward, everyone needs to get their opportunity.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Madam President, I welcome the resolution and the calls made to Turkey, and I agree with the calls for the European Commission to freeze payments to Turkey and to make sure that these funds do not finance military operations.  But just the calls won't do. We must not let ourselves be blackmailed into Erdogan. We should not allow the security issues of a region in the immediate vicinity of the Union to be exclusively determined by other countries. We should not allow the killing, the violent movement of people, the humanitarian catastrophe in all dimensions.  In addition to economic sanctions, the freezing of European funds payments and a Pan-European arms embargo, at least the so-called No Fly Zone and the UN ice secury zone should be put in place.  True, Moscow and Ankara have reached an agreement and say Turkey sees no need to continue the offensive at this stage. What does that mean? At least that residents will still be in fear of attacks. I repeat, at least that. It is high time that we unified European foreign policy and finally assumed responsibility, which comes with the supposedly geopolitical ... (The Speaker's Chair deprive the speaker of the floor.)

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, military intervention in Syria is not a question of the moment. This military intervention in Syria has already taken eight years and has been responsible: the United States of America and the great powers of the European Union, which, together with other NATO members such as Turkey, and other its allies, such as Israel, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates or Qatar, have contributed to the organization and arming of terrorist groups , for the murder of thousands of people and the forced displacement of millions of others and the destruction and social, economic and patrimonial disorganization of a country. The position of this Parliament and other institutions of the European Union, as well as several governments of countries that are part of it and which want to pass on an image of distancing from this new military aggression against Syria, is absolutely hypocritical.  Condemning Turkey is not enough. It is essential to end the destabilisation and external aggression against the Arab Republic of Syria and to defend its sovereignty, its independence and territorial integrity, while respecting international law and the principles of the Charter of the United Nations.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in this debate I would also like to point out that the first victims, the most defenceless of the Turkish military offensive in north-east Syria, are children. It is precisely the European Union guidelines of 2008 on children and armed conflicts that underline that it is the little ones who suffer the greatest and most lasting suffering in every conflict, and the one that is taking place in Syria is certainly no exception. Unicef estimates that at least 70 000 children have been displaced in north-east Syria since the start of the armed intervention, but if hostilities continue, tens of thousands more children may soon need humanitarian assistance. In accordance with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, the thirtieth anniversary of which we will be celebrating in a few days' time, it is therefore necessary for the European Union to step up diplomatic efforts in favour of peace, so that the parties to the conflict and all those on the ground who can exert real influence work to ensure maximum protection for all children involved in this umpteenth conflict. Children are children in every situation. We have a duty to protect them!  (The President withdrew the floor from the Speaker)

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, Turkey has crossed the border and entered the sovereign country of Syria. It’s a violation of international law. Turkey has invaded Syria, not Kurdistan. We must express solidarity with the Kurdish people, but the territorial integrity of Syria is a matter for the Syrians to decide.  About 8% of the Kurds live in Syria and 50% of them live in Turkey, where they are treated abysmally, making Turkey an apartheid state in their behaviour. When the PKK fighters cross the border into Syria, they are called rebel fighters. When they come back into Turkey, they are called terrorists. And what is Europe doing about it? Sadly, Europe paid Turkey EUR 6 billion in the last two years to cage migrants whose homes were destroyed with the help of European countries. When is Europe going to stop behaving like this?

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, you have the opportunity to see unanimity here. Yes, I have heard that both the Council and the Commission are critical of this attack and the invasion of Turkey in Syria. We criticize, too, but is it enough just to criticize? We have a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow, but is that enough? I believe that the European Union, together with other international institutions, has an obligation to intervene concretely. And what can we do?  Sure, Turkey is important, it is important as a Turkey market, but what do we choose between the economic development of the internal market and the security of citizens? That's where people die, children die, women die, citizens die that we, in fact, must defend, because one of the european Union's objectives is also to ensure security and peace. As Mr Juncker said yesterday: yes, in the European Union we have peace, but is that enough? We have an international responsibility and I think we need to do more than just a resolution.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this exchange of views was useful and timely. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the honourable Members for their interventions, comments and suggestions. Turkey’s unilateral military action in north-east Syria has, and is, causing unacceptable human suffering. It undermines the fight against Daesh, it threatens European security. For all these reasons, the European Council on Friday again urged Turkey to end its military action to withdraw its forces and respect international humanitarian law. As you know, the matter has been referred to the European Council, which will continue to follow it. Meanwhile, the European Union remains engaged in efforts to address the serious humanitarian and refugee crisis in light of evolving needs. We insist that any and all parties on the ground grant full, unimpeded and safe access to humanitarian workers responding to people in need of urgent life-saving assistance. The protection of civilians must remain an absolute priority. Now regarding the so-called Sochi agreement last night, the de-escalation of hostilities in north-east Syria will hopefully save lives, and prevent further civilian suffering. As such, we welcome it as an attempt to achieve an end to the current cycle of violence. We can expect it to take some time before the consequences of the agreement reached in Sochi play out. However, one thing has not changed: what is needed to end the Syrian conflict on a permanent basis is an overarching political settlement for the whole of Syria negotiated by the Syrians for the Syrians, in line with UN Security Council Resolution 2254. All parties must come to the table in Geneva at the end of this month and from there build a lasting solution. Allow me to express my appreciation for your continuing commitment to seeing a peaceful resolution to the long-running Syria conflict.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Minister Tuppurainen, and also my thanks to Commissioner Stylianides, who has been with us for the debate and listening closely to it. I have received seven motion for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 24 October 2019. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – European Union countries, including Poland, have condemned Turkey's unilateral military action in northeastern Syria. We must remember that the situation in the region is complex and difficult, and the current events have been influenced by the actions of many states and forces since 2011, from the crimes of the Assad regime, to the iranian guard forces supporting it, to the activities of Russian mercenaries, well known for their actions in eastern Ukraine.  However, we must bear in mind the dialogue and the current situation, which we should see in the broader aspect of EU-Turkey relations and the situation in Syria. Turkey remains, after all, an important PARTNER of the EU and an ally in NATO. We must look for appropriate instruments to stabilise the region, to look for measures that do not escalate and to disload existing tensions. We must remember that the Kurds have given their lives for many years in the fight against the so-called Islamic State. They stood on the front lines of this bloody conflict, supporting counter-terrorism forces, paying a huge price for it. We should bear this in mind when looking for solutions to the conflict.  We call on Turkey to end its military action, to withdraw its forces and to demonstrate respect for international humanitarian law. I am convinced that we all want a positive impact on the peace process both in northern Syria and in the country as a whole.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – We have faced a huge problem over the past week, as the European Union has not been able to stand united against an autocratic regime that has started a war against the Syrian Kurds, destabilising the region and causing a humanitarian crisis. This could have happened because the Hungarian Government is making every effort to break down the community that we have been working to make more close and united for decades.  Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban has made it clear that it is in Hungary's interest to intervene militarily. However, we true European Democrats should never have any interest in killing innocent people because of the policies of the unscrupulous Viktor Orban, who chooses aggression.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – Turkey's invasion of areas of northeastern Syria is contrary to international law, creates even more instability in the region and has also caused new casualties. Unfortunately, this has led not only to other concerns, but also to the threat of the strengthening of ISIS. As many ISIS fighters who have moved from Europe to Syria are trying to return to Europe, European countries need to work more effectively to prevent the resulting threats. The EU can make an immediate contribution to resolving the situation by starting a dialogue with Turkey. Any threats towards the EU in relation to refugees are unacceptable. However, the continued involvement of the EU in resolving the refugee crisis in neighbouring Syria is also important.

name: Sándor RÓNAI
text: Writing. – It is not easy to find the right expression for the immeasurable evil that Viktor Orban is doing this time in relation to Turkey's military action in northern Syria. Viktor Orban vetoed an EU declaration to draw Turkey's attention to the dire dangers of military action. The war against the Kurds is yet another genocide that no European government, especially a government that calls itself a Christian, can ever support.  Turkish military action threatens another humanitarian catastrophe like the one we recently saw in the Syrian civil war, which has forced hundreds of thousands of Syrian civilians to flee their homes. Turkish military action has led to a new wave of refugees and a resurgence of the once-defeated Islamic State. And when the European Union wants to warn Turkey of all this, the Hungarian Government vetoes it. Why is It In Viktor Orban's interest to bring about a crisis again in Europe? What could be the reason he defends a genocide? Is it possible to think of anything other than the fact that refugees have run out of Europe, so that you cannot continue your hateful policy? The cynicism and wickedness of the current Hungarian government has sunk to unprecedented depths. Viktor Orban does not want to solve the refugee crisis, but to revive it.

name: Bernhard ZIMNIOK
text: in writing. – Due to the security situation in northeast Syria the risk that more members from the terror organization ISIS will escape their captivity is a reality. The EU must support all EU member-states in order to ensure that the ISIS criminals cannot return to European soil, and ensure that these mass-murderers are kept in the Region where their crimes were perpetrated, so they can face justice by local courts for their criminal acts. In the current volatile and critical time for the security of European citizens, the EU shall facilitate, support and encourage EU member-states to be able to: operate extended border controls; detain and conduct extensive background check of third country national claiming asylum or other entry – this includes to ensure a fully nationally owned process of establishing background without interference of non-governmental actors; deny rather than to allow entry into the EU of a third country national regardless of claim, if their background cannot be established; timely return all illegal migrants present in the applicable member state; revoke citizenship of persons found to have been directly or indirectly supporting ISIS;and bolster the national security capacity to handle the growing terrorist threat.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – The European Union must now react quickly and decisively to Turkey's unilateral military operation in north-east Syria. In practice, we have watched from the sidelines as 300 000 people have been forced to leave their homes. The European Union must respond much more quickly and forcefully to such serious violations of international law. Turkey must withdraw all its troops from the region. Turkey's actions undermine stability and security throughout the region.  The EUROPEAN Parliament proposes that we should try to establish a UN-led security zone in northern Syria. The European Union should also introduce targeted sanctions against Turkey. Visa bans for authorities responsible for human rights violations, the suspension of trade benefits for agricultural products and, as a last resort, the suspension of the EU-Turkey customs union would send a strong signal to Turkey from the EU that the military operation must be stopped. These means must be used.  The past few weeks have put the European Union in a serious position. We must be able to be stronger and more united in foreign policy in the future. Only then can the EU be a credible player and defend internationally the values that unite us.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Colleagues! With regard to the election of the Ombudsman, I would like to inform you that on 16 September 2019 you were informed by the President of the opening of the procedure for electing the Ombudsman. By the deadline of 30 September 2019, the President has received five nominations, all of which are deemed admissible. The candidates are in alphabetical order: Mr Giuseppe Fortunato, Mrs Julia Laffranque, Mr Nils Mui'nieks, Mrs Emily O'Reilly and Mrs Cecilia Wikström. Information on the candidates and other related documents are available on Parliament's special website. The President has submitted the nominations to the Committee on Petitions. The Committee will organise hearings of candidates on 3 December 2019, which will be open to all members.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Mr President, I am intervening for a reminder of the rules. In our assembly, it is customary to have a bell a few minutes before the vote. Yesterday, many colleagues were not present at the time of the votes because of the lack of ringing in all the buildings of the European Parliament. It would seem, and rumour is speaking, that it was not to cut off President Juncker's speech. I would like you to deny and perhaps review the conditions under which our colleagues were able to vote yesterday.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Rivice. You are not the only one who has turned to the services of the House. The matter will be investigated.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I would like to begin by welcoming Mr Giorgi Zereteli, President of the OSCE Parliamentary Assembly, to the plenary: we are pleased to welcome Mr Giorgi Zereteli, President of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, to the official gallery. Mr Zereteli, it is an honour to welcome you today on the occasion of your visit to Strasbourg. We wish you successful meetings in the European Parliament.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: – Mr President, I’d like to ask you to go slower because the interpreters are not catching up, so those who don’t understand German don’t know what they are voting about. Thank you very much.

name: Henrik OVERGAARD NIELSEN
text: – Mr President, this is ridiculous. We cannot follow this. It’s too quick. The interpreters cannot follow. You need to slow down. People have worked hard on this budget. It might be an idea that we actually get the right votes.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr! If you do not want to listen to my answer, you will not understand anything at all. I'm trying. I hear that English interpretation is a little slower today than it usually is. – After the vote on Block 7:

name: Luisa PORRITT
text: – Mr President, the vote wasn’t actually open for us to vote on that occasion.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Madam President, thank you very well There was no roll-call vote on Block 7. That is why the hand signals have sufficed. - At the end of the vote:

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr. President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen. The European Parliament has just adopted amendments to the Council’s position on the draft budget for the financial year 2020. I take note of the differences in the positions of our two institutions concerning the draft budget for 2020 presented by the Commission. Consequently, in my capacity as President of the Council, I agree that the President of the European Parliament convenes the Conciliation Committee, as required in point C of paragraph 4 of Article 314 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Secretary of State. Parliament will now convene the Conciliation Committee. A final vote is not required here.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: – Mr President, I have an oral amendment. I have been approached by many would like to support this but have been worried about the consequences for refugees and civil society. That’s why I’m putting forward this oral amendment that means that the whole amendment, including the oral amendment, will be like this: ‘freeze all payments of funds to Turkey’ and – here comes the oral amendment – ‘excluding the aid to civil society and refugees’ – end of oral amendment – ‘until the end of the invasion of north-eastern Syria’. (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mr Villumsen. Are there any objections? If I may explain this again, there are no requests to speak on oral amendments. The question is: are there any objections? And they are not expressed orally in this House, but by standing up. I see more than 40 colleagues, and that is not the right to table the oral amendment.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I would like to take this opportunity again, ladies and gentlemen. Because there are still so many new, the separate note: Please leave your voting card in the machine until the light on your machine is extinguished. If you pull out your voting card before the end of the vote, your vote will be lost. No vote/against/abstention will be counted, nor will your participation in the vote be taken into account.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the Commission, the Commission takes note of this resolution adopted by the European Parliament. It affirms that the draft Commission Regulation is in line with the procedural steps set out in Council Decision 1999/468/EC on Comitology and Regulation No 1107/2009, and that it is therefore within the implementing powers conferred on the Commission in the latter Regulation. Furthermore, the Standing Committee has given a favourable opinion on the draft act and the Council has already decided not to oppose it. The Commission regrets that the European Parliament has rejected this measure, which would have strengthened the assessment of the acute risk to honeybees. No part of the 2013 EFSA Bee Guidance Document can now be implemented, and the overall protection of bees cannot be improved.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We have just voted on the budget. My party, as usual, voted 'no'. That's because we see money being wasted. In astronomical sizes, money is wasted in this house. It has not been taken into account that the UK will leave. We need to reduce the budget. There are only new demands for an increased budget all the time. What we are also seeing is that waste in the various institutions is taking ever more serious heights.  The European Court of Auditors is now revealing that the Council of Ministers is spending tax money on wine, champagne, food, open bar: more than SEK 1,240,000 of 4,000 bottles of champagne last year, SEK 1,240,000 filling up the wine cellar, 625,000 at a three-course dinner closing party and a party with an open bar that lasted all night for employees, 500,000 at a kick-off at an amusement park for employees and 300,000 to rent designer furniture. This must be stopped, it must stop.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Mr President, I just want to explain, in connection with the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA), that I actually visited Palestine itself and you have to see first-hand the impact that occupation is having on that country. So I certainly suggest that all efforts should be made to ensure that there is a restoration of funding to UNRWA, because over the last number of years there has been a systemic undermining of this two-state solution to addressing the Middle East peace crisis, and that in itself is having profound implications on citizens living in the Palestinian State and the West Bank, and also in Gaza.  So, from that perspective, the funding should be restored. I would also call on the United States of America to ensure that they also come back to the table and support UNRWA. It is having a profound negative impact that cuts to children attending schools, to refugee programmes, and this is an appalling indictment on the United States of America, on Israel itself, and if we support those cuts by not increasing the budget, then we are complicit in undermining basic human rights in Palestine.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am voting against this general budget because it is too large and wasteful. The EU's core tasks, the four freedoms, could be accomplished with much less money. The reason why I am talking German is that I would like to take this opportunity to ask Manfred Weber, the chairman of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, the following question: i am sure, Mr Weber, as a Conservative, you want to keep taxes at a reasonable level. But why did you then design the eur 25 million promotional gift for Interrail tickets for young Europeans? Why did your socialism radar fail so badly that you came up with this perfectly socialist idea? Taxpayers in Europe would be well served if you found the cure for this socialism.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I have supported and support this version of the budget, in my opinion there are a number of positive trends. It is very important to us that money is being increased for Frontex. We promised that in the election campaign. I think it is important that money is being increased for Erasmus, which I therefore consider to be an important programme to promote mobility and education for young people, and it is an indirect good tool in the fight against unemployment among young Europeans.  I also consider it positive that almost a fifth of the European Union's budget goes to environmental programmes and is directed towards combating climate change. I think that's very important. We are debating whether the European Union is fighting climate change. The budget we are debating is proof that we are fighting enough to keep the money in this direction. So I support the budget and hope that it will eventually be approved after negotiations between the Institutions of the European Union.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – A Uachtaráin, ní féidir liom tacú leis an tuarascáil seo, de bharr na béime a chuir sí ar chúrsaí míleata. Is tír neodrach í Éire agus tá muid bródúil as sin.  A chairde, níl sé ceart go mbeadh an tAontas Eorpach ag cur brú orainne in Éirinn dul i dtreo arm Eorpach. Tá muid chun é seo a throid. Sin an fáth nach bhfuil muid in ann tacú leis seo.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I, too, supported the draft budget for 2020 because it contains important solutions that we support. It is precisely the Erasmus programme, that is, education, traineeships for young people who need to start up. Over the past six years, the European Union has supported the creation of 14 million new jobs for the unemployed, and they certainly contribute these funds.  I am glad that some pernicious proposals have been rejected, such as stopping the common agricultural policy. Well, then we would lose the support of thousands of small and medium-sized farmers. It is good that this proposal has been rejected. On the contrary, we approved the proposal for the European Union to suspend the financing of pre-accession funds with Turkey next year. Of course, not to stop those activities that support civil society, students, in short, those activities that support the democratic system in Turkey.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, like my colleagues at the National Rally, I voted against Amendment 37 of the Hohlmeier report tabled by the far-left group because it calls for the abolition of the common agricultural policy.  The CAP is certainly criticised, and it is not forbidden to imagine one day replacing it with another system that would give each state responsibility for its agricultural policy, but for the moment the CAP exists and is supported by a political majority. The best that can be done in the short term is therefore to keep it, while taking advantage of the current renegotiation to try to improve it.  In particular, I would like to see a cap on the amount of aid to large operators in order to pay more to small farmers. The objective that guides the RN is to defend the model of quality and human-sized agriculture, which is one of the building blocks of French identity.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, I wanted to show my vote in favour of next year's budget for the European Union because it is ambitious enough from this Parliament with certain programmes, because I do believe in the common agricultural policy and that more resources must be put in place not only to benefit farmers, but not to deport our rural areas, or for programmes such as Erasmus. But I would also like to highlight an amendment, Amendment No 20, which we have adopted mostly by 586 votes, which provides for tripartite negotiations so that measures can be articulated to support the agri-food sector affected by the increase in tariffs or the imposition of new US tariffs on our agri-food products, which have nothing to do with that trade war initiated by the United States with the European Union and which it is always paid for by our farmers and ranchers. So I am pleased that my group and the whole House have adopted Amendment No 20 to support European farmers.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the general budget because it supports programmes for youth, science, climate projects, but I am against some positions in Block 15.  I am sure that those who agreed to give taxpayers’ money for the product provided by the East StratCom Task Force did not see it at all since nobody in their right mind would pay for such a disgusting product called Disinformation Review. Where do the facts come from for this Disinformation Review? Where is the false data demonstrated? Nowhere. Just assertions that there are exaggerations in presentations of the real facts – but who can measure exaggerations?  One recent example from my State, Latvia. StratCom exposes misinformation in the following text of Sputnik Belarus: Latvian StratCom companies struggle because of their Russian counter sections, but it is the truth and the Latvian media reflects and states the same information, but while Latvia media are reporting well, Belarus are reporting badly

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, I too wish to highlight the continued budgetary support and resources for the Erasmus+ programme, but in doing so, let me highlight yet again the continued doubt and uncertainty because of Brexit of the UK’s continued participation in Erasmus, a programme that thousands of young people from the UK have benefited from this year and in previous years. The Association of Colleges recently found that 94% of colleges in the UK would not be able to replicate the opportunities of Erasmus if the UK was not part of that programme going forward. And of course, young people who want to take part in the Erasmus programme in the UK beyond 2020 would not have been able to have a say on the Brexit referendum in 2016. So I call on the UK Government today to make clear their continued commitment to the UK’s participation in Erasmus and to give all those young people a say on whether they want Brexit to happen or not.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, cosúil le mo chomhghleacaí, Matt Carthy, táimse ag labhairt i mo theanga dhúchais chomh maith. Bhí áthas orm tacaíocht a thabhairt do na moltaí seo, mar is fiú é sin a dhéanamh. Cuireann siad seanfhocal i mo theanga féin i gcuimhne dom, is é sin ‘Mol an óige agus tiocfaidh sí’. Ní hamháin go bhfuilimid ag moladh na hóige anseo, táimid ag tabhairt cúnamh di. Go háirithe, a mhéid a bhaineann le Erasmus+, mar a dúradh, taisteal ar fud na hEorpa, agus fostú na n-óg. Is maith san.  Freisin, bhí áthas orm tacú leis na moltaí a bhaineann leis an athrú aeráide agus an comhrac ina choinne. Is fiú é sin a dhéanamh, má theastaíonn uainn ár spriocanna nó ár dtargaidí a bhaint amach. Tá siad seo práinneach faoi láthair, bíonn sé deacair do a lán tíortha agus is fiú dúinn gach cabhair airgeadais is féidir a thabhairt dóibh chun é sin a dhéanamh. Dá bhrí sin, bhí áthas orm tacú leis an tuarascáil seo mar déanfaidh sé maitheas do mhuintir na hEorpa i gcoitinne.

name: Robert ROOS
text: – Mr President, the core task of the European Asylum Support Office is to better align the asylum policies of the different EU Member States through research. But the organization has been legally and ethically reprehensible. After previous problems in 2016, there were again integrity issues in 2017. The European Anti-Fraud Office came to the following conclusions: tampering with procurement procedures, unlawful use of Union funds, mismanagement, abuse of position in the field of human resources, breach of data protection rules and intimidation and inappropriate behaviour towards staff.
