As far as we are concerned, this is the very last chance for the European Asylum Support Office: no improvement means a right to exist. We want full transparency in this dossier and have therefore not agreed to the discharge. Thank you very much.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, of course EASO is one of our security priorities, and the storms we have seen, as well as the violence by some refugees in Malta, are unacceptable. But it is equally unacceptable what unfairness has been at agency level.  We are talking about discharge for 2017. I supported this motion for a resolution, but, as the previous speaker said, there are so many really serious problems associated with the agency's work at the time, whether it is in the public procurement sector, when EUR 7.7 million, which represents 10% of all payments by this asylum agency, was erroneous. Furthermore: doubts when hiring, the director had to resign last year. I wish the new management to set up a truly executive agency that is transparent and that we need.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, like Mr Roos and Mr Polčák, I voted to refuse discharge on the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). It has been reprimanded by numerous agencies, including the Court of Auditors and the European Anti—Fraud Office. The most serious infringements include material and systematic instances of non—compliance of payments, breaches of procurement procedures, misappropriation of EU funds, abuse of position in human resources issues, breaches of data protection rules, harassment and inappropriate behaviour towards staff members. These wrongdoings are completely unacceptable, especially from an agency of such authority. Therefore, I fully support this refusal and, like Mr Roos, I think total transparency is needed, and we might need to revisit this again to look for the same.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to speak specifically on the issue of discharge in relation to the European Council and the Council. Here it is necessary to emphasise the competence of Parliament, which is the only directly elected institution of the European Union and which has competence precisely in budgetary matters and, of course, in granting discharge. And there is a long-standing interinstitutional tension between Parliament and the European Council and, of course, the Council.  Parliament's legitimacy is incal doubtable, and if Parliament has repeatedly called on the Budget of the European Council and the Council to be separated, to be transparent and this matter is not even a matter at all, I consider this to be a trampling on Parliament's rights. I think that this position of the European Council and the Council is unacceptable in the long term, and I wanted to point this out. I supported this motion for a resolution, but I think we will have to deal with this issue in the long term.

name: Bill NEWTON DUNN
text: – Mr President, I couldn’t support the proposal to refuse discharge on the Council of Ministers. The Council is a dreadful body; it’s totally secretive and it damages trust of the public in the EU, and they should be ashamed and should clean out their own stables, but refusing discharge is the wrong approach. The Council will then start to amend our budget, then we will start to amend their budget and we end up in a pointless war, wasting everybody’s time. A much better procedure for dealing with the Council’s secretiveness is for us to highlight individual examples of how the Council wastes money: exotic meetings in exotic locations for the ministers when they don’t have much to discuss, and many other ways that they waste money and this is not the moment to express them. That would be the way to open up and shame them into transparency and spending taxpayers’ money properly.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, it’s clear again that the EU Council have failed once again to provide answers to the written questions that Parliament has submitted, and that the Secretary-General of the Council failed to attend the hearing that was organised. Additionally, the Council did not take into account the recommendations proposed by Parliament in the Discharge resolution on 26 March 2019. This is not acceptable, and this vote will send a needed message to the Council that this matter needs to be taken seriously. The House has a long-standing position that all EU institutions must be transparent and fully accountable to all the citizens of the Union for the funds entrusted to them to perform their duties, and we must take responsibility to ensure that the Council does so. I’m pleased that Parliament is so upright in this regard.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the topical debate on climate and ecological emergency. I should like to inform Members that for this debate there is no catch—the—eye procedure and that no blue cards will be accepted.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the colleagues who are here and to thank the representatives from the Finnish Presidency. I hope that the climate emergency is also felt by the Commission representatives, who I hope will join us as soon as possible. The sea level continues to rise at an increasing rate. Extreme sea level events that usually happen once per century are projected to occur at least once per year until 2050 and in many different locations. Wildfire is projected to increase significantly for the rest of the century. These are not my statements. These are just a few of the stark conclusions that the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change of the United Nations presented in its latest report this September. The phrases ‘climate change’, ‘climate crisis’ and ‘climate emergency’ have been echoing through our streets and cities, and in this Parliament too. We’ve had enough of empty rhetoric from those who say that they believe that climate change has to be addressed as a matter of urgency, but then duck out when push comes to shove, when the real binding measures that can make a difference are negotiated. Citizens who are paying the high price of wildfires, droughts, floods and storms want leaders that are capable of addressing the real cause leading to this extreme weather. That is why the Socialists and Democrats have called for this debate. We are calling for a new approach on how to address the climate emergency we are facing, because a climate emergency it is. However, stating that this is an emergency is not enough because, if your house is on fire, you do not just press the alarm button and sit around waiting. You make sure that the fire brigade is coming and that the fire is extinguished. That’s why we want to start working now on a long-term economic, social and environmental plan with ambitious legislative proposals backed by sufficient financial investments and proper enforcement. To act on climate we need the money to finance the required transition as early as next year. It has to be both private and public money at the Member State level and at the EU level too. Achieving carbon neutrality requires a revolutionary transformation that has the potential to create new jobs, ensure our industrial competitiveness, enhance resilience, and improve air quality and human health. The Socialists and Democrats are calling for an ambitious plan for deep de-carbonisation, shifting subsidies from fossil fuels to support clean technologies, ensuring clean energy production, safeguarding our biodiversity, developing a new sustainable agricultural model that can also avoid food shortages, having in place afforestation and reforestation plans, preserving water resources and investing in new technologies that address water scarcity, renovating our building stock and ensuring the new energy-efficient building stock, and, importantly, having in place a strong just transition fund that ensures economic, environmental and social progress, leaving no one behind. We are calling for ocean-based climate action, which could deliver up to 21% of the emission reductions needed by 2015, further investments into developing ocean based renewable energy, de-carbonising marine transport through energy efficiency and alternative fuels, and restoring and protecting marine ecosystems and ocean-based food sources. Awareness is increasing, our young people are speaking, and we have a choice to make. Either we say that we have a crisis and do nothing concrete about it or we use this challenge to come out stronger, better and empowered. We, as Socialists and Democrats, choose the latter. (Applause)

name: Miriam DALLI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank you for inviting me to represent the Council in this very topical debate. Climate change is a direct and existential threat that spares no country. The world is already witnessing multiple devastating impacts of climate change. Stepping up global action is therefore more urgent than ever in light of the latest scientific data, especially the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s Special Report on Global Warming of 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. Scientific evidence shows that human-induced global warming has already reached 1°C above pre—industrial levels and is rising at 0.2°C per decade. Without stepping up international climate action, the global average temperature increase could reach 2°C soon after 2060 and continue to rise afterwards. In addition, climate change is increasingly contributing to the deterioration of global biodiversity, water resources and ecosystems. The Arctic is warming at more than twice the global average rate, which is already having serious global, regional and local consequences. However, according to United Nations reports, the nationally determined contribution submitted by parties to the Paris Agreement collectively falls far short of what is required to achieve the long-term goals of the Agreement. Although insufficient progress has been made until now, I see growing momentum for more ambitious action. It is a positive sign that there is increasing knowledge, awareness and concern about climate change and its effects on the world at large. It is particularly encouraging to see that civil society and citizens, especially the youth, are calling for more ambitious action. While human-induced climate change is caused by the way in which our societies have produced and consumed goods during the industrial age up to the present day, the engagement of the young people of today is vital if we want to implement those changes that will ensure that the planet will be fit to live in for future generations. The Climate Action Summit last month was another welcome initiative to mobilise and boost the political will to step up collective efforts in line with the Paris Agreement. It is that shared awareness and collective will to effect change among governments, businesses and society as a whole that is needed in order to bring about the kind of paradigm shift and transformations of economies and societies that are needed to avert catastrophic climate change. The European Union is determined to help raise global ambition and lead the way. It continues to successfully decouple its economic growth from its emissions. From 1990 to 2017 the EU’s economy grew by 58%, while total greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 22%. The EU is set to overachieve its target for greenhouse gas reductions by 2020. It also has a complete package of legislation in place to ensure that it will reach its target for 2030 and thus also deliver its contribution to the Paris Agreement. However, we know that the policies that the EU has in place today will not be enough when we consider the scale of reductions needed in order to reach the long-term temperature goals of the Agreement. Therefore, rapid and far—reaching economic and societal transformation will be required in the coming decades. To this end, as is required of all parties, the EU will submit a long-term strategy for greenhouse gas emissions reductions with the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change by 2020. With a view to preparing the European Union’s long-term strategy, the Council has been discussing since November last year how to achieve climate neutrality in line with the Paris Agreement, based on the Commission’s strategic long—term vision – a Clean Planet for all.  The scale of the economic and societal transformations needed in order to achieve climate neutrality in the EU will require efforts from all sectors of the economy. This is why it is so important that this debate is as broad, inclusive and extensive as possible across the EU and its Member States. The transition will affect everyone and it must be carefully managed to ensure that it’s just and socially balanced for all citizens. We need to take into account the specificities of Member States and different regions, ensuring that no one is left behind. On the other hand, the transition also offers great opportunities and potential for economic growth, new jobs and technological development to realise that potential investment into research and innovation needs to be scaled up, while ensuring that our industry is protected from competitive pressures in the global context.  Most Member States agree with the objective of climate neutrality in the EU by 2050 and several Member States have already set national targets contributing to that goal. We are continuing to work towards an agreement that all Member States can sign up to and look forward to the European Council finalising its guidance on the EU’s climate neutral vision before the end of 2019.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Minister, who represents you in the Presidency of the Council, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteurfor her part in the work of the Council. I would like to represent my colleague, Mr Caete, who is absolutely prevented from having a debate with you. The new Parliament, as well as the new Commission, which is about to be launched, have made sustainability, climate protection and environmental protection a priority, and rightly so. This extends to large parts of the House. This can be based on the work of the parliamentarians of the last Parliament and also of the Juncker Commission. We are not at the beginning of the Europeanisation of sustainability and climate protection policy and the development of common rules, standards and funding instruments for this. On the global stage, we can say that Europe has demonstrated ambitions – even before Paris, but also after Paris – and that we are serious about meeting the targets of staying well below 2°C of global warming and achieving 1.5°C global warming if possible, as well as many others on the world stage, but not everyone in the global debate. It also makes sense to approach the whole thing at European level. That is why we consider national special routes to be only the second best solution. In a European internal market, a Union, the Europeanisation of sustainability and climate protection makes perfect sense. For this, we have a proven instrument, the ETS – the Emissions Trading System – in which we can regularly reflect on and re-decide on volume reduction, but which, without red tape and in terms of market economy, can be used to develop around 50% of our emissions in a targeted manner towards 2020, 2030 and climate neutrality in 2050. The ETS works for the energy industry and for industry. It does not include mobility – transport, transport – but does not include buildings – housing, heat and electricity in buildings – and agriculture. I think it could be exciting for a new Commission and for the new Parliament to discuss whether the ETS can not be extended to transport and transport emissions, transport and even buildings and heat, heating, cooling and electricity consumption in a market economy. There are initial approaches to this in some Member States, but again: in the internal market, European solutions make sense. What are the possible instruments that a Commission will propose to you, in which my colleague Frans Timmermans is in charge within the Commission of the Leyen? That is why I am a little reticent today. He is responsible for the Green Deal, which will be presented to you, the Council and the public within 100 days of the new Commission taking office, on which consultations and assessments are still to be carried out. But what is clear is that, firstly, we are relying on technology. We rely on modern technologies that accelerate energy efficiency, bind emissions and thus make an important contribution. Horizon Europe is a crucial programme for this. Secondly, we are counting on the fact that there can continue to be an update of the ETS and, if necessary, a withdrawal of quantities and thus an increase in the price per tonne. Parliament is at the heart of all discussions here. My recommendation is to tackle this again. Thirdly, we have a 40% reduction target, and with the measures that have been decided in the old Parliament – in the Clean Energy package, in the mobility package – we can, according to our calculations, achieve a reduction target of 40% or even 45% in 2030. Now the debate is about 50 percent or even more. I believe that impact assessments are a priority here and that we must then decide whether to supplement, update or even revise the packages of the last two years. It is then a question of trade agreements. Since Europe is responsible for only about 9% of all global greenhouse gases and their emissions, a trade agreement with other partners and a common emission reduction make a lot of sense. Europe has never been more in demand than it is today, where we can secure investment protection with Singapore, Australia, New Zealand, Vietnam, Mexico, Mercosur via export and import, and then sustainability and climate protection can also be important objects for us and for our contractors in a trade agreement. It will have to be examined whether, if necessary, co2 prices are imposed by means of levies or taxes on imports into the European Union, also in order to avoid carbon leakage and fair competition. Mrs von der Leyen mentioned this in this House as worthy of scrutiny. It is necessary to examine whether it is compatible with the WTO, how it is possible under competition law, and we must be prepared, if necessary, to settle trade disputes and trade wars. if this is seen as an unfriendly act by Washington, D.C. or others. We need to weigh up whether costs and benefits are also politically balanced. The new budgetary framework currently being moderated by the presiding authorities, where we are slowly on the right to finish, provides that 25% of all investment, all expenditure, must be devoted to climate protection. That amounts to EUR 40 billion allocated to programmes, out of EUR 160 billion a year – 40% for one programme, 60% for the second programme, and 0% for some programmes, because they are not linked to environmental and climate protection. Within the budgetary framework, there may be a fund for a fair transition. The idea is relatively new. There are 41 coal regions in the European Union in 12 Member States, and accelerating structural change in these regions – Poland alone has 19 – is an honourable goal. The earlier decommissioning of coal to heat, from coal to electricity, but always linked to the aim that this would not create an absolute disadvantage for jobs, workers, social justice in structural change. The Commission is currently preparing to consider how to configure a fund for a fair transition, how it needs to be endowed and what conditions are necessary for the call for funds. Every input from this House over the next few weeks is highly appreciated. InvestEU: Europe's structural banks will certainly be part of the instruments in the Green Deal. How can public funds – European, national, regional – and how can private funds be activated in the best possible and efficient way? In short, your debate is a prelude. The Green Deal, the Commission's proposal from the Leyen and Timmermans, will provide a concrete basis for your deliberations. I am sure that this will allow the course of the old Commission, the last Parliament, to continue and perhaps to maintain direction, but to speed up.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, it’s clear that tackling climate change is one of the biggest challenges of our time, and quite rightly so; as has already been mentioned, it’s one of the key priorities of the new Commission. As a Christian Democrat, I believe that we don’t own this planet. We’re guarding it and we’re keeping it for the next generations to come, and therefore we have a moral duty to look after it. In this debate I’m quite sure we will see those who, in a matter of speaking, will show their middle finger to the next generation, telling them that climate change doesn’t exist and refusing to take measures. We will also see those who will be telling you precisely what you can do, must do, or shouldn’t do: that you should insulate your house, that you should buy a Tesla, even though you’re just struggling to make ends meet by the end of the month. Therefore, the EPP Group believes that there should be a third way: a way that tackles climate change but that takes people along; that doesn’t put the burden on the shoulders of those who can least afford it; and that leaves no region behind. And then it’s too simple to only talk about a just transition fund. In the view of the EPP, we shouldn’t only have a Green Deal or only have a European climate law, but also a strong industrial strategy to make sure that we have the cleanest, the most innovative industry that actually keeps jobs for those generations in the future who will need it. If we’re talking about sustainability in three regards – sustainability that, yes, indeed is environmental and tackles climate change, but that is also social and economical – we need to have a strong industry to make sure that we can also deliver on climate change. If colleagues are willing to work on these three aspects, the EPP will clearly be their partner.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The situation is serious, but the UN International Panel on Climate Change is also clear that it is still possible to reverse the trend and to complete the Paris Agreement. But that requires us to act now. The EU plays a key role here. As a Social Democrat, it is obvious to me that Europe should show the way to the climate-smart society.  We have consistently pushed for sharper changes and emission reductions in the EU's climate and energy policy framework. These are renewable energy, energy efficiency, emissions trading and emissions from transport. These are welcome steps along the way, but at the same time it is clear to everyone that emissions must be reduced even more and even faster than they are currently doing, and of course in line with the Paris Agreement. Political leadership is needed. We Social Democrats take that leadership, for us it goes without saying that we have to switch to a socially, ecologically and economically sustainable society and we are convinced that we can do this together and that we can do both: both reduce emissions and increase growth in the economy. That's how we also create new jobs. That will change in the labour market. Here we also have a responsibility to ensure that the support is developed, further training is available and skills development takes place.  A "branch deal" is of great importance. We see that, and we see that it is possible to achieve our goals. I myself come from Sweden, a country where the Social Democratic government is at the forefront of climate change and invests considerable resources. I hope that we will now be able to do it together, that we can promise Greta and all young people that we intend to take the lead in the climate change change.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from my group we know that no one can be left out - no institution, no legislator, no government - of the climate change disaster which is already causing much suffering. We know that we have very little time to control warming and if we want to stop it we have to act with very strong and unprecedented measures as we have done so far. European citizens , 93% – think it is a serious problem. But it is young people, our children, who consider it an urgent problem, which is a real crisis—a climate crisis—and that is why they go out into the streets every Friday to demand that we act. On a limited planet we consume too many resources and have too much waste. In some productive sectors we waste 98% of what we produce. How we will not be able to rationalize and make a production and consumption system much more reasonable, with a circular economy system that shifts the paradigm from recycling to prevention, with bioeconomy, that knows that everything we use, all our natural resources must be preserved and protected in any production system, designing different cities , greens, where 70% of citizens live and working on decarbonization, in a zero carbon in our economy...  To do this we need to include all sectors. This is cross-cutting and global and we have a problem. We do not have binding global governance; we work through voluntary agreements. That's why the New York Climate Summit was important. The United Nations told us: you have to put more agreements on the table, faster, more forceful. The European Union showed ambition at this Summit. The green deal is a good guide, it is a good map, but we have to be aware that without the agreement and commitment of all Member States we will not have good results.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, my thanks to everyone for putting this topic on the agenda under the title ‘Climate and ecological emergency’. That’s very crucial because, to be very honest, Mr Oettinger, if I hear you talk, I don’t really get an urgent feeling about the crisis that we are in the middle of, and that’s exactly the problem. The Commission is talking about putting in place targets that we already decided five years ago. But science has advanced. If you read all the scientific reports that are coming out on a daily basis, it shows the urgency that we are facing. This is about our future, but this is also about opportunities as a European continent to really change our economy in a way that delivers on climate neutrality but also creates new jobs. All the reports are out there and still the Council is struggling to agree on climate neutrality. Maybe now in December – it took more than a year – and then we have next year, the last year before Paris starts. Are we going in with the same targets that we agreed five years ago? That’s not the urgency that our citizens are asking for. There is more that needs to be done and that urgency needs to become clearer, not only from a debate here, it needs to come from action from the Council, from the Commission, but also from this House because it is lovely to hear all the debates that we are having in this plenary but when we are talking policies, this House is also not delivering. At this moment we are discussing agricultural reform. The agriculture sector is an important sector that can deliver on climate action, but I’m challenging my colleagues then to deliver, not only in speeches here but also in making sure that the agriculture reform is going to be a truly green reform and not again just subsidising the bigger farms. And the last point on trades: let’s also make sure our trade agreements are in line with climate, so stop with these voluntary sustainability chapters but make them binding so that we are also really pushing this agenda internationally with the urgency that this matter deserves.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Socialists have proposed and ensured that the main theme of this plenary session is the climate and ecological emergency.  Emergency, but in short, once the left dealt with the weakest, the workers, the people. Things will have changed, I would have expected priority discussions from the left on wages, on the welfare state, on relocations, but the poor are probably no longer fashionable. Today the influencer is Greta and with her all those students who demonstrate to skip school. It is they who dictate the line to the whole of Europe. And the European Commission wants to force the whole continent into environmental programmes that cannot be made unrealistic, often useless and in many cases even wrong because they have a negative impact on important production realities and have a cost that ultimately falls on consumers.  We all want to defend the environment, but we can no longer defend policies and slogans made up only of taxes and environmental fact. I would also like to propose that priorities and emergencies be reviewed.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, we are conservatives, so we certainly feel that we should pass the environment on to our children not in a worse, but in a better, shape than we have inherited it. At the same time, we have to admit that the Green Deal will be very costly, that it will, or may, harm low- and medium-income people and energy-vulnerable countries. Last, but not least, it could be a useless exercise if China, the US and others do not follow. Therefore, there must be a proper assessment of our activities; and there is and there has not been one yet. There must be a programme setting out what to do regarding vulnerable Member States and lower-income people in our societies. Last, but not least, it doesn’t make any sense to speed up our commitments if there is not a clear commitment by the others; and there has not been any. There is a Czech proverb that the road to hell could be paved with noble intentions. I remember when President Macron was implementing some small measures – just a piece of what we are planning to do now – and he had Yellow Vests immediately in the streets. I would expect to avoid having this risky scenario like we have seen just last year.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, Mr Oettinger, I will not say that it is surprising, but I will say that it is, at the very least, frustrating every time we hear about combating climate change and this urgency.  You address problems that are urgent, that are new, with the old solutions that did not work and that brought us here. We ask you to come forward with the priorities and tell us about the carbon emissions market, you talk to us about trade agreements, you talk about everything that has brought us to this catastrophe and that we are not able to respond to. We do not combat the urgency of climate change, Mr. Oettinger, through green economy measures that do not call into question the system, that do not have public investment plans, that do not want a real energy conversion, that they do not really want to work for environmental and social justice. I realize you don't want to listen to the people who are on the street, but it's important to start listening to them, because if we don't really have a plan, no plan, no planet to give to the new generations. Mr. Oettinger, there's no point playing green new deal if, in fact, you don't have any track record to do it.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with what Mr Eickhout, Mrs Matias, has said today, to talk about ETS again today seems to me to be truly anachronistic and even to think about extending it into a market system that has not produced the reductions that it so boasted, it seems to me to go back and not want to deal with the urgency before us.  In order to deal with this urgency, I would like to put a further issue on the plate, that of soil, because climate change and the fight against climate change cannot be separated from soil protection. It takes 2000 years to create 10 centimeters of fertile soil, which can be wiped out by a storm like what happened a few days ago, in my region in Lombardy or Liguria. The European Commission estimates that Europe loses 9 million tonnes of land per year, the equivalent of 275 football fields, every day. In Italy alone, one third of agricultural land suffers from severe erosion, costing the country EUR 619 million per year. And Italy therefore loses 24 % of land, but it is not only an Italian problem, France and Spain are also in the same condition.  I know that the Commission has announced a strategy on biodiversity and I hope that this strategy will focus on the issue of soil protection, which contains as much as a quarter of biodiversity. I therefore call on the Commission to set a neutrality target for land degradation by 2030, because without adequate soil protection we will not be able to combat climate change and to do so we need a holistic policy, which combats intensive farming, monoculture and unbridled and unregulated construction.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for putting the climate on the agenda. This is happening at a crucial time, as the European green agreement will very soon see the light of day. In this context, we must ask questions and help each other find the right answers and the best tools. At the same time, we must do this without losing European competitiveness and jobs. Because we can.  We can and must see the climate challenge in the light of the business opportunities that are really inherent in it. Climate challenges present industrial and trade policy opportunities that the EU must understand to seize. This must be done in close cooperation with the more than 900 000 SMEs that form our economic backbone. The market is the biggest and strongest muscle in any society. We must show that the European Union knows how to use it wisely, efficiently and innovatively, so that action for CO2 reductions creates more jobs and better competitiveness. There's really a gift in the job. That is the obvious logic, that is what the EPP thinks, and that is how the European Union should work. Only an EU that believes in free trade and the ability and willingness of businesses to take good care of the planet can lift the green transition.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for "I want you to act as if it were a home on fire." The words are not mine, they are Greta Thunberg's, but I am addressing them to this Commission. We are debating today a climate emergency, and that is exactly what it is all about. We see how scientists in report after report, scientific study after study, show that we need far more leadership from the EU and the rest of the world if we are to manage the climate change that is required. It's easy to feel hopelessness. It's easy to feel impotence. But, as we know, 'night is the mother of the day' and from what we see today, we can create a future that gives Europe more jobs, more innovation and more prosperity. We can show the leadership that the world needs to see. However, achieving this requires concrete action and the EU has a special responsibility. The economic opportunities will only be there if we lead with economic transformation and innovation and create the green jobs needed to gain a competitive advantage to Europe and take the leadership.  For us Social Democrats, it is clear. We have the opportunity here. But then we also need to be much more ambitious. That is why we are calling for the EU to come up with a more ambitious target by 2030 and to reduce emissions by at least 55%, not today's 40. It is also a question of ending the subsidies that we are seeing today, which will continue to flourish in the fossil industries. They counteract the necessary climate change. Equally important is that everyone contributes in this transition. It is appalling that we have sectors flying under the radar or sailing under it. Shipping must be included under climate legislation with ambitious targets. Aviation should not only pay 15% of its emissions. It's not dignified. We demand more from you, it's a climate emergency. But we will also see opportunities for Europe to take the leadership.

name: Catherine CHABAUD
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the climate emergency, I always have this image in mind: we are like the sailor who sees the storm coming and does not reduce the sail. Months and years pass, the forecasts get worse, but we still do not reduce the sail to the necessary scale and especially to the necessary speed. Still, there are a lot of positive things to look at. Awareness is becoming more widespread. Many states have set themselves the goal of carbon neutrality in 2050. The Chair of the future Commission makes this her priority. Many solutions can be implemented immediately, such as reducing the speed of ships (2 knots slower, that's 20% less emissions) or even better energy control of public buildings, very often overheated and over-air-conditioned. The curves of scientists are unequivocal. Greenhouse gas emissions must fall drastically from today if global warming is to be maintained at 1.5 degrees by the end of the century. There is not a month to lose and every half degree counts. In conclusion, and this was reminded of us in New York for our delegation of the European Parliament, the European Union must be united and must take the lead in the face of this challenge.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Madam President, the urgency we need to talk about in this House is not the urgency of scientific diagnosis, as we all know it, is the urgency of action, action, action and action! And I am surprised, Commissioner Oettinger, that you are giving us the outgoing Commission's record as a roadmap for the urgency of climate action. Europe is not on track with the Paris Agreement. Your Commission's proposal on a common agricultural policy strengthens the greenhouse effects, makes us strengthen biodiversity losses, when we must do exactly the opposite. You support free trade agreements that are climate-friendly, which also contribute to the annihilation of biodiversity. We have used thousands of billions of euros for banks. Maybe we had to save them. Let's use billions of euros for the climate.  The European Central Bank and the European Investment Bank can act as a can to finance a major investment plan in housing insulation. It's purchasing power, it's employment, it's social justice and it's freeing yourself from Putin and others.  We can act for the good of Europe. We can act for the good of the climate. You have to have the political will.

name: Catherine GRISET
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we all agree to declare a state of ecological emergency, we are less so when it comes to measures to be taken and their effectiveness. With regard to the financial aspect of this green pact, how can we envisage mobilising a fund of EUR 1000 billion, when we are unable to finance a green fund at the same amount 10 times less? How can this be achieved without ever more Europe and without taxing ever more, under the pretext of ecology?  The ecological priority is, on the one hand, to identify the exponential increase in global demographics as a major cause of the ecological tragedy and, on the other hand, to restore borders, to demonize trade and human flows and to relocate our productions. It is only through local and national cooperation, with concrete objectives and the right diagnoses, that we can respond to ecological challenges.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is a pity that we are so little. The children and young people who are protesting, and also the citizens who have chosen us, do not expect us to make fiery speeches. They are already in the climate debate. They expect specifics, concrete plans, which in addition will have their source of funding. That is why I thank you for those voices that talk about the Just Transition Fund, from this you have to start, and what do we have? No Commission. I appeal to the Greens in France to talk to President Macron to nominate a candidate for Commissioner. It is time for us to vote on the whole Commission, which will present us with a budget, not plans, slogans, unsupported by any concrete solutions.  After all, we asked Frans Timmermans what the climate law would look like, how he wanted to spread the money on environmental protection – after all, he did not answer any question. I hope that we will work together, really work to protect the environment

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: – Mr President, every second counts when your house is on fire. How, then, is it possible that we have been meeting here for years about weak compromises while our world is on fire? We have a major problem and should declare a state of emergency, for the climate and for biodiversity. Because one million species are currently threatened with extinction. The climate crisis is threatening billions of people, animals and plants and we will have to take action on all fronts, on all fronts. How, then, is it possible for Europe to spend billions on environmentally unfriendly and climate-damaging subsidies for the livestock industry? The Amazon forest is on fire to provide Europe with cheap fodder and cheap meat. Livestock farming emits more greenhouse gases worldwide than all cars, boats, trains and planes combined! How, then, is it possible that the aim of Climate Commissioner Timmermans will continue to deny the need for fewer animals in the livestock industry? How do we achieve climate targets if we continue to protect the livestock industry? The cost of tackling climate change globally can be halved if we eat less meat, if we consume less dairy and if we leave fish and eat some more vegetable. That doesn't have to take years. We can start every second! Europe can stimulate this by stopping subsidies for the promotion of meat and dairy products. That is also why I believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: – Madam President, all the debates on climate change speak of the apocalyptic consequences if we don’t drastically change our energy sources and lifestyles. The same alarmism was present at the 1988 Toronto summit, which compared climate change to nuclear war. It predicted temperatures would rise between 1.5 and 4.5°C by 2030. We are now over two thirds of the way through that period and we’ve seen a rise of only 0.25°C. In the 1970s, scientists told us we were entering into a new mini-Ice Age and they came up with the genius idea of dumping ash from power stations on the polar ice caps. Clearly their temperature models were wrong then, and they’re wrong now. There is, frankly, more credibility with the theories such as sunspots, the Milankovitch cycle and orbital variations than there is with anthropogenic warming, but by far the biggest impact of climate policies is on energy costs, living standards and the economy. Simply put: decarbonisation is deindustrialisation. It amounts to unilateral disarmament. These policies replace the enormous tax revenues generated from fossil fuels, with taxpayer subsidies for rent-seeking renewable companies that generate no tax receipts to fund public services. This time will be remembered as history’s most expensive virtue signal ever committed knowingly by government.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, I think we’re a bit despondent here and we’re forgetting that, in the real world, things are happening. For example, my own local authority, County Meath, today had an action training course on climate change for its staff and its local councillors. The neighbouring county, Louth, have a very strong Dunleer Sustainable Energy group and they work at ground level and help vulnerable communities refurbish their homes with support from government. So don’t be despondent. The real world is taking action.  But we need to do much more. I want to talk in particular about how we’re going about this. There’s a lot of finger pointing about what you’re not doing and what you need to do and I think we need less of that. We are dividing sectors and we are fragmenting within sectors, particularly on agriculture. I want to say very clearly that farmers know that they need to take action, but if you push them into a corner and blame as being the problem, they cannot be part of the solution. So we need to be very careful about our language.  Farmers themselves are in dire straits. They’re protesting, they’re fragmenting and they really are directionless, so we need to give them direction. We have smart farming and we have conservation agriculture. I do agree that we need a more environmental Common Agricultural Policy, but we need to give strong signals and reward people who do deliver. More importantly, the food supply chain is broken. Competition law has resulted in the following statistics, and I’ll give them to you: 70% of global agricultural industry controlled by three companies, 90% of the grain trade by four companies, and the five largest food retailers in 13 Member States have a combined turnover of 60% of the marketplace. It’s broken. We need to fix that before we can really fix climate change issues.  (Applause)

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fact that there is a climate and ecological emergency today is a fact that must be taken very seriously, whatever some people say in here too.  Temperature surveys show that an unprecedented upward trend has increased over the last fifty years. Every European citizen now has almost direct experience of extraordinary and often catastrophic weather events.  On the other hand, the demographic pressure on the planet increases, we were about 2 billion in '27, now we are 7 billion with projections in thirty years that show that in 2050 we will reach 10 billion. So if we want to preserve the planet and the quality of life of future generations, we need a paradigm shift in our development model. Today, action to combat climate change means putting policies in place in all areas, without exception. Firstly, we must protect what we still have, defending the environment and biodiversity. But I am also thinking of the challenge of cleaner energy and more sustainable agriculture, the great issue of mobility, with less polluting means of transport and more efficient and integrated infrastructures, making the most of the new models of shared mobility. No less important is vocational training in order to create the new skills that innovations in production processes and consumption patterns require. Let us think about the circular economy and the possibility of employing new workers in the processing from waste to new raw materials. Because that is how we protect a subject dear to us today, work, adapting it to the new professions.  However, if we do not want to make fun of ourselves, wash our consciences with good intentions and then continue as if nothing had happened, we need adequate resources and far-sighted decisions. The commitments made by President Ursula von der Leyen simply need to be financed from a multiannual EU budget that is more ambitious and adapted to the climate challenge.  I will end by paraphrasing the Nobel Prize in Physics Michel Mayor, who recently, in front of those who asked him about possible plans B of new habitable planets, replied: "let us think rather about taking care of our planet which is still beautiful and above all livable". Well, let's take care of our planet now, not because Greta asks us, but because it's about our future.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger, every time we discuss climate change in this House I look over there at the gallery at the young people because actually that’s what we’re discussing about. I want to give you a message today: the European Union is a climate mitigation giant but the European Union is also a climate adaptation dwarf. Climate change is here and is happening now, but we are doing so little to adapt to it. We must adapt to climate change by changing the way we build houses, by preventing climate migration, by building dykes to prevent floods, by managing forests to prevent wildfires, by greening the roofs in our cities. There is no contradiction between mitigation and adaptation. In France, insulating homes to reduce greenhouse emissions is also an adaptation measure preparing the homes for climate change. But in the current MFF, only 3% of our EU Structural and Investment Funds on climate are related to adaptation. In the next MFF, Mr Oettinger, let’s put our money where our mouth is.

name: Michael BLOSS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The climate crisis is not a natural disaster, no, it is homemade, and it is the result of misguided policies. To change that, 4.5 million people in Europe were on the streets in September. Thank you, Fridays For Future! Thank you for every sign, for every Friday you take to the streets and encourage us and refer to science. Because that is clear and unambiguous. There must be no more "Continue like this!" no more pills. So far, however, there have been only hollow announcements on the Commission's Climate Change Act. At the same time, EUR 1.5 billion is being invested in climate-damaging gas projects, and in Germany, unfortunately, the climate protection package is just one thing: pill said. This is not how we create climate neutrality. It is nice that the Social Democrats want to have a debate on the subject here, but it is not enough to discuss it. We want to see action at last!

name: Sylvia LIMMER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If the climate neurotics gathered here are constantly talking about a climate catastrophe, it is always in terms of the CO2 content in our atmosphere, and here only for the last 150 years. And for good reason: if you look at our Earth history, you would realize that the previous CO2 content was mostly much higher than our current concentration of 400 ppm. Worse still, there is no proportional correlation between CO2 and temperature. Take, for example, the green-hysterical assumption that an increase of 100 ppm will cause a temperature increase of 2 oC. This would mean that at the time of the dinosaurs, when the CO2 concentration was close to 2 000 ppm, i.e. 1 600 ppm higher than today, the temperature should also have been a whopping 32 oC higher, i.e. around 50 oC or more. I know a lot of numbers in such a short time, that certainly overwhelms one or the other politician's brain. Climate change is the rule, not the exception. We do well to adapt to a changing climate. They can only lose the battle of the Climate Don Quixote es against the climate.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Madam President, I believe that we should all see each other and really listen to what is being said here because everyone is talking about science and here we are almost talking about magic. These are words in which everything is full of ideology. You're not really talking to common sense. We are further and further away in the language of rationality. We're increasingly in ideology. We are increasingly in radicality. There is already talk in the title of the 'climate emergency'; it's already loaded. Everything is full of ideology in this debate and above all we have new clerics who are expelling from the debate all those who question, seek other positions or who have other real positions. I think we should all make an effort on this so as not to allow these clerics, those fanatics to take control of the discussion and that's what seems to be happening in Europe. If they are in control of this discussion, what have been substitute ideologies in the twentieth century—which have been communism and Nazism—are now to be replaced by these kinds of ideologies of environmentalism and climacatastrophism.

name: Petros KOKKALIS
text: – Madam  President, I would like to thank the author for introducing this bill, but I would like also to disagree with the title. It is an emergency. It is a serious and unexpected situation requiring immediate action, but it’s not climate or ecological. It is a human catastrophe which is affecting frontline communities. It is disrupting food patterns. It is creating failed states. It is creating climate refugees. It is exhausting our civic protection capabilities in the face of extreme weather phenomena, and this is the action that we need to take against it. And in this emergency, Europe can be the leader. Unlike the emergency room which we talked about in the morning about Turkey and Kurdistan, in this emergency we can offer more than words. We are the leader in this situation, and we should continue to be so globally. In this House we expect to pass a just European Green Deal in the spring. This means that we need a comprehensive cross-sectoral platform full of new regulation and legislation, an action plan that will ensure climate neutrality by 2050, and at the same time not only creating millions of jobs, but saving us trillions of imported fossil fuel which of course we don’t have in Europe. So this is not about losing jobs, it is about creating jobs, and it is our action that needs to be taken to confront this emergency.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: – Madam President, it’s now or never. Climate change is no longer a theoretical debate among scientists, but a reality. If not addressed immediately and resolutely it will have a devastating impact on the planet and on the lives of current and future generations. We all need to understand it is no longer linked to certain political forces or ideologies, but it is a total issue: the biggest risk ever involving all of humanity.  I want to be very clear about what I believe should be the concrete proposal of the new European Commission. First of all, it is essential to exclude green investments from deficit calculations in the Stability Pact. Indeed, with the actual EU constraints it is very difficult for Member States to act properly. Second, we must aim to completely phase out investments in fossil fuels. And third, we need to be much more ambitious in terms of targets, aiming for a 65% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030. Future generations will judge us for what we are doing to the planet and those judgments will be decidedly very harsh. We need concrete and urgent actions now.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. I would like to point out that global warming is a very important issue that we need to find a solution to as soon as possible. Scientific evidence shows that it's not too late to slow down climate change. I think that is why we can do the most with calm, well-thought-out plans. It is necessary for the European Union to make a serious financial contribution to member states' expenditure if the aim is to have a climate-neutral economy for the European Union by 2050. Hungary 90 percent of the world's energy production could be climate neutral by 2030. However, the impact assessment has also shown that total carbon neutrality in Hungary, planned for 2050, will cost at least EUR 150 billion.  In my opinion, the European Union must prioritise maintaining competitiveness, which must be in line with climate protection objectives. Therefore, in my opinion, in the future, we must find a way to jointly finance the costs of climate neutrality so that European economic operators can remain competitive.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report The message from New York was clear: the climate summit, the sustainability summit, wrote us in the register – and Commissioner Oettinger, I would also like to see that we are already on the right path, but the summation was another – that we are miles behind what we have said we want to achieve. And that's why we have to squeal. We, as the European Union, must lead the way and send out new signals both in our internal policy fields and in development, in trade policy and in foreign policy. I am waiting for one, and this is a job that you still have to do in the transition to the new Commission. The old Commission has rightly described a scenario 1, one in which sustainability becomes binding on all policy areas. However, I have not yet heard from the new President of the Commission the commitment that this binding scenario 1 for sustainability in all policy areas will become the compass of the new Commission. And that is what we want to see, we want to hear that, and here you can make a major contribution in the transition to the new Commission. I would be pleased to receive such an answer.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Madam President, let us be clear, the UN climate summit in New York gave birth to a mouse. Only 66 countries, representing less than 7% of CO2 emissions, have pledged to do better by 2020. Meanwhile, the big polluters, the others, continue to play the watch.  Europe therefore has, more than ever, our duty of exemplary exemplarity, and here the levers are known. It has been said. The most important, of course, is the Green Deal, which must come to fruition during this mandate. EUR 1 trillion pledged over ten years, which must be invested in the ecological transition, with a central role, of course, for the European Investment Bank.  So it is obvious, of course, but at a time when the ambitions for the next financial framework 2021-2027 are shrinking, we like to remind you of this obviousness. The climate emergency also means acting on the impact of pollution on our health. Air pollution is greatly exacerbated by climate change. It kills more than tobacco in Europe. It is responsible for 660,000 deaths a year.  In Europe, a healthy air is a right of European citizens. It must also become a priority for the new Commission, along with the climate emergency.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating The We really have an emergency on the planet, both in terms of global warming and the loss of biodiversity. Biodiversity that is so important for the planet to be able to adapt to a warmer climate. It is a global crisis that we are facing and yet we are not treating this crisis as a crisis. We've passed 1.1°C.  To it should be added about half a degree that particles, aeorosols in dirty air around the world, have masked away in some of the global warming as a result of an enhanced greenhouse effect that we humans have already caused.  We can still succeed with the Paris Agreement. We must not give up. But it really requires us who are elected in the European Parliament during these five years to do everything we can. This is exactly what all the demonstrating young people around the world are demanding of us. These five years are perhaps the last five years we have to change the world fast enough and fast enough. Let's do it together.

name: Aurelia BEIGNEUX
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, while we are to be pleased that the whole of the European political class is now interested in ecology, there is no denying the opportune nature of the political display which has been made of it for years with an undeniable aftertaste of greenwashing. The awareness of the climate and ecological emergency has unfortunately made it possible to give moral support to political coups and a hostage-taking of European nations. Failing to be environmental, the answer was fiscal, to better puncture peoples, and moral, to better impose mass immigration and supposedly climatic refugees. Without constantly blaming European citizens, especially the most modest ones, it is the orientations of their national and European leaders that must now be condemned and changed. It is indeed the whole political, ideological and economic software that needs to be reformed to respond to this obvious health, environmental and moral emergency.  All of this, of course, requires a questioning of all free trade treaties and the restoration of the sovereignty of all European peoples. This is the prerequisite for any serious debate. The rest is just literature.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I am listening carefully to this debate and, unfortunately, I have not heard a single word about the speculative nature of the emissions trading scheme. Nor have I heard the left's concern about the increase in energy poverty in the European Union. So I'll remind you.  The 54 million people in the European Union are suffering precisely from energy poverty. Today you are proposing to extend restrictive climate policy to new areas. You're talking about agriculture. So do you want to ensure that poverty also includes this area and that we finally start talking about food poverty? After all, outside the European Union, of course, food will be produced, animals will be stuffed with hormones, antibiotics without any control.  That is why we need a climate policy that is sensible and prudent, which takes into account the differences in the level of economic development of the Member States, which speaks of the right to shape the energy mix on its own, which is in line with the Treaty provisions, which also draws attention to differences in the level of wealth of societies, precisely in order to prevent energy poverty.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, at the EU summit, there was 10 minutes discussing climate action. It spoke volumes for their priorities. The UN Climate Summit in New York last month was supposed to boost climate action but it produced nothing. The latest science makes it clear that not one of the EU’s climate and energy targets are in line with the Paris agreement. An emergency situation needs an emergency response. If you’re serious about dealing with climate challenges and problems, there are some actions that need to be taken now: you need to end fossil fuel subsidies straight away; you should stop liquid natural gas projects across Europe, including the Shannon project in Ireland; you need to stop funding gas projects, and you should end the Stability and Growth Pact and let’s invest in renewable energy. Without these basic steps to undo these climate contradictions, we are in denial.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Climate change is a very emotional issue. We see it every Friday at the student demonstrations of Fridays For Future. What is clear in today's debate, but also in today's debate, is that the question is not that we need to do something about climate change – some ask this question – but that we keep turning to the questions of what and how.  It is very important to me that we stop demonising certain industries or actors. I would like to work to highlight the positive elements against climate change and to promote potential. Only action against climate change, supported by society, will be successful. An example from agriculture: farmers are frustrated that they are always pilloried and that they have a negative effect on the climate. Across Europe, they are protesting – yesterday, by the way, here in front of Parliament. Unfortunately, throughout the debate, it is often forgotten that agriculture and forestry are the only sector with the great potential to bind carbon. All our European forests store at least 10% of our European emissions. That is why we must actively promote and shape the prevention of carbon, especially carbon sequestration. I could imagine such an incentive mechanism for Europe as well. By the way, New Zealand has gone ahead. Please pay tribute to our farmers for their actions, not a mockery.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: – Madam President, tackling the world’s climate emergency must be Europe’s defining issue: renewables, energy efficiency, circular economy, agriculture, transport, oceans, climate-proofing trade deals, digitalisation, energy poverty, regional regeneration, sustainable investment, embracing our stakeholders, research experts and our citizens. A profound European Green New Deal that leads the world, works across the portfolio of every Commissioner and every EU government. We are facing catastrophic climate chaos unless as Europe we take immediate and joined-up holistic action, with a just transition that works for every European citizen and leaves no worker, no young woman and no region behind. For the air that we breathe, we need to listen to our young people. We cannot wait any longer. We need to deliver an EU-wide climate emergency now. (Applause)

name: Martin HOJSÍK
text: – Madam President, we have indeed an emergency on our hands, but we don’t act like there is one. It’s been long in coming and we kept on ignoring it, but now it’s here, both in climate as well as in biodiversity. Yet what do we see? Just today we had to object to protect the bees, to protect the biodiversity, to what our governments and the Member States have been doing. This House has been elected this year with a very strong mandate to act on climate and biodiversity. What we need now is to hold the governments – the Member States – accountable, because on one hand, we say that we act on the climate, we’re going to phase out coal, and on the other hand, we actually use public money to export coal-fired power plants to third countries. On one hand, we say we’re going to deal with the switch to renewables, and on the other hand we have projects of common interest building oil pipelines. We really need a fundamental change and we really need to hold our own government accountable. I will, and I hope that you will too. And so will the public.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the warmest year. The climate emergency is real, it is happening every day. It is already impacting and hitting the most vulnerable populations. The time for lectures and debates is over!  The urgency of the finding, we must respond with the urgency of the action. The urgency of the action is for this European Parliament to declare a state of climate emergency to push the European Commission to reduce our CO2 emissions by a minimum of 60% by 2030. It is also that the maritime sector and the aviation sector, through, for example, a kerosene tax, are finally participating in this transition. It is to show that the battle of climate is the battle of jobs, it is the battle of well-being and it is the battle of our common good.  All this can only be done if we have the citizens with us. We must show this youth, who are on the street, this youth who look at us, who is waiting for us, that we have finally understood the message and that we have the political courage to say correctly: we will do it fast, strong and well.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent, very media-based climate protests have feared catastrophic scenarios, without offering any real solutions.  Europe has already significantly reduced greenhouse gas emissions over the last thirty years. Frans now proposes achieving 'climate neutrality' in 2050, a laudable but so onerous and sudden goal that it will weigh on citizens and businesses. Italy, by investing substantial resources, will achieve the 2020 decarbonisation targets, other European states, which comply with the Stability Pact, however, use coal or even worse lignite for 40 % of its energy mix, and will not achieve the objectives set. But is it more important to respect budgetary balance or environmental protection? And who does not respect the parameters in this case does not pay? Pollution does not stop at national borders. We are closing trade agreements with countries that do not have environmental constraints and by importing their products we are helping to pollute and generate unfair competition against our companies, which are rightly subject to strict environmental constraints.  It seems to me to be a Europe which, although it is already in a pit, continues to dig out of it.

name: Izabela-Helena KLOC
text: –Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Let's start with the fact that there really is no clear definition of climate threat. I, of course, appreciate anyone who sincerely cares about the future of our environment, where the highest value is man. But what is a climate threat? We watch extinction rebellion videos from all over the world. They show participants who use violence, destroy buildings, generate additional costs for the police. It seems that these people are not fully aware of what they are doing. I am afraid that many have been let go and used for purely anarchist proceedings. This is a dangerous and irresponsible action, and the truth is that only the rich and the privileged can afford to preach and take radical action to combat climate change, and the poor, the victims, will really pay for it. A colleague has already spoken about energy poverty. This is unfair and I am surprised that the European left is taking such action.  I believe that energy security and affordability should be our top priority for these poorest people. Marxist social engineering experiments have yielded only poverty and suffering in the last century. Let us not repeat the same mistake, and I see that this is done on a massive scale.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, the next Commission needs its highest based approach towards climate change, biodiversity loss and all the other ecological emergencies. That means that all the political initiatives and regulations proposed need to be measured up by the size of the challenge within the next 30 years, because we are underachieving in our decisions and proposals. So what we do needs to equal the size of the challenge, and that basically means that we need to at least double our efforts if we are going to tackle it.  Secondly, we need a circular economy package. We need sustainable financial steps and impact assessments of the cost of non-actions. Let’s not be the democracies in denial that are sleepwalking to catastrophe. We know what the challenge is and we do have the technology to tackle that. And yes, we do have the money. It is only the 20 centimetres behind our ears that prevents appropriate action.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, it is clear that climate change is no longer a future threat to become a present emergency. Scientists keep telling us that if we don't act the damage is going to be irreparable anymore, and that damage is a real threat to our way of life.  Young people repeat this every weekend when they show up to ask us for strong action and are told by the United Nations, which organizes summits to call on the international community as a whole to act. That we act with a smart, ambitious and fair plan to decarbonize our economy and be CO2-neutral by 2050.  And that's acting on our energy, infrastructure, taxes, transportation, international trade. That is the scale of the change that needs to be made. And it must be done by mobilizing sufficient resources to make these changes a reality — the European Green Deal – and to put social buffers to accompany these changes for those who are harmed. And, moreover, by doing so in the European way — in the best of ways — because in the climate you cannot negotiate, you cannot compete. With the weather you can only cooperate, which is what the European Union and this house are created for.

name: Caroline VOADEN
text: – Madam President, the relationship between humankind and the earth we inhabit is in crisis, and all over the world we can see people’s frustration. Over the past few months alone, over six million people worldwide have marched and demonstrated to ask policymakers like us to listen, to take action on the climate emergency, and to protect the natural world. We must listen to what they are saying. Nature does not need people, but we need nature. How we choose to act now, and the choices we make about protecting our environment, will determine the future of humankind on this planet for the next 10 000 years. We here must make an ambitious European Green Deal a reality. We must ensure that the Commission’s proposals for legislation over the next months reflect the ecological emergency and the climate chaos that our children, our grandchildren and future generations are facing. We cannot let them down.

name: Jutta PAULUS
text: – Madam President, in 2009 the Stockholm Resilience Centre first published a paper in which they introduced nine planetary boundaries. This means these are boundaries which may not be passed if Earth is to remain habitable for humans. Everyone is fully justified talking about the climate crisis. But there are two boundaries which are much more drastically exceeded: this is biosphere integrity – biodiversity basically – and biogeochemical flows, which means putting nitrogen, soluble nitrogen and phosphorous into the environment. For these reasons species are going extinct at an unprecedented rate and what we are doing, we are putting the base of our life at risk – the biosphere which provides us with drinkable water, with fertile soils with clean air and this must stop. So, we expect the new Commission to come up with a stringent plan on how we will act. How we will act on agriculture, on land use, on oceans and this must be part of the Green New Deal, because otherwise we will not solve this crisis.

name: Robert ROOS
text: Mr President, colleagues here talk about climate change as if the end of time had come to an end. Prophets of doom are, but the factual basis is lacking. CO2 is not a pollutant. It is an essential molecule for all life on Earth. The climate has been changing for as long as the planet has existed. Measuring is knowing and the climate measurements are very different from the climate models. Warming is now only at half the predicted value. There is no statistical evidence that there are more and more hurricanes, floods or droughts. Sea levels have been rising consistently for 130 years at just 1.86 millimetres per year and this is not accelerating. Yes, the ice at the North Pole is melting, but on the other hand, the ice at the South Pole is growing more than expected. The little ice age only ended 170 years ago. It is therefore no surprise that we are now going through a period of warming. But there's no need to panic, and there's no reason for Greta. We will only have to take adjustment measures, as we have always done.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear Chairman, global climate change is evident and clearly has a negative impact on the environment. We can't close our eyes to the testimony that we're losing glaciers, in the face of witnessing the Amazon burning, all of which we've seen over the years, this summer. The world recorded the highest temperatures in July this summer, and even research will seem to show that 2019 will be among the five hottest years. Therefore, it is evident that something is happening around us and before that we cannot close our eyes.  We must act and I agree with all of you who say that it is not the end of the world, but it is urgent and all of this leads me to say that it is good that today we have this topic on the agenda, that today we discuss this at the beginning of this term and at the beginning of the work of the new Commission, in which I will also be a member, and I am very glad that Ms. Ursula von der Leyen has put in her program as one of the top priorities of the Green agreement and that we will discuss it within the first hundred days. It's something that's really important and that inspires my confidence.  It also gives me confidence that the European Council also spoke at last week's summit about a peaceful transition, tentatively speaking, on a peaceful and green transition and will ensure the implementation of the Paris Agreement. Of course, someone said that the September meeting in New York was not with particular results, however, it is one of the first important meetings that took place after the Paris Agreement.  I want to say in the end that it is definite that we must give the Earth to our descendants better than we received it and that is our obligation both morally and legally and I hope that we will all continue to act in this regard.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am optimistic in nature. I would therefore like to send an optimistic message today about a complex and major challenge such as climate change. Despite the fumbling in the Council and the obstruction of many Member States in the Council, I am optimistic, Madam President of the Council, that the new Commission will come up with a good new Green deal and a good climate law. And I hope for a large majority in this House to set the 2030 and 2050 targets very ambitious. I would also like to send the message that we must not be naïve. If we are very ambitious and set high targets, then we must ensure that we also protect our industry and give it the means to survive in that difficult, competitive world. So we will need a mechanism for carbon corrections or a CO2 tax. It is not for me, if we just ensure that the polluter pays and that our industry is well protected, with high ambitions.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, let’s listen to science. We only have a few years left to take meaningful action against climate catastrophe. This is not radicalism: this is a fact. Representing a Member State that is home to some of the poorest regions of our Union, I also have to add that fighting the climate crisis has to go hand in hand with the poverty crisis, because our poorest regions are the most vulnerable to these climate-related risks. Those people are hit hardest who have the fewest means to fight back. We are dealing with a vicious cycle and we have to act now.  If climate change threatens the health and livelihood of those people who are already vulnerable, escaping poverty becomes even more difficult, and this is why a just transition is the only way forward to a carbon-neutral and circular economy.  Politics is shifting throughout Europe and I’m very happy for my hometown, Budapest, whose newly elected leaders pledged to declare climate emergency, ending years of inaction, and I applaud the ambitious climate agenda put forward by Ms von der Leyen. But let’s not forget that effective climate action has to go hand in hand with a strong regional policy with more solidarity, leaving no Europeans behind.

name: Damien CARÊME
text: Madam President, colleagues, the discourses on the climate emergency have long followed and are similar. Ladies and gentlemen, when it comes to voting for another CAP, for trade agreements or environmentally friendly energy projects, there is no more urgency. The gap between speech and action is unbearable today. Thus, France, for example, parades and paraphrases all the beautiful agreements, such as that of Paris, and, at the same time, does not act to the objectives set.  It is in fact to put an end to this hypocrisy that I have filed a complaint against the French state for climate inaction. The latest IPCC report confirms the concerns.
