Grande-Synthe, the city of which I was mayor for a long time, will be underwater in 2100 and 400,000 inhabitants will have to be displaced.  So let's replace the "at the same time" with "it's time": it's time to do and it's time to act. Yes, let's declare a climate emergency. Let us not make it one more statement of intent. So let's adopt a text that will make it an intangible golden rule. If there is a golden rule for the budget, there must also be one for the climate. Rather than a debate, the climate emergency must become an imperative for action and this imperative will also be social because ecology is social.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I think we are about to agree that climate change is a very important challenge. However, it seems quite obvious to me that we should pursue this sustainable, low-carbon and circular society within the framework of innovation, progress and economic growth. It is not about just taking planet and climate as a target. Jobs and prosperity must also be protected. I have three specific comments. We often hear it said: system change, not climate change. I fully agree with that, insofar as we are talking about the changes to a system in which the economic whole is also conclusive and market forces remain intact. Secondly, we must fully draw the map of innovation and abandon doom-mon view. Thirdly, of course, we cannot do it alone. We will need allies to tackle this challenge, and that is why I would like to ask the Commissioner: what is the Commission's strategy for actually establishing that international alliance?

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is leading the effort to tackle climate change and has ambitious targets, such as a minimum reduction of 50 % in carbon dioxide emissions by 2030. However, it is necessary to proceed with an impact study so that we can make the promises a reality and at the same time monitor closely the implementation of the models of the circular economy. But we also need the rest of the world players in this effort to tackle climate change, not only states, but also states and regions and regions and civic organisations. We also need sustainable funding. The European Investment Bank can become a climate bank, but it is necessary to provide opportunities to use natural gas as a transition fuel and to continue financing gas infrastructure. It is also necessary to have practical support in the Member States which set ambitious targets, targets for the energy transition. My country, Greece, is going to reduce the carbon footprint and reduce it to zero by 2028. It is therefore necessary, for this effort, to have the appropriate support.

name: Marek BELKA
text: – Madam President, transition from fossil-based energy production requires a lot of resources. Transition sometimes also has severe social cost. This cost is greater in some countries than in others. Poland is an extreme example where the cost is high. Nevertheless, it has to be done in the very interest of the country itself whose environment, airways and waterways are crumbling under the burden of coal. Poland asks for more money and more time. Is it legitimate? It is, but only if there is a determination on the part of the Polish authorities to change the energy mix from fossil fuels to renewables. More money and time? Yes, but only if the Government puts forward a detailed, credible, verifiable and closely monitored roadmap of switching away from coal into renewables.

name: Valter FLEGO
text: – Dear Chairman, Climate and Ecology are not only themes of the future, but also of the present. And everything that happens with temperatures, floods, droughts, doesn't happen by accident. For this reason, it is clear that we urgently need to act. One common, sustainable, green plan needs to be adopted urgently. We need a new Europe that will know how to reconcile, on the one hand, the protection of the environment and nature, and on the other hand, of course, the desire for economic growth and development.  Colleagues, time is running out, and therefore with the help of the European Union budget we need to implement a just transition, but we can only do so with the help of an environmentally oriented budget 21-27. because the price of electric vehicles, organic agriculture or alternative energy sources must not be paid by our citizens, craftsmen, farmers, but above all, the environmentally oriented budget of the European Union.

name: Ciarán CUFFE
text: – Madam President, the European Green Deal will only succeed if it makes a real difference in people’s lives. In transport and environment we have a real challenge and Frans Timmermans and Kadri Simson have a real struggle ahead of them. The urban agenda for the EU is a good starting point for their work. Why? Because it puts air quality, housing and urban poverty at the heart of a just transition through regulation, funding and knowledge. So, Mr Timmermans, I want you to promote active travel and that means walking and cycling. The end result is less traffic and a healthier population. I want you to join up urban planning and transport policies so people can travel less and easier. And to Ms Simson, speed up retrofitting. This tackles fuel poverty. Start with public housing and give us an A energy rating to public homes. And make the European super grid a reality so that green electricity can travel to where it is needed.  (Applause)

name: Agnès EVREN
text: Madam President, cities account for almost 70% of global greenhouse gas emissions. They therefore have a strategic role to play in the battle against global warming.  Commissioner, I am adamant that we cannot talk about a climate emergency without talking about cities. However, the observation is very simple: too often, cities, and among them, metropolises, are forgotten from the debate and this one is no exception.  Elected from Paris, I see it every day. Metropolises suffocate and city dwellers with: pollution, traffic jams, overdensification and lack of green spaces. They are a true concentration of the problems responsible for global warming. They are also the first victims. This can be evidenced by the tenfold heatwaves or the severe deterioration of the health of city dwellers.  If cities are part of the problem, they are also part of the solution, thanks to their many innovative and effective initiatives. So, Commissioner, let us put cities at the heart of the green pact if we want its success.

name: Aurore LALUCQ
text: Madam President, colleague, I thank you for organising this debate. Yes, indeed there is an urgent need to act and there is an urgent need to set up a Green New Deal. The Green New Deal is not green finance. It is illusory to think that what led us, in 2008, right into the wall, will now save us from anything, let alone from climate change. A Green New Deal is a social project that, through a massive investment plan in the thermal renovation of buildings in low-tech, not in high-tech, in plant infrastructure, in renewables, can allow us both to save ourselves from climate change, to create 10 million jobs, to eradicate environmental poverty and to finally create a European industrial policy.  So yes, it's going to be difficult because we have to anticipate everything in terms of employment because we've all been involved in mass consumption, but the real risk is not being ambitious enough at this stage. For the 50 to 100 million energy insecure people on this continent, for those who are already losing their jobs today, for climate refugees, let us live up to it, let us be ambitious in this Parliament.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, the alterations caused by man's action in the environment lead to increasingly frequent extreme phenomena. Forecasts augur climate migrations, flooding in coastal areas... Reversing this threat forces global climate goals to be influenced and internal action to be reversed.  At the local and regional levels, battles such as mobility or waste are won and, from proximity, it is easier to raise people's awareness of the impact of the principle of sustainability on everyday life.  I therefore propose that the fight against climate change be a horizontal axis in the budgets of all public institutions, that the energy they contract is one hundred percent renewable and that this climate and environmental axis be key in presentation and accountability.  The 2020 budgets in the Basque Country test these formulas which can be a very good practice for the European Union.

name: Tilly METZ
text: Madam President, fighting climate change also means taking care of our land and soil.  Indeed, and you all know it, besides plants, our land, too, can be an important lever for CO2 storage. With a growth rate of only 0.4% per year, the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere would be significantly reduced. But for this to happen, soils must be healthy and alive because a whole world of microorganisms, fungi, bacteria, insects and worms can live underground if, and only if, we do not destroy this ecosystem with chemicals and overexploiting these soils. So, yes, we need an ecological transition in agriculture to re-establish natural balances and thus combat climate change. Healthy soils, as well as air and water, are essential for life, biodiversity and the fight against global warming. So let's protect them through a framework directive on soil protection.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: – (beginning of the speech when the micro is switched off) ... Europe has finally pushed through the Paris climate agreement, important that we are global leaders in emissions trading and plastic bans, that we need to do much more, for example in research, through hydrogen initiatives, through export bans on plastic and much more. On the contrary, Europe must also use its economic power. We must curb the overexploitation of resources in Latin America, China and India. Here is the global climate problem. Let us cooperate wisely and economically with these countries for the mutual benefit of the same way, in order to ultimately influence them ecologically. But a Green Deal does not insult the people there and here – not the people who work in the steel industry, in agriculture, in mining, in the car industry. A Green Deal also takes people and jobs with them, all over the globe. A Green Deal does not intimidate the end of the world. A Green Deal also takes advantage of the self-interest of people and businesses in a sustainable environment. Climate protection must also be allowed to make money and save money. Climate protection must also be allowed to be fun, then the smart deal is really a good deal.

name: Mohammed CHAHIM
text: – Madam President, we cannot have a debate about climate emergency without talking about the measures we need to take. That is the difference between the EU being a leader or pretending to be a leader. I know that some people in this House think that we already do a lot, but are we really the cleanest continent? It is true that emissions in the EU have decreased, but our carbon footprint is still increasing. Who do you think China is producing for? We are the biggest consumer market, so we have a responsibility to lead, and as true leaders we have to invest in climate diplomacy, get rid of fossil fuel subsidies, introduce a climate law and start using natural solutions. I’m not convinced when I hear Ms von der Leyen say we need to go for a 50% reduction and if other countries follow, we go for 55. This is not only pretending to be a leader, this is ignoring the current climate emergency. It’s time to show leadership. It’s time to show ambition.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The climate needs Europe. Environmental threats do not stop at national borders. Nor can the solutions do. The climate needs action and there is a rush. With several green liberal solutions, we can reverse this trend before it is too late. It must be easier for individuals to make good environmental choices, but it must cost expensive to waste and let out. Our emissions trading scheme must work much, much better than it is today. The best thing would be to have a common carbon tax for sustainability and growth.  The EU should be the world's leading environmental organisation, an engine for innovation where our free trade agreements become important policy documents for global climate policy. We need to take the lead and show that it is possible to switch from fossil dependence. If we don't, how are we going to demand it from someone else?

name: Scott AINSLIE
text: – Madam President, we have ten years left to try and avoid environmental and ecological breakdown. The science is clear and free of political spin. Politicians who choose to ignore them are failing to protect citizens, and this is why a record 7.6 million people around the world, many of them schoolchildren, took to the streets last month to demand urgent action. When those children ask you what you did when there was a chance to act, what will you say? I’ll say: I was one of the people who got my local council to be the first in London to declare a climate emergency and have plotted a course and a timetable to get to carbon neutrality by 2030. And we will do the same to ensure the London Assembly and the UK Government deliver on their commitments. I’d also like to say: and I was one of those who persuaded the EU to end fossil fuel subsidies, put a tax on aviation and helped ensure the EU got to carbon neutrality by 2030 and used its influence to get other nations to do the same. If you want a future, we must act now.

name: András GYÜRK
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. The seriousness of the climate situation is beyond dispute, so raising awareness, if you will, in such a parliamentary session is not enough today. We must act responsibly, i.e. with the complexity of the challenge in mind. In addition to the ecological component, sustainable development has a competitiveness and social dimension. If we focus purely on the ecological factor, we will soon face a social and economic emergency, which is as unacceptable as the climate emergency. A fair and competitive transition is therefore needed to resolve the climate issue. Measures that do not lead to a sharp increase in consumer prices and do not jeopardise the security of supply and competitiveness of the Member States. On the road to climate neutrality, it is also worth taking into account good practices in the Member States. Such a good example Hungary, which, in addition to a steadily growing economy over the last decade, has reduced greenhouse gas emissions and lowered household energy prices.

name: Delara BURKHARDT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What other word is left for us to call the state of our climate and the environment a state of emergency! Because temperatures are rising, more and more species are disappearing from our planet, more and more people are having to leave their homes because of climate change. Calling a state of emergency is one thing. What we are doing now is the crucial thing. If we are serious, then the reform of the common agricultural policy must ensure that our subsidies protect the environment and support farmers in doing so. If we are serious, our trade agreements must contain binding, enforceable environmental and social standards. If we are serious, we need a European and international policy on the protection of species, with clear objectives and concrete implementation. If we are serious, we are investing in a sustainable future, in just and socio-ecological change, with the Green Deal. The declaration of a climate emergency can therefore only be a beginning. Let's get on with it!

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Madam President, if the global temperature of the earth’s surface increases as is predicted, this has terrible consequences, and one place where the effects of global warming and climate change can be visibly seen is the Arctic. The Arctic is warming at almost twice the global average rate of temperature increase and the melting of the Arctic ice in turn contributes to climate change.  As regards the Arctic, the responsibility of climate action cannot be in the hands of the Arctic countries alone. Pollution that appears in the Arctic climate is mostly from Asian, North American and European emitters, and as it happens the melting of the Arctic sea ice has opened a race for the region. Many governments and companies are very interested in new navigation routes as well as new fishing and natural resources in the Arctic. Developments concerning security, energy and the environment affect the security situation in Europe and beyond.  If we wish to stick to the Paris Agreement, immediate emission reductions are necessary. Also, we must be prepared for the changes resulting in the climate change in the Arctic to avoid the rise of tensions.

name: Anna DEPARNAY-GRUNENBERG
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Unfortunately, we humans have no direct sense to feel the state of the planet. Unfortunately, we human beings have no point in tracking down our actions in time. The effects of what we do are global and extend far beyond our human time horizon. But are we not knitted in such a way that we react quickly only when we see the need, when we feel it, when we smell it, when we understand it? That is why ecological change is also a profound cultural change.  As a society – and each of us every day – we must learn to make life-sustaining decisions in our daily lives. What mobility culture do we need? What consumer culture do we need? What food culture? How do we define prosperity? And, of course, in addition to the regulatory measures that we will have to take collectively, in addition to the market-based measures and technology levers that we must use, we also need to work together between science, politics, art and philosophy. We need to formulate positive visions in order to show the diversity of opportunities. Here too, in this cultural change, we as the EU must make progress in order to protect our climate and our biodiversity.

name: Hildegard BENTELE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Anyone who declares a state of emergency must be clear that this entails a clear shift of power to the executive, which can lead to the restriction of fundamental rights. In my view, therefore, this should be handled very carefully in peacetime. However, we parliamentarians should not relieve ourselves of this either. There is so much for us to do. We MEPs in the big cities in particular know that, in future, we will have to review all measures to see whether or not they contribute to greater cleanliness of air, water and soil, to greater energy efficiency, and not to a healthy environment as a whole. In cities – be it in Berlin, London or Paris, or in the twin cities of Berlin, Jakarta, Mexico City or Beijing – environmental problems are increasing due to the density of the population, transport and trade. In cities, however, there is also a higher density of know-how and innovation for the science-based and technology-open solution of environmental problems. My call for the Commission, therefore, is to recognise, in particular, the starting point and potential of cities and to respond horizontally in terms of promotion and regulation, so that together we can speed up the climate- and human-friendly transformation of our cities worldwide.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, sometimes we need to explain why we need to do something. But not today. Today, our businesses, our cities and our people ask us and want us to act to stop global warming, to stop deforestation, to stop climate change. Climate change will not slow down because of single actions, because climate change knows no borders. From China to the US, Australia and many places in the world, climate change affects us all.  We can only win if we work together, leaving no one behind. We must act on coal. We must act on aviation fuel tax exemptions. Fossil fuels belong to the past and together we must look into the future of energy. It’s time to let go of old technologies. It’s time to create and fund new ones. Let’s push Europe forward. Let’s invest more in science and innovation. Let’s make trade deals that fulfil the Paris Agreement. We face that choice. Either we act together or climate will change us all.

name: Tom BERENDSEN
text: Mr President, we have a great responsibility to our children and future generations to transfer the world sustainably. For me, sustainable means three things. Sustainable does indeed mean a cleaner world and we must be very ambitious in that. Sustainable also means an EU that is strategically independent of Russia or the Middle East for energy. That is why we need to look strategically at where we can best use solar, wind or other sustainable technologies in Europe and how we all benefit from it. Finally, sustainable means an EU with a strong economy, so that our children can also offer their children a good future. So we need to plan a fair transition for residents, business and industry. Are we wise to deal with, for example, existing gas infrastructure that can be used for other, more sustainable purposes in the future? And can companies benefit from the opportunities that the transition will undoubtedly offer? Ambitious, clean, strategic and a strong economy: these components make the climate plans truly sustainable.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, climate change is a certainty today, and its dimensions oblige us to react immediately. Agriculture, however, is today the most vulnerable to climate change compared to any other sector. At the same time, farmers in the European Union are the main guardians of the environment. The agricultural sector and rural areas of the European Union are essential for the well-being of European citizens, which requires access to quality and affordable food.  In 2050, the population will be 30% larger than the current one, which obliges us to strengthen our role as the most important food producers and food security guarantors. In the face of the threats and risks posed by climate change, Member States must develop environmental schemes to stimulate farmers so as to choose, as a matter of priority, the most effective agricultural practices for the climate and the environment.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: – Madam President, there is no doubt that the environment and sustainability are one of the great challenges that we must face, especially given the terrible effects of natural disasters, such as floods in Spain in September, where we must even mourn fatalities. Unfortunately, however, the left, for many years, has been aiming to promote the debate on everything about environmental conservation.  The left has colonized the common ground, in such a way that any realistic policy to address the climate future without making a revolution seems impractical. The left writes the reports of the international panel on warming and sustainability in its particular account adjustment with the development of capitalism and globalization, which has been pending since its enormous moral defeat in 1989.  Development and progress are not enemies of the environment. Let us not forget the great role that private management plays in the preservation of natural and ecosystem spaces throughout Europe. This issue cannot be addressed without emphasizing the local, the individual's link to his environment, personal responsibility and the role of local agencies.  Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, I ask you to stop using the environment as an argument for other political battles, to flee from exaggeration, fatalism and stigma and to start working to offer real proposals to citizens.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, there is a lot of work to be done and done to halt climate change, but it is also important to remember what has already been done and achieved. The targets set by the European Union for 2020 will be achieved and exceeded. More ambitious targets have been set for 2030 and, according to the European Commission's assessment, those targets will be achieved and exceeded once we implement all the legislation that has been dealt with here with this in mind.  A large clean energy package has been adopted here, an ambitious waste directive has been adopted, new emission limits have been decided for new cars, for the first time also for lorries. An ambitious plastics strategy has been decided, certain single-use plastics have been banned altogether, the circular economy has been promoted. In other than that, really impressive decisions have already been taken, but now we know that we need to keep up the pace and increase that 2030 emissions target to 55%. This is supported by an overwhelming majority in parliament. The European Union must take global leadership in climate policy.

name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the need to combat climate change is not a matter of political debate. The overwhelming evidence with which we are confronted forces us to act. We will have to act with ambition, but also responsibly, without making empty promises focused on what we can achieve, first of all, through the implementation of the policies and measures already agreed and the use of clean technologies already available, many of which have not yet been implemented.  We must also have the ambition to go further by adopting additional measures always on the basis of a sound impact assessment. But to go further, we need more scientific research, more innovation and more technology. Only in this way will it be possible to reconcile ambition in the fight against climate change with strong industrial leadership on the part of Europe, preserving our way of life.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, having the honour of representing Parliament at the Paris Agreement and in Marrakesh and, last year, in Poland, and being a rapporteur for the renewable energy file, I welcome this discussion because things have moved up a gear. it is now, as was rightly said, a climate and ecological emergency, and young people, in particular, have pointed that out to us. I welcome President-elect Ursula von der Leyen’s commitment to the Green New Deal and, above all, to come forward with proposals in the first 100 days because it is vital that we tackle this as a matter of urgency. When we were doing the renewable energy file, we said that the targets could only be increased upwards. That’s a good thing. But, at the same time, it is very important that we do not rush headlong into something and forget about those who are going to be impacted. A just transition fund is absolutely vital in this and Member States also need to be held to account on an annual basis to see how they’re progressing. That’s how we will deal with this emergency and honour the young people who are so concerned about their future.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, this House is prolix in reports, resolutions, speeches, pledges of commitment to combating climate change and defending the planet. The problem comes later. It comes with the carbon market that sacrifices the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions to the deal done with permits to pollute. It comes with policies that favor unsustainable production and consumption models. It comes with the deregulation of international trade, which favors models of intensive production of exporting nature. It comes with agricultural policies that favor agribusiness and its unsustainable practices, while destroying small production, promoting rural abandonment, the alienation of the relationship between man and nature, which Marx told us, in which they promote the concentration of the population in huge and unsustainable urban agglomerations. The problem comes with the European Union budget that finds resources to finance the arms industry, but cuts into economic, social and territorial cohesion and fails to finance nature conservation.  Now, instead of repeating here stifled and inconsequential proclamations, it would be good that we start to look very seriously at each and every one of these contradictions.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which it has been Together with my staff, I have recorded your numerous and substantive speeches. They have mapped a wide spectrum from agriculture to industry, from energy to buildings, from citizens to our economies. And it can be said that you also wanted to put pressure on you, thereby defining your expectations of how, in particular, the new Commission – with its first draft law after 100 days and in the Green Deal package – should speed up the whole dimension at European level and with partners outside Europe, thereby also meeting citizens' expectations and urgency in the matter. I believe that the debate is timely, because firstly, the new Commission will start soon, secondly, the budgetary framework is in the middle of the discussion – on the home straight – and can still experience improvements, changes: the Fund for a Fair Transition as an example, mainstreaming as a second example. In this respect, there is now a certain share of responsibility, particularly with the Committee on Budgets and the rapporteurs. I will report to Mr Timmermans and I thank you for your comprehensive remarks.

name: João FERREIRA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, this has been a very interesting discussion. I’ve listened carefully to your interventions and suggestions. Thank you so much for them. As I said at the beginning of this debate, stepping up the fight against climate change is now more urgent than ever and the EU has to show determination. We have to show leadership, we have to act as a global leader in climate action, and we as Presidency are working hard so that we can achieve that position.  We are also aiming at an agreement on the EU long-term carbon neutrality strategy. We hope to see positive results in the December European Council. It would be a great achievement if we all could agree on EU being climate-neutral by 2050. And as soon as the new Commission takes its place, and if there’s a proposal on the Just Transition Fund, I’m optimistic that the Member States would welcome such a proposal and it will be included in the upcoming seven-year budget, the MFF. Just Transition is key and we should all approach climate in that way. By its very nature this topic requires broad, extensive and inclusive debate, and the more opportunities we have to discuss these issues together, the better we are able to shape a shared vision for the future. So as our presidency motto says, let’s work together for a sustainable Europe, for a sustainable future.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – I would like to draw attention to the fact that a key element should not be missing from this debate: our most powerful weapon to combat climate change - the forests of the European Union. It occupies almost half of the union's territory, is Europe's lung, seizes most of its carbon dioxide emissions and underpins all environmental commitments undertaken: the Strategic Forest Plan, the UN Sustainable Development Goals, the Paris Agreement.  However, almost 77% of the European Union's forests are left behind, not subject to binding common legislation, as the Commission itself recognises in a reply that we have just received from the European Commission. There is an hour-by-hour fight for life, death and many millions of euros with the mafia of illegal deforestation.  That is why I think it is very important that, in the future European Green Pact, the Commission and the Commissioner in charge of this portfolio think of an effective, strict and applicable strategy for all Member States for the forests of the European Union, for which attention, and time resources, and the money needed to push the accelerator in the fight against climate change, are also being allocated.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – The sustainable development of States and the health of their population also involve the identification and continuous implementation of the most effective measures to combat factors that have a negative impact on the environment.  Without a clean planet, we cannot talk about healthy long-term development, prosperity, and that is why joint efforts are needed to increase the quality of life and the health of the planet. Climate change and its effects must be limited as a matter of urgency, through concrete actions by each EU Member State, but also by the EU. There is also a need for a constant synergistic effort to protect the environment to minimise climate change and the devastating effects it produces. Efforts must also be directed towards raising citizens' awareness of ways to protect the environment through individual action. The Union has committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, and this objective can only be achieved through the progress of each Member State, in order to ensure the transition to a climate-neutral EU, in line with the paris agreement.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. The climate and environmental events in different countries around the world demonstrate the growing importance of this issue for people and young people in particular. The protection of the environment, understood in all its forms, as a universal common good, unique and fundamental for life and health, as the primary place where the existence of present and future generations develops, is an objective to be pursued at every level to prevent the balance between ecosystems, biodiversity, human well-being and living beings from being compromised. Action must be taken now, prompting governments and the international community to adopt rules recognised by all as necessary to change our lifestyles, so that they are more responsible and eco-sustainable. We need a circular economy, we need to encourage renewable sources, we need to regenerate our cities, we need to focus on reclamation, we need to take all those actions aimed at reducing polluting emissions and energy waste, making a complete transition to clean energy. Building an economy and a society that make the environment and innovation the key to building new opportunities for well-being and employment will be the best thing we can do for our planet, for ourselves and for the generations to come.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – It is a certainty that the European Union's commitment to maintain its leading role in the fight against climate change is certain. After the 2015 Paris Agreement, the 'zero carbon emissions' target proposed by the future European Commission opens a new and ambitious stage that responds to citizens' concerns. The European elections in May this year have shown us all that, for European citizens, climate change is a real problem and that we are responsible for solving it.  At the same time, we have equal responsibility for economic development, job protection and the social impact of the changes required to reduce carbon emissions by 50% by 2030. If we take as an example the decarbonisation of road transport, mainly achieved by heavy-duty vehicles, we must commit that the transition to low-carbon technologies and fuels will be made without affecting the lives of the more than 6 million Europeans working in this industry.  On the other hand, the energy transition involves great systemic changes, from technology, infrastructure and new economic models, to social norms and new consumption habits, which we must make without jeopardising the economic security of citizens. In addition, we have a duty to ensure greater economic and social protection of economic regions based on coal mining by creating financial instruments to enable them to transition economically with minimal social costs.

name: Manuel PIZARRO
text: in writing. – Climate change needs an effective response from the Commission to monitor the recognised emergency of the situation. Based on the available scientific data, in line with the climate changes already verified, such as rising seawater levels and the increase in forest fires, among other disasters, it is important to act decisively in order to allow clear decarbonisation. The Commission will have to show signs of commitment to this issue and will have to allocate resources to environmental issues in order to achieve the targets set for 2030 and 2050. Member States' commitment to complywith eu legislation, strengthen the adoption of more ambitious plans, in line with the 2050 targets and the implementation of the plans approved by each State, should also be achieved.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the presentation of the Court of Auditors' 2018 Annual Report (2019/2802(RSP)). I welcome Mr Klaus-Heiner Lehne, president of the Court of Auditors. Before i open the debate, I would like to inform you that, in order to request spontaneous speeches and blue cards, it is possible to register both the standard registration and the use of the new system, which allows Members to register spontaneous speeches and blue cards electronically. I would therefore ask you to always bring your voting card. If you want to register an impromptu speech, you can do so now. You do not have to wait until the end of the debate.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: President of the European Court of Auditors. Madam President, honourable Members, representatives of the Presidency, Commissioner Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I am very pleased to be here with you today, together with my esteemed colleague Lazaros Lazarou, the rapporteur for the annual report of the European Court of Auditors, in order to launch this year's discharge procedure of the European Court of Auditors with the annual report for the financial year 2018.  What am I talking about this afternoon? My aim is to present to you the current state of financial management of the European Union. In our annual report, and in particular with our statement of assurance, we assess whether the money you, as a Parliament, approved for the budget last year, has been used lawfully, properly and, of course, economically. We have audited the consolidated accounts of the European Union for the financial year 2018. In our opinion, it presents the financial position of the European Union as a whole in a proper way and does not have any material misrepresentation – in other words, we have delivered an unqualified opinion.  Secondly, we have not found a significant error rate for the revenue that has flowed into the EU budget. Thirdly, we have estimated the error rate in expenditure at 2.6%. This means that, in our opinion, 2.6% of payments should not have been made at the expense of the European budget because they were not made in accordance with current EU legislation. However, this overall estimate obscures an important distinction: the disbursement mode of European funds has a major impact on the risk of errors. In the case of expenditure that is subject to complex rules and which account for around half of the EU budget, i.e. primarily the so-called 'refund-based payments', where beneficiaries have to submit applications for reimbursement of the eligible costs incurred – for example, research projects, employment-related projects, regional and rural development projects and development projects in third countries – the error rate is estimated at 4.5%.  On the other hand, the risk of error is lower in the case of so-called 'claim-based payments', which are subject to simpler rules and where beneficiaries receive a payment if they simply meet certain conditions – think, for example, direct aid to farmers, administrative expenditure, student grants or EU budgetary assistance to third countries. In other words, around 50% of the Court's population we have examined does not have a significant error rate. For this reason, for the third year in a row, we issued a limited opinion on expenditure, that is, a 'yes, but'. We see it as an encouraging sign that the European Commission and the Member States have been able to maintain the progress made in the previous two years. Our auditors were able to note positives in the areas associated with low risk. At the same time, there remain worrying problems in the high-risk areas, which need to be addressed further. As part of its own multiannual strategy, the Court of Auditors is gradually moving towards basing its Statement of Assurance on a test-based audit. This means that, in future, we want to provide audit certainty on the Commission's management statement, which in turn is based on our own reviews and, in the case of shared management, also on the reviews carried out at national level. We are therefore increasingly working with the Commission to create the necessary conditions for progress towards the test-oriented audit, and I would like to take this opportunity to thank Commissioner Oettinger and his staff for their support, and I look forward to further developing this cooperation with his successor. I am convinced that paths are created by taking them, that is, by taking concrete – perhaps initially modest – steps to achieve this reasonably aspirational objective of taking advantage of work already done by others, thereby also saving double the burden of examination. Honorable Members! A deeper insight into our conclusions and recommendations on the individual MFF headings can be found in the respective chapters of our annual report, which is available in all eu official languages. Two weeks ago, in the Committee on Budgetary Control, I had the opportunity to draw a detailed attention to the individual chapters. to enter. Since many of you were present, I will not go into detail here. Dear ladies and gentlemen, Members of Parliament! However, I would like to make one point very clear once again: we are at a crossroads – a new parliamentary term, a Member State in the process of leaving the European Union and the other 27 Member States in the final stage of the negotiations on the multiannual financial framework for the period 2021-2027. Our audit work, which I have been able to present to you today, shows that, despite many problems that still exist, the European Union is consistently upholding high standards of accountability and transparency in the use of public funds for the third year in a row. We expect the future Commission and, of course, the Member States to continue and build on these efforts. And, of course, we are counting on you all to work with us to ensure that this will be the case. Thank you for your attention!

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, Mr Lehne, Mr Lazarou, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by thanking you, Mr Lehne, and you, Mr Lazarou, and the whole office, the whole Court for a valuable piece of work and for a fair cooperation that I have seen together with my team over the last three years. I do believe that together we have also made progress and have the opportunity to make further progress – we, operationally the Commission, in the control of the Committee on Budgetary Control, Parliament, the Council and, with technical support, the European Court of Auditors. We strive for high standards of transparency, we have a full duty of accountability, and it is about the money of our European citizens and taxpayers. I believe that the outgoing Juncker Commission leaves European finances in a very good state. Firstly, for the twelfth year in a row, the Court has judged the accounts to be flawless. Secondly, the error rate has fallen significantly in recent years. In 2018, it was around 2.6%, and just five years ago we had to register 4.7% as a margin of error. Thirdly, for the third time in a row, the European Court of Auditors has come to the conclusion that the sustained improvement in the financial management of the European budget has made it possible not to make a negative but a qualified judgment on the regularity of expenditure possible. Last but not least, we have jointly improved the reporting on the performance of the programmes and thus the significance of the european budget. The European budget plays an important role for millions of citizens, farmers, researchers, entrepreneurs, start-ups, start-ups and students. Three quarters of our expenditure is managed jointly with the Member States, and since we do not have a substructure, we need this cooperation and the proper assessment of European law by Member State authorities. These play a crucial role in areas such as cohesion policy and agricultural policy, where around 70% of the budget is still carried out today, for which we are grateful to and dependent on the national and regional tax authorities. The Commission has strict rules for good and effective management of funds. Even if the funds are spent far from Brussels or Strasbourg, we have a clear governance structure with clear responsibilities for all those involved. We also know that the impact of errors that occur – the error rate – is ultimately less, because we can ask the Member States and/or the recipients to repay amounts that have been wrongly received – which is also largely happening. That's why we always present two figures: the risk of errors at the time of payment and the risk after corrections have been made. For the taxpayer, the latest figure is the decisive one, which, according to our estimates, is only 0.8% last year. For what counts for the citizen is what has been misused in the end after all efforts and has not been reclaimed. Together, we have identified some problems with the management of cohesion programmes in some Member States over the past year. And so it can be said that here and only here in 2018 more mistakes were made than in the previous year. We will pursue this – together with Member States through our deliberations, by improving our regulatory framework, by simplifying, simplifying the next budgetary framework and by taking further action. However, it can be seen that in the sample carried out by the Court concerning the transactions, the majority of errors have now been detected and financial corrections have been made. I agree with the Court that complex rules contribute to errors, which is why we have simplified the rules, but we have also carried out training and communication measures to facilitate access to European funds for recipients. The proposals for the post-2020 budget framework provide for further simplifications, and I would ask the legislator, the House, to stick to this simplification of our rules in the coming weeks, particularly with regard to the implementing rules for the budgetary framework, and not to go too far up the complexity again. We will continue to work with our partners to address the root causes of identified errors. I come to the subject of performance: we have achieved a great deal in this regard in recent years. The performance framework for the European budget has been set up by the OECD, which has an excellent Overview of global budget management , ranked as the best of its kind. We have improved and simplified our reporting. We publish detailed information on the results of each European budget programme. We have made considerable efforts to ensure that the budget is not only properly spent, but that it also finances projects that concern EU-wide tasks and that make a difference for a large number of people. The Commission remains committed to optimising its performance reporting in line with its respective policy priorities. European added value plays a central role in the Commission's proposal for the next budgetary framework. Goals are formulated even more clearly, and performance is brought even more into focus. Our aim remains to provide you, as decision-makers and our citizens, with the best possible information on the results achieved with the European budget. Once again, I would like to thank President Lehne, Mr Lazarou and the whole team in the Court, but also thanks to Parliament and the Committees for Budgetary Control. I would also like to mention the former chairwoman, Mrs Gräßle. Otherwise, I would like to say to you that I find the work that is being done there very significant and relevant. Thank you very much for that. We look forward to further budgetary discharge. On detailed questions, my colleagues will be answering the hearings in November, and then the Budget Commissioner will be with you again in December – hopefully then my successor, no longer me.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr Lehne, Mr Lazarou, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, I would like to begin by thanking the Court of Auditors very, very warmly for the excellent cooperation and very, very good cooperation and also for the quality of the work that we can experience through you. A thank you to Commissioner Oettinger for not only taking up many, many suggestions, but also helping to implement them in a very concrete and active way. I believe that it is noted that the overall trend, as President Lehne says, is positive. We have several questions which will give us suggestions for the new MFF, which we have to take into account.  Firstly, if we find that refund-based payments have a much higher error rate, then this is simply due to the so-called gold plating, which makes things even more complicated in the Member States than is absolutely necessary, sets even more criteria, makes it even more complex. I would urge the Commission to discuss simplification with the Member States in the MFF, because if the so-called ineligible costs are a significant part of the problem, it is often because the complexity is too great and the Member States are unfortunately very often pushing it to the level of Brussels, even though it was not the Commission. , which invented these regulations.  Secondly, we know that we have Member States which also have problems and difficulties with the national authorities. It's not just about naming and shaming, because that doesn't help in the end. We will have to ensure how we need to strengthen the national authorities, firstly in the advisory function and, secondly, in the audit function, or also through technical assistance, to ensure that they are sustainable, that they carry out a good audit and that the application to the applicants is fair, correct, clear and transparent.

name: Tsvetelina PENKOVA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Dear Madam President, President Lehne, Commissioner Oettinger, thank you for your presentation and for the facts presented. Dear colleagues, I am pleased that the European Court of Auditors gives an unqualified opinion on the 2018 Accounts of the European Union. However, the increase in errors in the Convergence area, where the Court highlights inaccuracies in the expenditure declared, is alarming. We also doubt the data provided by some of the Directorates for Regional Policy and Employment. These conclusions are of concern and require a response from the Commission. Finally, I would like to welcome the pilot initiative of the Court of Auditors and the Commission aimed at strengthening cooperation between the Court and the Member States in audit processes. Thank you.

name: Olivier CHASTEL
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would really like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors, both for the presentation of his annual report, but also for the work done by all his services.  As I had the opportunity to say in committee, this presentation begins our discharge process. So we are at the beginning of our work and, in terms of budget efficiency, our mission, as we know, is not simple. We need to find a balance between a budget that is both ambitious and realistic. The European Union must not make promises that it cannot keep. While the Court's report is generally positive, I still note a number of points on which we need to pay particular attention. Moreover, these are problems that are not new: the review of the repayment rules, because they generate significant errors; The error rate in high-risk spending Low absorption rates in some countries; we just talked about it, over-regulation and the need for administrative simplification; the accuracy of the amount of own resources collected, particularly at the customs level, or the error rate in the European Development Funds. The Court also states that all European bodies must work to harmonize audit procedures and all audit practices. We therefore hope that initiatives will be taken, both by the Court and by the Commission, to align the procedures, the audit methods in order to simply guarantee the reliability of the data.  At the other end of the day, the impact and effectiveness of policies must be strengthened through effective budgetary controls and audits. As you know, calculating the impact of performance is a priority of my political group and, as such, I encourage the Court to carry out more performance audits to ensure that policies and programmes are effectively implemented.

name: Viola VON CRAMON-TAUBADEL
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would also like to thank everybody for their cooperation in terms of the last report. We are looking at the spending figures for the 2018 financial year. However, we need to make sure that our budget is sustainable.  The payment backlog not only shows what we did in 2018, but it is also a good indication of what to expect in the future. The outstanding commitments have constantly been growing in the past years and in 2018 we reached a record high number with EUR 281 billion. The projections show that it will grow even further in the coming years. The high number is not just a number in our accounting system. This bears a political significance. We need to make sure that the payment appropriations will be available to cover all amounts due in the first years of the new MFF. Otherwise, it will endanger the new MFF programmes. The difference between Member States is enormous. The risk, especially in the eastern and central Member States, suggests that there might be a structural problem as well. We need to take steps to reduce the amount of the backlogs and help faster absorption, especially for the Member States lagging behind, in order to secure an EU budget which is sustainable, not just in the short term but also in the medium and long term. The way to speed up the absorption of funds is simplification and you have talked about this. We have to avoid high pressure on the new MFF.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for If the European Court of Auditors did not exist, it would have to be invented. Your work, Mr Lehne, is extremely important to all of us, and we appreciate that very much. However, much remains to be done. The 2018 report clearly shows this. I would like to quote a word from the wise preacher Solomon. He says in Kohelet 10: "Dead flies make the oil of the ointment mixer stinking and fermenting." They are in the process of looking for and fishing out these dead flies. In this task, I wish you continued success, good success. Don't have bite inhibition, but bite if you notice that you're encountering problems. Their work is urgently needed.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Mr President of the Court, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Sch This is an important debate, a thank you to the Court of Auditors, which plays a very important role – and these are not compliments, but a statement of fact – and is very necessary. In 2018, EU spending totalled almost EUR 157 billion. This amount represents 1% of the Union's gross national income and corresponds to approximately 2% of the total public expenditure of the Member States of the Union. It is essential that the spending of these funds is not only in line with the rules, because it is clear, but at the same time delivers the intended results. For expenditure for the financial year 2018, the Court delivers a qualified opinion, as the estimated level of errors in budget expenditure was 2.6%. This, of course, falls within this range of estimated error levels over the past two years. Only a year earlier this error rate was 2.4%. My question is: is this level just starting to rise when it's 0.2% higher, or is it a cosmetic, statistical issue, and it's not a problem? Maybe it will be a problem in the future. I think here we can be pleased when it comes to entitlement-based payments. My time is running out, so I would just like to thank the Commissioner and the President of the Court for their good cooperation with our Committee on Budgetary Control.

name: Michael HEAVER
text: – Madam President, the latest European Court of Auditors’ report shows the level of irregularities in EU budget spending rose in 2018: EUR 4.1 billion of the budget was misspent – but it’s worse than that. On page 168 you state that the transactions from the EU Commission’s climate department, which manages a budget of EUR 864 million, were not audited because we did not sample any transactions in the area of climate action in 2018. We have no audit results. On page 189, under the Global Europe Budget heading, where EUR 9.5 billion of taxpayers’ money was spent in over 150 countries across the world, you say the number of transactions audited was not sufficient to estimate the level of error. Let me make one thing absolutely clear: I do not want my country paying another penny piece into the European Union’s coffers. Hard-line remainer cowards in my country are currently running scared of an election. Well they can run, but they can’t hide for much longer. A day of reckoning is coming in my country in the form of a general election. In that election the choice will be clear: sign up to a European treaty where we hand over billions for years to come in a transition that will go years into the 2020s, or take back control with a clean-break Brexit. The Brexit Party won the European elections in my country. That’s why we’re here, and we’re going to make our presence felt in the general election to come.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, I thought the Monty Python circus was over, that they had already announced their end, but my colleague Heaver here constantly convinces me that Monty Python continues to perform and he and his crew are constantly embodying the roles of Monty Python here and continuing to do so.  I don't know, Partner Heaver, you must have had a reading problem. You didn't read the report. We enjoy your data here again and watch everyone laugh at you. 'Cause you're back together with pears and apples. I'm not keeping you here. Really, if you want Brexit, there's the door and go. After all, we're just waiting for Britain to tell us specifically when it's going to leave. And go. Really. No one's keeping you here.  And the report. Yes, the report itself is such a kick-off of audits in the European Union. It is actually a dig at the fact that there has been work on audits concerning the European institutions. And this audit shows that there are still a number of things we can improve. In particular, in these special reports, we must focus on greater efficiency in how this money is used and how these reports are then presented inside the European Union and what is precisely the particular output with which we will work.  And I think that this report is a good basis for discussion with the European Commission. A lot has changed in the five years I have been an MEP. And I am glad that the next Commissioner, Commissioner Hahn, will continue this effort for change. Thank you and I look forward to the blue cards.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the Blue Card (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: blue-card question. – First of all I would just like to congratulate the fellow MEP. He has a lot of support in the Chamber, which is always good to see. The question I have for the honourable Member is the following. You used the analogy of Monty Python, and I think it’s a very good analogy. In ‘The Life of Brian’, I think it was Mr Creosote who devoured as much food as he possibly could in an orgy of largesse. In many ways it’s a very good analogy between the budget of this place, which just devours more and more the wafers, the buffets. Do you agree that that’s the correct analogy?

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague, I would love to answer your question, but you are still recording me to use another analogy with British humour. I think what you're showing is that not only is Monty Python continuing, but that "Sure, Minister" continues, and your question is more or less the answer to what you want to hear.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Given the advanced time, we'll leave it at a blue card.

name: Isabel GARCÍA MUÑOZ
text: – Madam President, thank you to Commissioner Oettinger and thank you in particular to President Lehne for presenting the Annual Report to the European Parliament.  As shadow rapporteur of the S&D Group for the discharge of the other institutions, I would like to stress that in the Court's report I miss a greater dedication to their financial management: in the 2018 report we find some slight notes on the European Commission and Parliament, but that is all.  I know that the error rate in recent years has been very small, but I am convinced that more comprehensive attention can only mean that the operating expenses of the other institutions continue to be carried out more and more rigorously and effectively, and that it will also assist Parliament in its control work.  If the Court does this work for the 41 agencies, by dedicating an exclusive annual report to them, I am sure that it will also be able to find the economic and human means to make a report for the eight institutions of the Union.

name: Gilles BOYER
text: Madam President, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, thank you for your important work in controlling the expenditure of our European Union budget. As you point out in your report, this budget represents only 1% of the gross national income of the Member States of the Union, and more than 80% of its resources are made up of contributions from the Member States, in a logic which is purely redistributive and which is difficult for our fellow citizens to understand and which, as we have seen quite recently, is fuelled, including in this Chamber. , easy populism.  In the current political situation, many of us want more than ever that the European Union should have, as soon as possible, a budget that is up to its ambitions and is fuelled by the European Union's own resources, without additional taxation for households and individuals. Finally, we hope that the European Union will, of course, be able to develop its own projects of continental interest, and for that it must live up to the expectations of citizens that were expressed at the time of the elections. And in this renovated framework that we call for, your precious work, Mr President, would make more sense to help restore trust between the European institutions and the citizens.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, the National Gathering has always believed that asylum policy should remain a national competence. The European Court of Auditors has just agreed with it in its report published in 2019, denouncing the scandalous dysfunctions of the European Asylum Support Agency.  On pages 202 to 213 of its report, the Court of Auditors reveals that the agency has signed irregular contracts worth around 3.5 million euros. Even more seriously, in 2018 the agency launched a public contract of 50 million euros, the illegality of which was so blatant that it had to be put an end hastily. At the same time, and I quote the report, the human resources situation there has deteriorated exponentially, to the point where the Executive Director has had to resign. These findings are damning. They prove that the Court of Auditors is doing its job well, but also and above all, that the European Union is unfit to manage the asylum policy of European states.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors and the Commissioner for presenting an annual report of great value in understanding the accounts of the European Union. As both have said, in 2018 the error for expenditure as a whole was above the 2% threshold. Clearly, efforts to adjust this deviation must continue.  And with regard to the allocation of natural resources, and in particular to the CAP, we know that efforts are being made to simplify the task of administrations, but the truth and truth is that complexity continues to increase for the final recipient, who are but farmers.  The lack of simplification, the bureaucracy that continues to grow and the complex requirements that must be met in order to receive the aid condition the activity of our farmers, who have to devote more time to paperwork than to agricultural work. I hope that the Court of Auditors will continue to require more coordination with the Member States from the Commission.

name: Sabrina PIGNEDOLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the Court of Auditors for its work.  The annual report is indeed a document of great importance to the European Parliament, as it facilitates our work and provides many elements for assessing aspects of EU spending and identifying the problems to be solved.  The 2018 Annual Report noted some improvements compared to previous years: firstly, the fact that, in general, the estimated level of error for payments made is constantly decreasing, 2.6 %. This is a step in the right direction.  However, the Commission must continue to make efforts to increase transparency in the use of public funds and at the same time step up cooperation for the Court of Auditors. There are a number of critical points, for heading 3, which concerns security and citizenship, and for heading 4, which concerns Europe's global role. The error rate has not yet been detected.  This certainly leads to a serious lack of transparency and control of expenditure. In some areas, such as cohesion and rural development, but also in specific programmes such as Erasmus and Horizon 2020, error rates persist on issues that must both be addressed and resolved as soon as possible.  I therefore call for greater organisation in controls and an increase in performance audits, to see whether policies and programmes are being implemented effectively and, in order to ensure that citizens are properly spent, I hope that all measures to improve the situation to protect the credibility of the European Union and its institutions will be implemented.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Madam President, dear Commissioner, I have to say that I am surprised to see so much passion during the presentation of the Court of Auditors’ Annual Report. I didn’t expect that, but it’s nice to see. A lot has been said about the numbers, statistics and percentages in it, and rightly so. But I would like to talk about what stays behind the numbers and namely people, companies and their projects. It’s good that you’re searching for error rates. This is your job. You are the taxpayers’ best friend. But along with searching for errors in our project, we should consider what the quality of this project is. Did it reach the goal that it was designed for? Did it reach it in the correct way? So along with looking at how funds were spent, we should also look at how goals were reached.  And we have to consider that one of the reasons that in the fifth year of this programing period we absorbed only 30% is because of bureaucracy. So we need a risk-based control. Those beneficiaries who have a good track record and know how to use EU funds deserve less control. Those who constantly make errors need more control. This is the way that we can find a balanced solution to serve the taxpayers’ interest and to encourage beneficiaries to work even more with EU funds.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Court of Auditors' 2018 annual report presents us with an improving financial situation for the European Union compared with previous years, although we have said that there are still some areas where errors and fraud have a major impact on the budget, particularly in high-risk expenditure under the Cohesion Funds and in agricultural funding.  However, the Court itself has pointed out that the complexity of the rules on access to European funds leads to many errors. We therefore need less technical, more accessible discipline which will enable farmers, small entrepreneurs and researchers to use existing funds and not to make mistakes.  And then more needs to be done, from the point of view of prevention, if we consider, for example, that only 11 Member States have a formal anti-fraud programme. Therefore, the Commission should promote greater regulatory and operational homogeneity in the Union and urge States to adopt anti-fraud policies and to activate all available internal prevention and control strategies, precisely in order to better protect the Union budget.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Madam President, I thank the Court of Auditors for the excellent work it has been doing for many years. After examining the EU funds programmes, the Court notes that the performance indicators currently used in relation to the European Union budget do not always give the right picture of the progress actually made towards achieving european policy objectives. I consider the conclusions of the European Court of Auditors to be fundamental. The Aim of the European budget is not just to move money from one pocket to another. The aim is for every euro invested to bring back the greatest possible benefit in the form of better services for European citizens. A similar picture to that given to us by the European Court of Auditors is given by the OECD in its recent study, which shows that the European Union has the most information concerning the budget and its performance. This is the ranking of countries on this graph: the European Union is the first, but in terms of the use of this information, hard data, we are already at the end. It is very important that we get higher.

name: Brian MONTEITH
text: – Madam President, walking across the sitting room, I turned the television off. Yet another news story about EU largesse. But I say, in the spirit of tonight, always look on the bright side of life. We are leaving the EU. And my name is Brian. In the previous life of Brian, I was Chair of the Scottish Parliament Audit Committee for four years and this report’s figures do not fool me. The report shows a 2.6% error rate –EUR 4  billion. EUR  4 billion is more than what some Member States actually pay into the EU.  Let’s consider goals, like some examples of paying for flights for staff to Jamaica on a pollution budget. The funding of a radio drama series in Mozambique. There are areas where no audit happens. When funding is given to a country outside the EU, no audit takes place. When EU funding goes to multiple donor projects, compliance is assumed, not inspected. Many budgets, as my colleague pointed out, have insufficient transactions to be audited, meaning again that they are not included in the error count. Here’s an idea. It’s very simple. If you cannot audit it, don’t spend it. That’s the way to improve your budget audit.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: – Dear Madam President, dear Colleagues, The European Court of Auditors presents its annual report on the financial year closed each year, which begins the discharge procedure, at the regular and efficient management of the European Union and at Parliament's plenary session each year. This is the 11th time I've been involved in a closing procedure. Every year I was responsible for different reports. On the basis of my experience, I must say that the European Court of Auditors has done an outstanding job. Cooperation with the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control is excellent. The regularity of the European Union's financial management is improving. 2018 is the third year in which the Court has given a limited opinion on expenditure for the financial year rather than a negative opinion. The estimated level of error in their expenditure was 2.6 percent in 2018, with a significant increase in the level of member states' payment requests for the European Structural and Investment Funds. Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. I'm so sorry. I'm going to deviate from the agenda for a thought. As head of the Hungarian delegation of the European People's Party, I can speak on 23 October. October 23rd is a celebration of the Hungarian Revolution and The War of Independence of 1956. It is a celebration of the elemental sense of justice and freedom of the Hungarian people, the Hungarian nation. We bow our heads to heroes. And we are the heirs to this sense of justice, a desire for freedom. Thank you for your attention.

name: Lara WOLTERS
text: Mr President, we have talked so much about one country and one particular issue in recent months that you would almost forget that there are 27 other countries in the EU, which will soon have to have a budget for the next seven years. This budget offers an opportunity, not only for a more social and greener Europe, but also to deal with a few persistent bottlenecks. The european court's report clearly shows the latter. Of course, the EUR 280 billion in unclaimed funds are of course problematic. Some countries seem to be unable to come up with approved projects. These are often the countries that can use European funds so well for their economic development. That is why it is time to make the budget more sensible, so that money can be put into good projects with European added value more easily. Investment in European railways is an example of this. In summary, let's work on "project seeks money" over the next seven years instead of "money looking for project".

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her To your British colleagues first of all, with this controversy, you will also drive the United Kingdom apart.  Thank you to the Court and the Commission for the work on budgetary control. 2.6% sounds good, and some things have improved, but the budgetary sector, where Europe is showing its face in the regions – structural policy – has deteriorated massively. 5% after 3% last year is a very bad signal for the taxpayer.  I really must ask myself whether the Commission, and the Court, is also sufficiently complying with our demands for transparency. For years, we have been calling for countries to be named – to name, to publish – where things are going wrong. For years, we have been calling for country reports from the Court which clearly show the deficits of the black sheep. Yes, there is a naming and shaming in beginnings. Yes, much is linked to bureaucracy in the countries as well, and yes, we too have a responsibility if we allow funds to be called up much later. N+, these rules, which are unsettling, which ultimately leads to a backlog of subsidies and finally to hasty funding actions. But the Commission and the Court are squeezing themselves into the responsibility of intervening. They hide behind samples and interpretable statistics. We all hide behind shared management and avoid taking responsibility for ourselves. We could, however, together contribute to the improvement here. Just blame us if you need to be more transparent – in the Member States and also in the financing of NGOs. We will insist on this in the next few years.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Madam President of the Court of Auditors, I want to start by appreciating the report you have presented, the 2018 report, being comprehensive and reflecting the complex and important work, because those thousands of audit days that you have done with your team on the ground, either in the Member States, in third countries or in the European institutions , behold, they have paid off, and we have this involution of corrections.  What I want to tell you, however, is that you, as the Court of Auditors, should implement a strategy and certainly advise a strategy that goes more on prevention because I know, of course it may be somehow justified for an institution to find an error, but I think it is better for everyone to prevent. I think that's the philosophy.  Secondly, I want to appreciate the fact that you have done the 41 audit reports from the agencies much more explicit and much more understandable, and then you have a record of the published documents — which is very good — and I congratulate you on that. As rapporteur for the discharge of management for Parliament I will use your reports.

name: David LEGA
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is, of course, gratifying that the mispayments of EU funds have been reduced, but that is not enough. In some areas of the budget, there is no light at the end of the tunnel and, unfortunately, it is in precisely those areas that I believe should have had reduced appropriations. It is problematic that the cohesion policy budget not only swells, but that the money is also being spent on other things, wasted on other things than what it was intended for. In 2018, as much as 5% – that is almost EUR 3 billion – of the total budget of cohesion policy was paid out to activities that were not eligible.  The waste is blamed, among other things, on complex EU legislation. Yes, EUROPEAN bureaucracy is undoubtedly complicated, but I cannot understand, and I cannot accept, why the EUROPEAN apparatus itself is unable to comply with its own regulations. The annual report shows that several eu institutions and bodies have failed in both recruitment processes and procurement. That is totally unacceptable.  The processes need to be simplified and they need to be clarified. I am saddened when a great amount of EU money is spent completely wrongly. Money cannot continue to be sent to bragging projects in rich regions or to projects that are not even eligible. Europe's citizens deserve better. They deserve us to spend their money in the very best way, and we do not do that today.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
