text: – Madam President, I want to thank you for the report that has been presented, which I think gives a true picture, and it is useful information for our work.  In any case, what is going on with our debate is the question of error rate and, in my opinion, it is a continuous vessel with that simplification. Sometimes the error rate decreases, sometimes it rises. I, when I saw from a farmer, when he showed me the requirements that go to administration in greening, for example, is a stack of documents that a regular farmer has to fill out.  I think we really should focus on simplification. I see that both unpaid payments and error rate in the regional fund are increasing, this is certainly not good news. I think that what the Court should focus on unequivocally is an audit of the performance of individual policies and, of course, the money used. That is what I think we are missing, we should also focus more on these audits, they will certainly take us further.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Madam President, we appreciate this consistent effort by the Court of Auditors and, to be honest, I see big changes in what the evaluation of the European institutions means. Obviously some things are correctable and I can say today that only divine laws are perfect.  On the other hand, I ask you to insist on prevention work, because many procedures can be simplified and I would not necessarily want to see culprits and thieves in places where there are errors because we may not have properly directed certain activities, especially on agricultural activities, where things can be simplified.  Maybe we're coming up with some standard operating schemes so that those involved in such activities don't make mistakes. Thank you and I am convinced that, as we lean more closely on the work of these institutions, we will make things change for the better throughout the European Union.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Simplification – yes, that is true: we must do everything possible to ensure that, for a support programme, a budget programme, the rules on how to apply for funds, how to carry out projects and then document and settle them are as simple as possible, because the cost is a cost within the European administration, with Member States and their authorities, with citizens, with universities, with companies, with NGOs. What is clear, on the other hand, is that some requirements for application forms, bureaucracy and billing have to do with the fact that corruption, fraud, infidelity and mistakes can be partly avoided. If you make it easy, abuse is easier. A second request: we can demonstrate that in recent years and decades, complexity has arisen mostly in the Council, but also in Parliament – even more rules, even more expectations of documentation. That is why, with the post-2020 budget framework, there is now a chance that we will bring simplification to the fore, as many speakers have requested, and that everyone will withdraw to the Council and Parliament when it comes to more complex derogations, documentation rules and more.  In my political years, I have seen budget implementation and accounting control at regional, local and national level. I can really assure you that the quality of documentation and accounting, the avoidance of errors, the recovery of funds is at least as good at European level as at all levels in the Member State from which I come and where I am well versed at town hall level, district office level, state government level and national level. We have no reason here to talk our work worse than it is compared to the work of others. Making mistakes is human. It is important that you do not make a mistake twice, that you uncover and correct a mistake, and that for others – best practice – you learn from mistakes and advise others so that the mistake that has been made here does not find itself permanently or repeat itself.  We must then see and, as the Commission, try to ensure that the error rate – the issue of 2.6%, 2.4% a year ago – remains at this low level or even falls even further, but an increase of 0.2% is more about randomness than a trend that will start with it.  I see a number of speeches, but the speakers are no longer. Let me tell you frankly, perhaps this is my last opportunity: I have always experienced it painfully and I do not know from any other Parliament that the Commission or the Court of Auditors is being critically addressed, that questions are being asked, and those who ask the questions: angry, they are out! I don't know where, maybe with beer, wine or coffee? Perhaps also in the study room, but it is actually a requirement of collegiality and courtesy that in a democratic debate you should also hear what you want to hear directly in the room where the question was asked. I am not saying this so much to this cluster of polemics at the back right, but I say it to Mr Lega: very critical, comprehensible and no longer there. I would have liked to have told him, so I do not give the answer. Mr Pieper, we are happy to look at the issue of full transparency and then the presentation of where mistakes are the main focus. With our transparency, we fully comply with the rules of the Financial Regulation, which you have adopted. No more and no less. Whether we want more and whether this is backed up by a Financial Regulation can be seen. When it is mistakes, we are not as transparent as we are about fraud, corruption and infidelity. There, we are also pillorying countries, companies or citizens when it comes to criminal issues.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: President of the European Court of Auditors. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had on the work of the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work First of all, I would like to thank Mrs Hohlmeier as the new chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Control. In any case, we look forward to working with you and your committee in the new parliamentary term. I think you raised the central point; this has also been mentioned repeatedly in the debate by other Members of the European Parliament: the more complex the rules, the higher the likelihood of errors. That is actually, in very few sentences, the basis of the whole problem. And now I say something to yours, but also to my address, because I have been sitting on the other side for 22 years: of course, this is often the fault of the legislator. Legislators tend to make more and more detailed regulations for a simple reason: because they do not trust the administration. So he's trying to sort out individual cases, to sort out more and more details. This applies to all parts of the legislator, and the consequence is that, in the end, the rules become so complicated that mistakes happen. Perhaps – that is the realisation, if you have sat on the other side of the problem for a few years and see what the administrative problems look like – it is sometimes better to have more confidence in those in the administration, whether on the European side or at Member State level, that they have simpler and clear rules that can perhaps be interpreted here or there. , will nevertheless be able to make appropriate decisions. I think that is the crucial point on which we should also try to improve the basics, and then the error rate will also be reduced. Mrs Penkova, thank you very much also for your comments. You raised the issue of pilot initiatives for the transition to the attesting test. That is a very important point. Since we have been doing this, we have also been examining the internal audit mechanisms of the Commission and the Member States. And this will give us new insights into how far they work, how far these deficits have, and then, in dialogue with the Commission and the other bodies audited, we can also make concrete proposals on how this can be improved and how it can also be used to create data that we can deal with afterwards, which we can use directly for our audit. The new approach is already showing considerable success. Mr Chastel made the point that the problems we are raising here are basically the same every year. That is absolutely right. The issue of complex bureaucratic regulation has already been raised. Perhaps I would like to comment on the problem raised by Mrs Grapini and Mr Chastel in the context of the concentration on not only compliance, i.e. the legality and computational accuracy of the implementation of the budget, but also on the question of performance, efficiency and cost-effectiveness: in recent years, the Court has examined the number of reports dealing with performance – i.e. efficiency and efficiency audits. , more than doubled. In other words, we have shifted the focus of our activities in this direction and we want to continue to do so more and more, because we do indeed believe that the citizen and you as a stakeholder are often more interested in whether the bridge or the terminal or the port that has been built with European funds is actually used. whether it is economically efficient than whether a tender ingescent might have been awarded to the wrong contractor because of some technical error. This is also important, of course, but the question of whether someone is actually using this infrastructure is at least as important and, in my opinion, even more important in my opinion. Mrs von Cramon-Taubadel and Ms Wolters raised the issues of sustainability. You will have already seen – and you will see this even more so when we adopt our new strategy, which will then apply to the Court from 2021 onwards : we will also deal intensively with the problem of sustainable development goals, i.e. the UN's SDGs. This will also play an increasingly important role in our audit work. You will hear from us even more about sustainability. Mr Kuhs, thank you very much for the kind and good words. I can assure you that the Court has no bite inhibition. As you can see, if you read the report, we will continue to give concrete examples of where things have gone wrong, because criticism is a prerequisite for it to get better. This is simply the very central experience that has been made over decades and which must be continued. That is what we are going to do. With regards what Mr Czarnecki, but also Mr Monteith and Mr Heaver and others have said, I would like to say this once again: we are using a statistical method. The Treaty obliges us to provide a statement of assurance on the implementation of the entire budget. No one is in a position to examine in detail the millions of transactions that the European Union makes in various sectors of its budget. So we do what is common according to international standards, which is what other audit institutions in the world, in Member States or in international organizations do: we take a relevant statistical set of operations that are randomly selected, and then examine these processes, and then examine these processes, and on the basis of the results we find – that is, the error we find – we calculate an estimated error rate. , and according to a very simple system: if you have a population of just under 1 000 transactions – in our case there were about 750 – that you have tested, then you can say with a 95% probability that under a certain curve in the middle is +0.8% the actual error rate. These are the international standards by which we are guided. Of course, we can be more precise, of course, in theory, instead of the whole budget, much, much more details can be provided on individual aspects of the budget. But if we do that, we need far more resources – far more resources! We currently use almost half of our resources for these transaction audits as part of the annual report. And if we want to be more precise, it means that – yes, that too is mathematics, statistical mathematics – we need four times the amount of resources for double accuracy. Let me put it very simply: at the moment, the Farm has almost 1 000 employees. If you give us 4 000 staff – you as the budgetary authority – then we will also be able to check twice as closely and provide you with twice as much data and accurate information. That is the crucial question facing the budgetary legislator. But within the resources we have today, we are simply limited, and we can only do what we have done. In order to use resources sensibly, we naturally make a risk assessment. In other words, we are looking more closely at this and making concrete statements where we know that the risks are higher. Where the risks are low over the decades of the audit period, such as in the area of administration or administration, where we always have very low error rates, we naturally do less accordingly. This means that we try to use our resources economically in order to achieve the best possible result for you. That actually answers the question asked by Mrs Garcia Muoz about the statistical method. Mr Boyer raised the issue of the use of resources and quantity. We have presented specific opinions on the various MFF proposals. You can read them all, and you can also read our views on the MFF. Mr Novakov raised the issue of performance. I do not want to say anything more about this now. As I said, we have shifted our focus. Mr Jurzyca cited the OECD's decision or publication. In fact, we believe that today, within the European Union, we have a very, very high standard of administration and implementation of the budget. We have a high standard. There are still areas where improvements need to be made. We have said that, there is no question about that, and you can find it all in the report. But if you look at this in an international comparison – we know, for example, what the figures at the Government Accountability Office in the US are – then we are in a good position, then we are really in a good position overall. But you also have to know where we actually come from. When the Commission was forced to resign from Jacques Santer in 1999, the Court of Auditors naturally also produced annual reports and issued negative opinions on the implementation of the budget in these annual reports. At that time in the 1990s, we did not publish the data on the individual household sectors, some of which were in the range of double-digit percentages. And if we compare the situation at that time, when there were no functioning internal audit systems with the efficiency that we have today, with the situation today, then we have made considerable progress. And I would like to say this: also thanks to your House, because, of course, the European Parliament after 1999 has made a number of important changes to the The Financial Regulation and, through constant pressure, which has also come from the Committee on Budgetary Control, has helped to ensure that these things have changed accordingly and have improved. So I think there is considerable progress. And then perhaps a comment on Mr Pieper. This is basically exactly the same as I said earlier, only in another form: of course, we could theoretically provide data on countries. But then I need other resources. If I do 750 or 800 transactions as part of the audit of the annual report on the entire budget, i may only have 16 transactions for some countries, which I examine. This is statistically completely irrelevant. In other words, it is like an opinion poll: if you poll 1,000 people, you get a reasonable result in terms of the likely outcome of party preferences – that is clear. But if you only ask 16, you can throw away the result. And that's exactly how it is here. What we did in response to Parliament's request was that every seven years – we did this for the first time after 2014 – we published all the data that we had collected in previous years, but with a clear disclaimer that these figures are statistically irrelevant and that they have no relevant value in terms of any statement or assessment of the situation in the Member States. That is where we are, and this state of affairs will not change. That is why I am telling you the same thing that I said in Ecofin the day before last week, because the Wishes of the Council always come from: more here, more there, more detailed information on this or that sector. With the resources we have, we cannot. We can demand this as many times as we want, we simply will not be able to do it unless our resources become different. But the question still arises: does this make economic sense to use more resources in all these different sectors of the budget in this case? This is a decision that the legislator will have to take again. In other words, the answer to this question lies with you and not with us.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I have taken an interest in the Court of Auditors' 2018 annual report, and in particular the cohesion policy section. We assessed the level of errors in the Cohesion heading as important, which is worrying news on the one hand and forcing reflection on the other. The most errors were due to ineligible costs and non-compliance with public procurement rules. The Court is very right to point out that simplification would help to prevent these irregularities and that errors could be avoided if Member States' authorities set less complex national eligibility conditions. I fully agree with the Court's opinion on this and believe that everything must be done to implement this recommendation. In addition, the Court notes that, in view of the projected repayment commitments for 2021 of EUR 63.7 billion, payment appropriations may not be sufficient. We must therefore do everything we can to ensure a level of resources to cover all commitments.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the debate on: - the oral question to the Council by Juan Fernando López Aguilar, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, (O-000024/2019 - B9-0052/2019) (2019/2755(RSP)), - oral question to the Commission by Juan Fernando López Aguilar on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, (O-000025/2019 - B9-0053/2019) (2019/2755(RSP)). Before starting the debate, I would like to inform you that, in order to apply for the blue card question procedure, you can both register as before and use the new electronic registration system. Therefore, please always have a ballot paper with you. If you would like to register for the house question procedure, please do so now and not wait for the end of the debate.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: author. – Madam President, I am humbled and honoured to present this draft motion for a resolution on such a sensitive issue: search and rescue in the Mediterranean. I mean it. Search and rescue of human lives in the Mediterranean against the unbearable death toll in the Mediterranean that we have mourned so many times throughout the debates of this plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg. I’ll make some remarks in English, according to the documents that have been widely circulated throughout the debate within the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and then I’ll move into Spanish to make some final statements. Presenting the case is just recalling the importance of the historic record of the resolutions of this European Parliament, quite a number of them. Every time there has been a tragedy in the Mediterranean – 1000 dead human lives in the Mediterranean only this year – we have mourned them on a regular basis, almost ritually. It is not the case that we ritually deplore this tragedy. It is about time that we bring about change and call on the Commission and the Council for real action on the matter. This is the aim of this concise resolution that has tried its best to encompass all of the component elements of the rationale behind the different political groups in this House which are willing to spread the message – to reach out to the European citizens – that we actually do care about the necessity to stop this death toll and this tragedy. So many lives are lost because they don’t have a regular pathway to make it to Europe. That is why they expose themselves to trafficking in human beings and the most unbearable violations of human rights on the other side of the Mediterranean coast, namely, Libya. So we not only make the case for the necessity of enhancing legal pathways, namely humanitarian corridors, but also to call Libya by its name: no safe place, no safe port for disembarkation. We care about enhancing the capacity to respond of the actual agency, which is Frontex in cooperation with some Member States and also in cooperation with the Libyan coastguard, but we know that people trying to flee from Libya are subject to the Libyan authorities, which deem it to be a criminal offence against the Libyan legal order to try to flee from Libyan territory irregularly when they are not given the chance to make it regularly. That means, in practical terms, that those who are sent back to Libya are subject to the most inhumane violations of their most basic rights. We should not turn a blind eye to that situation. There is also a very important legal point that has been present on a regular basis in the ongoing discussions and that is the need to stop the criminalisation of NGOs trying to save lives in the Mediterranean and trying to cooperate in the operation of saving lives. Of course we pay respect to the efforts that have been deployed by public authorities, namely, Italy and Spain. They have invested massive public resources, as have the rest of the southern bordering countries of the European Union: Malta and Greece. They spend their own resources to save lives in the Mediterranean, but they have to do it under a European framework, which makes sense at a European level and which is consistent with European law. By European law I also mean international humanitarian law, which is at stake because international humanitarian principles are part of European law, according to the Lisbon Treaty, which entered into force in 2009, 10 years ago now, along with the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which enshrines in Article 18 the right to seek asylum. It is 20 years since Tampere, which launched the call for a European space of liberty, justice and security which makes sure that the response towards asylum seekers is a European response, consistent with European values and Europe’s foundations, and this means fairly shared responsibility towards the issue, as in the mandate of Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. All these component elements are in place. What we call on the Commission to do is to do its best with the Council in this new mandate for a fresh start to unblock the asylum package as a whole, to make sure that the Facilitation Directive is reviewed, to stop the criminalisation of NGOs, to open ports for safe disembarkation for those vessels which have saved lives in the sea, according to international humanitarian law, because the Convention on the Law of the Sea, which was codified in Jamaica in 1982, and the conventions on rescue and safety in the seas adopted in the 70s in the last century are still binding on all Member States, as they are binding for the European Union itself. So there has to be a European framework for response which really does make sense. Finalmente, quiero simplemente señalar la necesidad de que el Parlamento Europeo, en la votación que se celebrará mañana jueves, muestre la misma voluntad de marcar su mensaje propio ante el Consejo y la Comisión que mostró en resoluciones anteriores, notablemente en la Resolución que adoptó el concepto de «holistic approach», una visión comprensiva ante la migración y el asilo que lleva la firma de sus ponentes en aquel momento: la señora Metsola, del Partido Popular, y la señora Kyenge, del Grupo Socialista. En aquella Resolución importante se lanzó un mensaje humanitario y de compromiso de cambio. Queda todavía pendiente, como quedó pendiente el mandato que adoptó este Parlamento en la legislatura anterior de acabar con la criminalización de las ONG, modificando la «Facilitation Directive».  Este es el mensaje que quería compartir y agradeceré el voto de todos los grupos parlamentarios que estén dispuestos a renovar ese mensaje ante la Comisión y el Consejo en su nuevo mandato.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me start by saying that the migratory situation in the Mediterranean remains of concern. However, we should also note that it has improved significantly over the past years. According to Frontex, in 2018 around 137 000 irregular migrants crossed the Mediterranean Sea on one of the three main routes. This year so far, we have had 105 000 arrivals, which is 20% down from last year.  Equally important is that, although any death is one too many, the number of deaths at sea in 2019 has dropped by 44% since 2018, a figure which can be attributed to the decrease in departures and increased search and rescue activities and capabilities of the Libyan Coast Guard. By the beginning of October this year, 688 people were known to have lost their lives while attempting to cross the sea via this route. This is obviously a tragedy, even if there is some progress.  The United Nations Refugee Agency estimates that in 2018 the Libyan Coast Guard rescued or intercepted nearly 15 000 migrants at sea. Even though the security situation in Libya has worsened in 2019, the Coast Guard has continued operating, rescuing 7 100 people at sea. These numbers reflect the important contribution of the EU to act and reduce fatalities at sea. In Libya in particular, assistance has been of paramount importance owing to the lack of resources of the Libyan State to provide for migrants. EUR 91.3 million were granted to support the Libyan Coast Guard and to support the development of Libya’s own Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre. Operation Sophia has provided training for a total of 355 coastguard personnel so far, and the European Asylum Support Office has provided training on access to the asylum procedure.  Despite three EU joint operations in the Mediterranean Sea having saved more than 478 100 lives since the beginning of operations, and assistance to improve migrant conditions on land in North African countries, there is no denying that the overall situation regarding search and rescue operations is unsatisfactory. There is a lack of responsibility-sharing under the International Law of the Sea and we need a greater predictability of search and rescue operations. We need to strengthen cooperation and coordination on search and rescue with our North African partners.  This is not an EU responsibility alone. International Maritime Law applies to all States, and coastal States have specific responsibilities. In order to enable our partners to carry out these responsibilities, we offer additional support for the North African States – including Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt and Algeria – in migration management, including carrying out search and rescue activities and disembarkation under international law.  As you know, Italy’s migration and asylum policy has recently changed, with Italy now again permitting NGO vessels to dock in its ports. Italy also intends to revise its policies regarding the seizure of NGO boats and on fines for ships bringing migrants to Italy without permission. To address the ad hoc handling of the arrival of migrants via the Mediterranean, four Member States have been working since this summer on a common solution. On 23 September, a joint declaration setting out a mechanism which could replace the current approach with a more coordinated and efficient one was agreed by France, Germany, Italy and Malta.  Since then, a few other Member States have agreed to participate and others are invited to join. We need to see how this new approach works in practice. I am convinced that if the mechanism proves smooth and efficient this will be the best incentive for others to join. Those Member States which previously took part in voluntary relocations from Italy and Malta have started to look at the common practice which was already developed with the help of the Commission and the agencies, and are now discussing standard operating procedures. However, even if such a mechanism worked efficiently, it cannot itself be our ultimate aim. We need to find a long-term solution to these situations, but also to the whole of the common European Asylum System. In line with the invitation from the European Council in the new Strategic Agenda, we need a sustainable solution based on solidarity and fair sharing of responsibility.  Such a system has to work well, both in normal situations and in times of crisis. It needs to guarantee protection to the people in need, prevent secondary movements and be more effective in returning those who do not have the right to stay in the EU. During our Presidency term, we have tried to promote strategic and forward-looking discussions on the most pressing challenges. We are, together with the Member States, trying to look at the key issues at stake from a broader perspective and in a comprehensive way. We believe this could help us rebuild a climate of trust in the spirit of cooperation between Member States and, at the same time, feed into the new Commission’s programme. That being said, the continuation of the work on the legislative proposals will depend on the way the new Commission will reassess and reconsider the texts that are on the table.  Regarding the issue of criminalisation of organisations providing humanitarian assistance, the role of NGOs in search and rescue operations cannot be overlooked. As the Chair of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) stated in his question, and as the European Parliament reminds us in its resolution of July 2018, we need to recognise their role in saving lives at sea.  The EU Action Plan against migrant smuggling stresses the need to ensure that appropriate criminal sanctions are in place, while avoiding the risk of criminalisation of those who provide humanitarian assistance to migrants in distress. I understand the new Commission will take a close look at the facilitation framework and possibly come up with the requested guidelines for Member States to prevent humanitarian assistance from being criminalised. In addition, we need to further consolidate our efforts to tackle smuggling networks in a comprehensive way. This remains of key importance.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thanks to the progress achieved over the past four years to implement a comprehensive migration policy. I think there are significant developments which we can really comment on in a very positive way together. The migration situation across all roads has returned to pre-crisis levels, with arrivals since September 2019 around 90% lower than in September 2015. However, the situation is volatile and we must remain fully mobilised to anticipate any upcoming challenges.  While the number of lives lost in the Mediterranean has been falling, it’s still too high. Each life lost represents an individual tragedy that’s a stark reminder that we need to do more. I am therefore glad to have the opportunity to discuss today the important issue of search and rescue in the Mediterranean. Saving lives has always been a priority of the Commission. Since 2015, four EU operations have helped to rescue nearly 730 000 people at sea. Of these four operations, three – Themis, Poseidon and Indalo – coordinated by the European Border and Coast Guard, continue to be fully operational. As regards the fourth operation, Sophia, Member States agreed to its continuation only on the condition that the development of its naval assets be temporarily suspended, a solution which is far from optimal and not sustainable.  Our commitment to save lives doesn’t start when people are on the boats and at our borders. Our comprehensive strategy to prevent irregular migration flows also includes measures to assist migrants in third countries before they embark on a dangerous journey and to prevent the activities of smugglers.  When talking about search and rescue, one should not forget that this remains a merely national competence which our Member States exercise on the basis of the international law of the sea. The EU as such has no power to coordinate search and rescue activities, and for the same reason we also have no right or duty to indicate the ports of disembarkations. These talks lie within the remit of the national coordination authorities that are bound under international law by the duty to render assistance to persons or vessels in distress at sea.  This brings me to your question on the forms of facilitation which should not be criminalised. Let me reiterate one more time – no form of genuine assistance to migrants, be it those in distress at sea or those in a state of necessity on EU territory, should be criminalised under European Union law. But those involved in search and rescue operations must comply with relevant international rules. EU legislation on the facilitation of unauthorised entry, transit and residence does not require Member States to criminalise genuine assistance to migrants. On the contrary, it provides for the possibility to exempt this type of contact from criminalisation under national law.  That being said, the Commission’s evaluation of the EU’s legal framework, carried out in 2017, has acknowledged that there is a lack of clarity in the implementation of the humanitarian exemption clause in the Member States. As a result of this, the evaluation has recognised the need for Member States to have a dialogue with NGOs to facilitate cooperation, clarify context and address the concerns related to criminalisation. Also, the Commission has started to engage with civil society to gather more evidence and foster dialogue on the implementation of the existing rules. The last meeting between civil society and Commissioner services on this matter took place on 1 October this year. The results of the engagement and dialogue with civil society will feed into the reflection of the next Commission.  Despite all these limitations, the Commission is working tirelessly to find a solution to the distribution of people rescued at sea, in accordance with the principle of solidarity and the fair sharing of responsibility.  At the request of Member States, the Commission has played an active role in the relocation process following 15 disembarkation incidents. On these 15 occasions over 1 100 disembarked people were transferred to other Member States and to Norway. To date, around 750 people, of which the vast majority disembarked during the last two months, remain to be transferred, but pledges have already been given by Member States that they will do so. 15 Member States, namely Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Portugal, Romania, Slovenia, Bulgaria and Spain, as well as Norway, have participated in these exercises. I would like to underline that in each case this has been preceded by an active coordination role of the Commission at the highest level, with Member States willing to demonstrate solidarity through relocation. It is thanks to these efforts that we have managed to overcome difficulties encountered in deciding where a particular vessel should be disembarked.  The Commission has strongly encouraged Member States to agree on temporary arrangements following disembarkation. Therefore, we have welcomed the progress achieved at the end of September in Malta concerning a temporary solidarity mechanism between Germany, France, Italy and Malta. The Malta Joint Declaration was submitted for the consideration of all EU ministers at the recent Justice and Home Affairs Council and further discussions will continue at both the political and technical levels. To this end, a first technical meeting between those Member States taking part in relocation to discuss operational issues took place on 11 October, with the participation of certain Member States and Norway, as well as EU agencies. This is, for the beginning, I would say, a good sign. Work will continue on this basis. At the same time all these arrangements can only be an intermediary step towards a structural reform of the asylum and migration system. That is why work on the reform of the common European asylum system and of the Return Directive, but also on the implementation of all legislation adopted to strengthen the protection of our external borders, coupled with strong partnership with key third countries on each migratory route, needs to be pushed forward.

name: Lena DÜPONT
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work she has Saving people in distress at sea is our legal and humanitarian obligation. There is no doubt about that. That is why we have also, to the best of our knowledge and belief, taken part in the negotiations on the resolution.  What we do not want, however, is to create a model that plays into the hands of smugglers and traffickers, which also supports, rather than combats, this cynical business model. Because we have to be clear about one thing: causes of flight do not arise at sea, but on land. What we therefore need, therefore, is a maritime rescue procedure based on international law and EU law, to which all actors adhere. We need serious and intensified discussions with countries of origin and transit, both in terms of the prospects of staying for the people on the ground and about the common fight against organised crime. We need a clear distinction in asylum and migration policy between refugees and economic migration. We need humanitarian corridors to safe third countries for people fleeing war and violence. These countries deserve our support. None of this has been addressed in the resolution to the extent that we would have liked it to be. But we need all this to achieve our ultimate goal: to prevent people from embarking on these dangerous and, in the worst case, deadly escape routes. Only in this way can we save more lives.

name: Claude MORAES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the ongoing situation in the Mediterranean, where lives are lost and the European values that we speak about are being challenged every day, requires us to act. I think the chair of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) has had a very difficult task in trying to bring together Members of this House on this Resolution. But essentially, what he has done is to address both the Commission and the Member States on some key points, because it is quite concrete in the end: either we do something or we don’t. And we are doing this at the beginning of the new Commission, as the Commissioner said. So let’s be very clear: we can get around some of these things that would show our humanitarian effort and understand that we have some values here in the Mediterranean. We repeatedly called on the Commission to issue guidelines specifying which forms of facilitation should not be criminalised. In our Resolution, we call on the Commission to finally adopt those guidelines by the end of this year. I know the new Commission will only take office at the beginning of December, but the Asylum Package is frozen, as has been said. But there is a lot of work to be done to take this proactive approach. Operationally, we need more information and transparency on Frontex’s activities at sea, as well as on the funds and material support that are provided by the EU and its Member States to the border and coast guards in third countries, including Libya, Turkey, Egypt and Morocco. Fundamental rights, the principle of non-refoulement and the principle of disembarkation in a place of safety have to be respected. Finally, Member States should step up their moral and legal obligations to save lives at sea and adopt a proactive approach to search and rescue, making use of all available vessels, and to cooperate and support NGOs in their efforts. Essentially, the Resolution addresses, on the one hand, what the Commission can do and what the new Commission can do, and then the Member States, because for the Member States, this blame game, which is simply not demonstrating our values but passing around the blame, will continue to drain our resources, but ultimately it will require us to make difficult decisions: difficult decisions which ultimately will be the right moral decisions in the Mediterranean, but also sustainable decisions and proactive ones. This resolution should be supported. My Group is asking for the maximum amount of support to show that we have the European values that we want to demonstrate in the Mediterranean, and I hope it gains maximum support.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, I would like to start by saying every life matters. Every life matters. And when we’re talking about numbers of people drowning in the Mediterranean, we’re talking about individuals – people who came into the world one day, and their parents had hope for them. And those people are now dead at the bottom of the Mediterranean. They are people like you and I, so that is something we shouldn’t forget. The second thing I would like to remind us of is that this resolution is on search and rescue. This is not on adopting a comprehensive asylum package because that’s been blocked in the Council, as we all know. This House has done its homework. We are ready. But we cannot wait until the asylum package has been adopted. As there are people drowning, we simply have to make sure that there is sufficient capacity in the Mediterranean. And the point is that if the EU, if the Member States, are leaving a gap, then what we see is indeed that NGOs, or sometimes commercial vessels, fill in that gap. We shouldn’t be criminalising those people for saving lives. And then to say that ‘oh but these people are irregular, they’re labour migrants or asylum seekers’ – that’s irrelevant! First, you rescue them and then we argue over their status, Okay? There has to be a permanent sustainable solution. I’m personally no big fan of the solutions that don’t have their basis in the treaties, but I have to say, if the Malta agreement can be a first step in the direction of a permanent solution, then all the Member States should sign up. it is very disappointing that out of 28 there are only four who have done so, so far. That is shameful. The asylum package is blocked and they use that as a pretext for not saving people. But then when it is about saving people they’re also not there. That is shameful. And finally, I would really like to call on our friends of the EPP because I would like to recommend the good efforts that have been made by the shadow, Ms Düpont, but I also recognise that there are parts of the EPP who, despite very often referring to Christian values, actually don’t express their Christian values in some of the amendments. Sorry! When we’re talking about the camps in Libya – there’s a German ambassador who wrote to Ms Merkel referring to those camps as ‘concentration camps’. These camps have to be closed. People have to be evacuated. it is not negotiable. So I also hope for support from EPP quarters.

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Albert Schweitzer once said that humanity is not to sacrifice a human being for a purpose. Unfortunately, I believe that we are sacrificing people for a purpose if we do not finally manage to put an end to the mass extinction in the Mediterranean. It is up to us, with the resolution, but also with the new European Commission, to show that we can do more than keep saying that no one should die on the run. Yes, of course no one should die and, of course, no one should have to flee on unseaworthy boats. Unfortunately, however, we live in a reality in which thousands of people die every year on these boats at our external borders, people who were once the most important person in another person's life. We live in a Union that does not currently send a single rescue ship to the world's deadliest maritime rescue area. We live in a Union that has been banned by the supreme court from bringing people back to Libya, and what have we done? We are now paying Libyan militias to do exactly what we have been banned from doing. That is not European, it is actually shameful! What is needed at last is a European maritime rescue mission, and an end to the criminalisation of humanitarian aid. We expect Frontex aircraft to inform all the ships in the area in the event of sea rescues in order to save people, and we also expect that we will not help to bring people back into the civil war from which they have just fled. Let me conclude briefly in English. I think we can discuss details and we can tighten debate, but in the end I think we should all agree that our European way is to protect lives.

name: Annalisa TARDINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, you have proposed a resolution which represents the no plus ultra of the demagoguery of the left, in which you call for europe's doors to be opened to indiscriminate reception – so easy it is to be welcoming with the ports of others – and to allow NGOs to act freely in the Mediterranean, without control by the competent authorities. , and even considering their activity always excluded from the scope of the legislation on the aiding of irregular migration.  Well, for these reasons, not only did we vote against it, but we also tabled an alternative motion, this one aimed at protecting our borders and our citizens. The best way to save lives is to prevent departures and to act directly in Africa, strengthening cooperation with third countries, of origin and transit, in order to define long-term solutions, capable of addressing the causes of economic migration. To date, we have only heard of the Malta Agreement, which was first sold as a solution to all problems, now relegated to a mere pilot project, abandoned by the Member States, as we had planned. If these are the instruments by which the Von der Leyen Commission intends to manage migratory flows, I fear that it will be doomed to further failure. We have tabled amendments because we want the Member States to be able to continue to assess whether the rescue operations carried out by private vessels are an act of pure humanitarian assistance or of aiding crime. The Member States must be able to decide, on the basis of their own legislation, whether or not to allow NGO vessels to enter their ports and not to let the Carole on duty take up this right, even going so far as to challenge a minister. We want clear rules to discourage actions and initiatives that can become a further source of attraction for those who illegally want to reach Europe. Legal migration is welcome, but Europe must say 'no' to human traffickers and criminals hidden behind false goodies!

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will not support this motion because we do not want to be complicit in those who are planning to let the rule of law, reason and with it the lives of so many, too many migrants drown in the Mediterranean Sea, which will be handed over to human traffickers in the coming days.  Brothers of Italy and the ECR keep repeating to the point of exhaustion that there is only one way to prevent deaths at sea and is to prevent the departure of barges. On the basis of the data that all of you have at your disposal, we know that there is no alternative. We know that, and we keep saying here too, until we can no longer say that for us rescue at sea is right and proper when it comes to something impromptu, occasional and not organized, often in collusion with the smugglers, just as we know that there is no solidarity in welcoming thousands of people without being able to secure them a job , of possibilities, a free and dignified future.  That is why we think that this document is an extraordinary manifesto of socialist hypocrisy and that is why, like the ECR, we have also tabled an alternative motion. We wanted our thinking to remain in writing, and we did so.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, this year more than a thousand people have drowned in the mass grave where the Mediterranean Sea has become. When you have the capacity to save lives, doing so is no longer a matter of human rights, but of human dignity. And when institutions do nothing in the face of death, hindering or even criminalizing the activity of life-saving NGOs is becoming complicit. Because just as infamous is closing ports to rescue ships—as Salvini did—than threatening to fine them for not asking permission to rescue—as Pedro Sanchez wanted to do.  We'll tell them once and a thousand times: "Saving lives is not a crime." Europe has bought the xenophobic agenda from those gentlemen across the street. Institutional racism guides Community border policy today. We need legal and safe routes. We need a public European maritime rescue service. We need to end the policy of border outsourcing and human rights violations, making it clear that Libya is not a safe harbor. We call for the suspension of any agreement with the so-called "Libyan coast guard".  Ladies and gentlemen, do not devalue this proposal, which may be a small step in the right direction. There are no excuses: either with life, or accomplices of death. Choose tomorrow in the vote, ladies and gentlemen, choose.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the European Union, with its enormous responsibilities in syria's imperialist war, like its allies, is part of the problem of the growing refugee waves and not of its solution. The European Union-Turkey agreement, Dublin and all EU decisions condemn thousands of refugees and migrants to drowning in the Mediterranean, as was the case with the new tragic shipwreck near Kos, with a dead three-year-old child. At the same time, thousands of others are trapped in inhumane conditions, in miserable hot spots like Moria or Samos, which here and now must be closed. The policy of strengthening deportations, the militarization of borders, the repression are also reflected in the new asylum bill of the New Democracy government in Greece, which recycles and exacerbates the problems caused by the policy of the government of SYRIZA.  We condemn the change in the substance and concept of refugee asylum seekers, the targeted operation to shrink the already broken rights of refugees and migrants. Both are victims and creations of the capitalist exploitation of imperialist rivalries and wars. The situation requires their immediate transfer to mainland Greece to decent public accommodation structures, their transfer to their countries of actual destination and the safeguarding of all the rights of asylum seekers. The peoples can therefore now draw a conclusion and, in their fight against the European Union and NATO, oppose the imperialist war, put obstacles in the way of imperialist plans, isolate the poison of racism-nationalism.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I think we all agree on two things: firstly, it is our international duty, but above all humanitarian, to save lives, and secondly, trafficking in human beings is one of the worst violations of human rights and must therefore be combated by all means.  While we are discussing sea rescue, a humanitarian disaster has occurred in England: 39 bodies have been found in a lorry, presumably towed people. This is strikingly reminiscent of a drama in Austria in August 2015 on the A4 near Parndorf. Seventy-one people were found dead in a parked truck. Incidents such as these show us the brutality of the smugglers, how they exploit people's despair and, so to speak, – in quotation marks – accept the death of their customers, only to profit from it themselves.  We must not, therefore, play into the hands of the wrong person here, and we must be aware of the signals we are sending out. The completely unquestionable rescue in the Mediterranean must be separated from what happens after that, and as long as the rescue in the Mediterranean means the ticket to Europe, as long as people will go on rickety boats, in danger of being killed here. Let us therefore remain realistic and do what is necessary, namely cooperation with third countries, which we need to improve, establish safe places in third and transit countries and give the continent of Africa a future perspective.

name: Pietro BARTOLO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my colleague López Aguilar for his excellent work.  The resolution voted on Monday in the LIBE Committee is intended to send a clear message to the Commission and the Member States. We cannot go ahead with the policy of closed ports and put people's lives at risk at sea. We have a duty, first legal and then moral, to act. The ad hoc measures taken so far are not sufficient and adequate, and we saw this again last week with the latest shipwreck off Lampedusa. How many more people have to die for the Member States to decide to take responsibility? We need immediate, European and permanent responses. We need a sustainable and reliable approach to search and rescue at sea, as we call for with this proposal.  We call for guidelines that make it clear once and for all that those who offer genuine humanitarian assistance should not be criminalised. We cannot continue to point the finger at those who have saved lives for years, covering up the shameful selfishness of the Member States, the same ones who have tried to shift their responsibilities to countries such as Libya, where migrants become victims of all kinds of violence.  I hope that tomorrow this text proposing concrete and humane measures can be voted on by a large majority in this House. Voting against means being jointly responsible for the tragedies in the Mediterranean and beyond, and anyone who rinses his mouth by saying that with the measures taken and the ports closed or with agreements with Libya he has saved so many people and traffic has decreased by 80 %, he must explain to us what is the end of this 80%, what is happening in those lagers, in those concentration camps, say.

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. What is happening in the Mediterranean is and remains a humanitarian disaster. Sea rescue is a legal duty, but in my view it is also a human duty. We Europeans have a responsibility not to watch the deaths in the Mediterranean, but to act. I am therefore pleased that, in the vote on the budget this afternoon, there was a majority in favour of us setting aside our own resources for maritime rescue in the Mediterranean. This is a big step forward. It is also a good step for us to make progress in the distribution of rescued sea savers, but four countries are, of course, not enough, and I call on all the countries of the European Union to participate, to take in people who are rescued from distress until we have our own distribution mechanism at this point.  The best thing, of course, is if people don't get on the boats in the first place. That is why we must support the UNHCR in improving the situation in the camps. That is why we must create legal access routes to enable migration into the labour market, and we need to put in place more resettlement for the weakest of the weak, and the European states have a responsibility here to help these very people. I expect the Commission to make this a priority and to present us with proposals that are actually capable of winning a majority.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: – Madam President, at sea every minute counts. It’s hard to imagine that we would leave EU citizens in danger of drowning, floating in a rubber dinghy without any help. Yet this is what we do with migrants on a daily basis. But international maritime law obliges also the EU, as a party to the UNCLOS Treaty, to take responsibility for an adequate search and rescue. That requires sufficient capacity in the Mediterranean Sea, rapid coordination of the rescue, and disembarkation to a place of safety. As Libya is not safe, we cannot fund and organise their return to Tripoli without violating international law. What we should do instead is help migrants escape from this hell. This requires all Member States to take their responsibility and humanitarian assistance to be supported instead of criminalised. I urge the Commission to base its new arrangements on these principles, make it permanent, and make it swift. But please ensure saving lives and disembarkation in the meantime, as every minute counts.

name: Jean-Paul GARRAUD
text: Madam President, the resolution in debate proposes in fact to increase the migratory pressure on the Member States of the European Union in order to better welcome migrants and thus save them from drowning in the Mediterranean. According to the text, all EU ports should be opened and the work of NGOs should be further encouraged.  You propose to extend the aspiring pumps that cause the influx of millions of migrants, who often find themselves in the hands of so-called NGOs, accomplices of smugglers, by the very admission of the French Minister of the Interior. Blinded by a globalist ideology, you are actually amplifying, under the guise of generous ideas, an unprecedented migration crisis that Europe, in the long run, will not be able to bear. If you want to save lives, and we want to, the exact opposite should be done: to restore real borders to the boundaries of the Union and our nations; to hunt down smugglers and their accomplices, who send thousands of unfortunates to their deaths, to select genuine asylum seekers and to strengthen immigration regulations, and to encourage all initiatives and aid in the countries of origin, to avoid these dramatic migrations.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Madam President, again the European left brings to this Parliament the debate on the death of human beings in the Mediterranean. But again, he questions the wrong questions and the answers are therefore wrong. It does not tell us that in 2019 the number of deaths has dropped compared to 2018 perhaps because Europe's ports have been closed.  On Thursday we will vote on this motion for a Resolution on search and rescue, and my group presents a proposal for an alternative resolution based on scrupulous respect for national laws and decisions of member states, the relentless fight against human mafias and their necessary co-operators, and the strengthening of mechanisms for cooperation between States.  The right answers or the right questions would be: What measures should we take to end the called effect and eradicate that business model of human trafficking mafias and their trafficking NGOs? Why does the European left strive not to comply with the Facilitation Directive which gives the Member States the sovereign competence to decide who enters, under what conditions and who should be punished if it fails to comply with the conditions of entry?

name: Sira REGO
text: – Madam President, I repeat what my colleague said that preceded me. In 2019, more than a thousand people have lost their lives in the Mediterranean while trying to reach Europe. A thousand people. A thousand human beings. Deaths that are responsible: the racist policies of the European Union. Those who vote for some right here from their seats.  We make resolutions that condemn, but policies don't change. Instead of creating a civilian rescue and rescue corps and enabling humanitarian visas from areas where there are armed conflicts or climate emergencies, they remain committed to pushing the borders further away.  They are no longer good at funding Libyan militias involved in the slave trade, now a detention centre in Rwanda will also be opened. In the case of Spain, the governments of the Socialist Party and the People's Party have pioneered the implementation of border outsourcing policies in Morocco. A recent example of its consequences: the death of Ansou Keita following a beating by the Moroccan Auxiliary Forces in a raid. This is how the policies of this house end, with more death and more suffering. I end with a reminder: international law forces life to be saved. I hope that if they do not, they will be held accountable in court.

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: – Madam President, this resolution is based on a serious misconception. Its proponents claim that the aim is to save lives, but in fact its adoption would be sending the wrong message and would consequently result in even more tragic events. This is because in its current form it is a clear letter of invitation to millions of people in Africa. If we keep pretending that we are able and ready to welcome everybody into Europe, then even more people will depart and risk their lives. Instead, what we have to do is to help people where help is needed. We need a resolution that tackles the problem at its roots. We have to invest in border protection, further strengthen cooperation with third countries, and we have to effectively fight human smuggling networks for people not to leave their countries in the first place. The best way to avoid people drowning in the Mediterranean is to make every political effort so that the smugglers’ boats never leave the coast of Africa. It is also completely unreasonable to involve NGOs, with unclear backgrounds, in operations that can only be carried out by competent state and European authorities. It is completely unacceptable to worship and encourage NGOs to disregard rules and break laws. NGO ships must not be allowed to work as a transport service bringing illegal migrants into Europe. If we want to save people’s lives, we have to reinstate European border control and take help to third countries. The adoption of this resolution in its current form would be a great irresponsibility on our part. The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8).

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: blue-card question. – I have two questions for my colleague. Number one: are you sure you belong to EPP and not, rather, to ID? And number two: is what you have said in any way close to Christianity?

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: blue-card answer. – First of all, having debates on issues as important as this one, even within the political groups, is, I think, normal, and it’s a good thing to have these debates and to talk about these things openly.  Secondly, you mentioned Christianity. I tell you this: responsibility is part of Christianity, and I think that what Europe has been doing about migration has been totally irresponsible. It’s irresponsible to be sending messages to people in need, saying that anybody can come in without limits, let them in, and then tell them years later, ‘Sorry, you don’t have the right to stay now, go back.’ That’s irresponsible. The responsible approach and attitude is to be realistic and to take help to people in need where it is needed locally. That’s the local interest, and that’s Christian responsibility, I think.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank our President of the LIBE Commission for his work and the motion for a Resolution which he presents to us, which focuses on the urgent necessary measures we need to take to end the deaths in the Mediterranean.  Saving lives must be our priority. The agreement reached in Malta is a positive and necessary but still insufficient step. In the face of such a challenge we cannot go with patches. We must move from cooperation between some Member States to a true common European policy, starting with an emergency plan to save lives in the Mediterranean.  We must pay particular attention to women and children—many of them unaccompanied—who face a multitude of dangers and abuses along their journey.  Finally, not only do you die at sea: thousands of people survive in inhumane conditions in Libyan detention centres. Among them, there are more than a thousand unaccompanied minors.  We must act now. I therefore call on the Member States and the Union to endorse the evacuation plans of United Nations agencies and to open the humanitarian corridors.  And a personal note. I would like to remind this house that migrants and refugees are neither numbers nor statistics nor figures: they are people; that everyone has a life and a story behind them, ahead... And a son of migrants tells you.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Madam President, look, I am not very a member of demagoguery, and I also believe that we need great consensus in this Parliament to promote a policy of asylum, refuge, and also migration policies, in order to end the crisis we are experiencing in its management. However, human lives, from a point of view of the legal good to be protected, are somewhat superior to the persecution of mafias, for example, that traffic with human beings. Therefore, we would have to take that element into consideration. Right now, it's riskier to try to get past the Mediterranean than in the past. There are more people, the percentage of people drowned is higher. On the other hand, criminalizing NGOs is unfair. To play that, to play demagoguery with this issue, it has neither feet nor head with regard to what we have to try to solve, because the package is blocked in the Council. Secondly, today something very clear has been made in what the Council has said and what the Commission has said. They are blind to what is happening in Libya, and we cannot be complicit in very serious violations of fundamental rights. Whatever model we finally set, we can't allow that. Let's be very clear.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Every time a life is lost in the Mediterranean because of europe's unwillingness to act, I am filled with anger. The lack of humanity is a disgrace. The fact that this is allowed to go on year after year is unworthy of europe. We Greens demand that Member States systematically and proactively carry out search and rescue operations and contribute ships and equipment, individually or jointly in Frontex.  We demand that all mediterranean operators proactively disseminate information about ships in distress to other vessels, so that they can assist in search and rescue operations. And we demand that all people rescued in the Mediterranean be transported to a safe place in accordance with international and Union law.

name: Tom VANDENDRIESSCHE
text: Mr President, colleagues who break the law will be punished. That is the way we protect our citizens. In this way, our citizens can have confidence in a democratic rule of law. But that is exactly what this political elite refuses to do. Instead of protecting our borders, illegal migrants who deliberately break our laws are rewarded with a residence permit. In this House, some even applaud NGOs that encourage illegal migration. Some claim to be doing so for humanitarian reasons. But what exactly is the humanitarian to maintain the business model of people smuggling? What is it really about handing our people over to illegal invaders who commit numerous criminal acts? Those who have genuine humanitarian concerns will break that business model of people smuggling, close our borders, protect our people, take in illegal immigrants and send them unceremoniously back to where they came from. That is what our citizens expect.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I do not deny the need to save lives, but unfortunately rescue operations in the Mediterranean by NGOs are very often used by people smugglers. It is a cruel and cynical business that earns more than $10 billion a year from human suffering and naivety. Frontex has rescued 88,000 people at sea in the past year, but rescue operations are not its main task. Frontex aims to ensure that terrorists and criminals do not enter the Union. Unfortunately, people are smuggled without an identity check or a criminal background check. Rescue operations should be an exception please state, not the rule. In order to stop people smuggling by sea, it is necessary to act on land. A permanent relocation mechanism will only seal this bizarre criminal smuggling business, and we absolutely cannot accept it.  Therefore, please support our resolution, which proposes combating smuggling groups, a long-term approach to Africa's development and removing the root causes of illegal immigration.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Madam President, as already underlined by certain colleagues, the loss of life in the Mediterranean has been going on for many, many years.  And yet, here we are today, and we still do not have an effective and functioning solidarity mechanism on migration. And it is clear that for some Member States the migration problems of the southern states, on the periphery of our continent, are not a cause for concern. This should not stop, however, the work carried out towards ensuring a reliable and permanent approach to search and rescue that should replace the ad hoc solutions that have been used until recently. Given this scenario, the joint declaration between four Member States only – Germany, France, Italy and Malta, following the ministerial meeting in Malta – is a first step towards setting up a predictable solidarity mechanism. But these are four Member States only. The Council should take a leading role in putting forward a fair distribution mechanism for those people who have been rescued at sea: an approach that should give paramount importance to the principle of non-refoulement but making sure that existing search-and-rescue rules continue to be respected by all rather than exploited. No one should pretend to operate in a vacuum. Ultimately, a common EU response involving all Member States should be the preferred option. But in the absence of that, we can’t sit around doing nothing.

name: Antony HOOK
text: – Madam President, I find myself speaking on this issue on the day, a black terrible day, when 39 – 39 – people have died being trafficked into the United Kingdom, reportedly including at least one child, on a journey that took them through many Member States. Earlier this year I spent some time listening to refugees around the English Channel who had previously crossed the Mediterranean, almost all of them, and their experiences come in three stages: destruction in their homeland; secondly, movement to North Africa, which they find remains unsafe; and thirdly, they brave the danger of the Mediterranean because they simply have no other choice. And in some Member States, refugees remain victimised, driven into the hands of these people smugglers, forced to make these more and more dangerous journeys, and children left unaccompanied. We should not listen for one moment to those who oppose search and rescue. Let’s get on and save these lives.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, tomorrow Parliament will return, once again, to send a clear message that we need a rescue and rescue operation in the Mediterranean; we can't go on like this. But we have already asked so many times that it becomes a little tired that there is no reaction on the part of the institutions.  I have some very specific requests.  First, to the European Commission. We have asked you many times: make recommendations to the Member States for the decriminalisation of humanitarian aid. It's in their capacity and they can do it.  And we would obviously ask the Council to ask the different Member States to respect their rescue obligations in the Mediterranean; not passively, but putting concrete measures for the development and search and rescue of people.  And, of course, we're missing the reception leg. We have Dublin blocked, but we have first good news, which is this four-country Summit in Malta which, with enhanced cooperation, they want to start hosting. Make an effort to ensure that enhanced cooperation is extended to many more countries and we really have a real host solidarity mechanism.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The small number of Members in this Chamber shows the true importance of the issue of search and rescue operations in the Mediterranean. For once, Members are right here, because far more people die every day in northern Syria than in the Mediterranean, and they die at the hands of a person who has been repeatedly courted and treated as a partner by the EU for decades and, above all, by the left-wing parties, and it has long been apparent that Turkey is turning into an Islamist despotism. The wave of illegal migrants from Africa is now likely to soon be followed by a wave of refugees from Syria and the Kurdish areas. These people will come by land. But instead of focusing on how to protect national borders and, above all, how to stop Erdogan, you continue to talk about self-inflicted distress at sea, about Carola Rackete and about NGOs doing the criminal business of smugglers under the veil of sea rescue. Finally, take note: the real problems are no longer in the Mediterranean. Stop the search and rescue efforts, stop the illegal NGOs and their criminal activities, finally stop the expulsion and extermination of the Kurds!

name: Robert ROOS
text: Mr President, according to the International Organisation for Migration, the flow of migrants has decreased by 32% compared to last year. The number of deaths in the Mediterranean has fallen by 42%. Do you know why? This is the result of the policy pursued by Salvini. Why is the European Parliament calling for the capacity of search and rescue in the Mediterranean to be increased and the rules relaxed? The only explanation for this is that the EU's re-purpose is to encourage immigration with the help of NGOs. Mass immigration in recent years has had disastrous consequences for Europe's major cities. The globalists are opting for a solution that does not benefit Europe. Let us finally start working on a structural solution: closing our borders and sheltering in the region.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Madam President, last July the Council and the European Commission reminded us that their immigration objective was to save lives. Already at the time, I pointed out the gap between discourse and reality: a naval operation without boats and the Ever more deadly Mediterranean. And many of us recalled the urgent need to enforce the landing law and to propose decent reception conditions.  However, we are in this Chamber again, a few months later, and nothing has changed. However, we know the urgency of setting up a genuine European rescue operation not only to save lives, but also to enable coordinated arrivals at different European ports. Until this mission is in place, NGOs will have to make up for the shortcomings of the Member States, which is why it is also important to put an end to the criminalisation of people who help shipwrecked people. For months, we have been waiting for commission guidelines on the Migrant Aid Directive and its humanitarian exemptions. Solutions exist to create a right to save. Only the political will is still lacking.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Somali-British poet Warsan Shire wrote: 'No one puts their children in a boat unless the water is safer than the land'. It is clear that in Europe the water is no safer than the country. The number of deaths in the Mediterranean in 2018 was no less than five times higher than in the disaster year 2015. Five times! How did that happen to colleagues? Well, because Europe is wrong. We have a mouthful of European values, but we do not act on them. The number of rescue operations at sea has decreased. Some Member States criminalise NGOs for saving lives. These are European values upside down and these are actually practices that we would expect from Trump or Putin. We do not let drowning drowning in Europe. We take responsibility. Commissioner, I would like to ask you: work on a real European asylum policy. Step up the fight against people smugglers. Make sure that drowning people can be saved and make sure that we no longer have to experience this shame in Europe.

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Madam President, the EU is weak on crime and weak on borders. These nice open borders attract people – for the most part, young men from sub-Saharan countries – who want to have a better life. Europe cannot take in millions of Africans. Europe belongs to Europeans. European politicians should not argue year after year about relocating people. If we were to spend as much energy on the well-being of Europeans as we do on immigration, Europe as a whole would do so much better. We should be discussing about how to seal the external borders of Europe. Our duty is to safeguard the prosperity and security of the European civilisation.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating The While the EU and the Member States are stuck in negotiations on the EU's future migration policy, people are drowning in the Mediterranean. That's the simple truth. The response of the extreme right and parts of the right in Europe has been to try to criminalise the humanitarian aid efforts of NGOs to save human lives. An important part of the resolution on which we will vote on Thursday is the call for the Commission to present guidelines for existing EU legislation that makes it clear that unprofitable humanitarian aid is not illegal. The responsibility for maritime rescue lies primarily with each Member State, but it is not okay for only a few to take all the responsibility. The agreement in Malta to try to distribute the people who have arrived by boat is welcome, but the long-term sustainable solution is to ensure that everyone takes responsibility for a safe and orderly European migration policy, that is, where all Member States take responsibility for people who are on the run.  The forces that refuse to take responsibility are only talking about helping people on the ground. But all they mention is how we prevent people from getting to Europe. They are not talking about how we are looking to increase humanitarian development aid, for example.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, malta's agreement on immigrants is the usual rip-off against Italy and once again demonstrates the lies of the Pd and 5 Star Government: so much hot air and zero facts.  On the contrary, unfortunately, the facts are there. In one month Pd and 5 Stelle have tripled the landings of illegal immigrants in Italy, to the applause of Europe.
