Unfortunately, it is a film that has already been seen: an abusive government, imposed by Europe against the will of the Italian people, which opens the doors to thousands of illegal immigrants.  Dear bureaucrats in Brussels, this time you have done the maths wrong, because the Italians will no longer suffer in silence. Italians are tired of your lies and false promises. The Italians will never accept a new invasion of illegal immigrants. We are ready to barricade ourselves together with the citizens in order to defend our land and our people. We will never allow you to turn Italy into europe's refugee camp!

name: Hynek BLAŠKO
text: – Madam President, on the soil of this institution, there is constant weeing over the terrible fate of the people of the Mediterranean, but someone is responsible for their fate.  First, politicians who wanted to impose democracy on North Africa with their weapons, but caused more than chaos. Secondly, those who constantly encourage migration with meaningless directives, court decisions, ill-considered policies that advocate unfair benefits for migrants, such as the payment of inadequate social benefits. Those who reject harsh punishments for people smugglers, those who support people like Madame Racket, who so-called save at sea, but give others hope of making it to the mainland and therefore risk their lives. And lastly, the people themselves who go out to sea because they are unable to assess the level of risk. All of you who support this are responsible.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The debate shows that even the resolution that has been drafted covers only a minimal, small aspect of the problem. And that's my problem with that. I am in favour of search and rescue operations – there is no question about that. I believe that there is no dissent in the democratic part. But just talking about search and rescue operations does not solve the problem. Because the greater part of the people die in the Saharan region. People are rarely discussed because they rarely land with us, because we don't see it directly, because we don't know the pictures of them. That is why most of our attention and work must be focused on the areas in Africa with which we can work together to actually prevent people from landing. Frontex proves every day that we are carrying out searches and rescues with tens of thousands of people being rescued. That is not the discussion. Unfortunately, however, the solution being tried by the resolution is not a solution.

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: – Sinjura President, is-soluzzjonijiet Ewropej eżistenti m'għadhomx adattati u èertament mhumiex biżżejed biex jindirizzaw il-kriżi attwali in l-isfidi li qegħdin naffaèèjaw bħala Unjoni. Fuq naħa waħda għandna immigrants maqbuda f'ibħra miftuħa għal jiem sħaħ, in bosta nies, inklużi tfal u nisa, qegħdin jitilfu ħajjithom fl-ibħra tagħna. Imma fuq in-naħa l-oħra għandna èittadini Ewropej illi qed iħossuhom weave in fl-istess ħin inkwetati għal mode would I l-Unjoni Ewropea qiegħda tonqos milli taġixxi.  Il-pajjiżi fil-fruntiera huma affettwati direttament mill-immigrazzjoni. Huma ferm aktar vulnerabbli għal inèidents bħal dawk li rhine matul il-ġimgħa whether għaddiet fiè-ème miftuħ ta' Ħal Far ġewwa Malta. Is-sitwazzjoni qed tkompli teskala u ma nistgħux nibqgħu èassi u ninjoraw il-fatt li l-immigrazzjoni hija fost l-aktar punti ta' tħassib għaċ-äittadini tagħna. Jekk nagħmlu hekk, ser nirriskjaw li jkollna żieda ta' ideoloġiji estremists, tixrid ta' mibegħda in vjolenza. L-Unjoni Ewropea trid tqum in tindirizza din il-problema b'mod effettiv permezz tas-solidarjetà u permezz ta' soluzzjoni Ewropea commune.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Madam President, addressing such important issues as the rescue of refugees and migrants in the Mediterranean is of paramount importance. More importantly, we do not stay in words, but take concrete steps towards resolving the problem.  And the motion for this resolution is doing exactly that. The Union needs a more coordinated approach to rescuing and disembarking refugees and migrants and a fair and sustainable mechanism for allocation of rescued.  The fact that more than 19,000 people died in the Mediterranean between 2014 and 18 is frightening. I am aware that the issue of security often arises on this issue, but it is also important to be aware of the issue of solidarity. This has to go hand in hand.  I believe that the Member States can work together to help those who seek safe shelter in Europe – and have the right to do so – while ensuring and maintaining the safety of all residents.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Maybe to begin with, a quote known to everyone, "Who saves one life saves the whole world." I would like to refer here to my experiences as a former sailor, a man of the sea. I can't imagine a situation, whether I'm on a merchant ship or a sailing ship, to see a man in need of help at sea and not to help him. On the other hand, as a politician, as a responsible person, I am aware that criminal groups are listening to this debate today and that millions of citizens of sahel countries, from Senegal to Eritrea, are listening, including those living in Equatorial Africa. Responsibility, ladies and gentlemen. As Interior Minister of the Polish Government at the G6 meeting in Lyon last October, I heard the only rational voice of morocco's Interior Minister who said "We are dealing with an invasion". Realise that this is a debate that we encourage criminal groups and encourage millions of people who are aware of who have access to the internet, encourage them to come to Europe and hence these tragedies in the Mediterranean.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, I too would like to commiserate with the 39 victims found in the back of a container in Essex, via Belgium through an Irish-owned company registered in Bulgaria: part of an increasing race to the bottom in the haulage industry. And it’s yet another tragic and heart-breaking example of how desperate people are, and the risks that they take to come to Europe. So I salute the efforts of those involved in search and rescue. It’s basic morality and it’s basic international law. But what isn’t international law is pushing people back and delegating responsibility to Libya, where they face disastrous conditions. We do need a reform of the Dublin Agreement. We do need to develop safe routes into Europe in order to tackle the smugglers. But more than anything we need to stop bombing their countries and making them homeless and making them refugees in the first place.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, colleagues, have you noticed how many colleagues, especially from the ID Group, are no longer here and have not a wait for the opinion of the Commissioner, the Representative of the Council? This is truly shameful, given the reservations they have made on this report or on this point.  I would like to say that, of course, it is unacceptable to me how many people are dying in the Mediterranean on this border, which is actually becoming the most dangerous border in the world. It is a disgrace to Europe. On the other hand, I must say that it is not possible for non-profit organisations to function de facto as taxi drivers and to replace the activities of the Member States, the activities of Frontex. I think that is really unacceptable. This entails accompanying phenomena, such as security risk, of course, support for organised crime. All this entails activities that de facto replace state surveillance, Member States' supervision, Europe's supervision. We should not resign in the Mediterranean. I would like this not to really happen.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am genuinely appalled at some of the speeches I have heard from the right.  We are faced with a simple choice with resolution: human lives must be saved, this is obviously not enough. Nobody says here, everyone comes in, we say here, we save lives, then we realize what is still lacking: a common European policy – let me tell you as an Italian – for the redistribution of migrants on our territory.  Overcoming the Dublin Regulation, the legal access channels – these are the real enemies of traffickers to Europe – the emptying of the camps in Libya, in short, a European political breakthrough that has not taken place.  We put people's lives at the center and avoid playing on their lives for a few more votes.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as stated already at the beginning of this debate, saving lives has always been, and will continue to be, the Commission’s priority. It’s our moral duty and legal obligation to save lives at sea and grant protection to those fleeing persecution and serious harm, including as a result of war or conflict. To this end we have to continue building a wider, comprehensive strategy aimed at effectively managing migration in all its aspects. In parallel, we should continue our efforts to address the root causes of irregular migration and instability in the countries of origin and transit. We have to fight everywhere smuggling networks that ruthlessly exploit the vulnerabilities of desperate people. We have to offer more accessible and credible legal pathways of economic migration and resettlement for migrants and asylum seekers stuck in third countries. Implementing this comprehensive strategy represents a very challenging task, which the EU should not address alone. The only way to achieve results is to continue working in partnership with countries of origin, transit and destination, with the support of international organisations and hand in hand with civil society organisations, sharing responsibilities in a true spirit of international cooperation. I am sure that all these elements will be reflected in the new Pact on Migration and Asylum that the President-elect, Ms Ursula von der Leyen, will present to give a new impetus to the European Union response to migratory challenges.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the Finnish Presidency is fully aware of the critical importance of the humanitarian situation and assistance in the Mediterranean Sea, and we are committed to working on a more solid solution in collaboration with all stakeholders. Such an arrangement needs to bring predictability, in accordance with the International Law of the Sea concerning disembarkation, and enable efficient asylum and return procedures. It is of utmost importance that we succeed quickly. However, we need a solution that covers all aspects. The EU as a whole, not to mention the migrants themselves, do not deserve that this situation stays unresolved. Let me say it clearly: we must save lives. It is people that we are talking about. It is individuals that we are talking about. At the same time, we will continue working on reform of the Common European Asylum System, in order to deliver a permanent solution to the situation in the future. I remain confident that, thanks to all our efforts, we can make an important step forward towards this goal. Thank you very much for the discussion, thank you, Mr Chair of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) for your engagement. The work continues.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have received four motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 24 October 2019. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Who else is responsible for the tragic deaths in the Mediterranean, other than those who have turned Libya and the Sahel into a porous zone for terrorists, arms traffickers and migrants? What this angelic text obscures is that not only immigration is a tragedy for those who are forced to do so, but also for the countries of origin, deprived of their labour as well as their brains, so precious to their future development. At a time when the European Union claims to be setting the world's sustainable development goals, how does it imagine convincing the countries of departure to invest in the training and education of a young people who will grow the ranks of the candidates for exile? When we deplore the fact that 'so many lives are lost due to lack of legal immigration to Europe', let me deplore the loss of lives for lack of hope for a decent future in so many countries around the world. Finally, let us have other ambitions for Africa than to confine it to the role of "waiting room of 1.3 billion inhabitants at the gates of Europe," in the words of Stephen Smith.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: Writing. – We are losing many lives in the Mediterranean, including children. It is not enough just to strengthen rescue operations, but we must find a more sophisticated overall solution that is acceptable to all EU states. I therefore abstained from approving a resolution calling for the strengthening of search and rescue operations in the Mediterranean, the text of which ultimately failed to be approved. This may seem like a bad signal to some to refugees fighting for their lives, but let us use the situation to put the text in a more balanced form. I am not against the principle of solidarity when it comes to saving people's lives, and I am also in favour of strengthening the rescue mechanism. However, I do not believe that calling on Frontex to share data on its activities with every ship in the Mediterranean is a happy solution, as this could paradoxically contribute to facilitating their criminal activity and increasing casualties, instead of dismantling smuggling networks. Nor do I reject a fairer redistribution mechanism, but it should also take into account the specificities of individual countries and be the result of consensus. I am opposed to the criminalisation of NGOs helping refugees save lives, but they must also respect the norms of international law and, in particular, the rules that we should agree on throughout the EU.

name: Janina OCHOJSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am pleased that, after months of scandalous policies of not accepting refugees rescued in the Mediterranean, a political solution to this problem has been found. I hope that the relocation system, supported only by seven countries, will prove to be a good model for further cooperation and that other European countries will soon join it jointly and severally.  The Office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees reported that more than 1,000 migrants have already died in the Mediterranean this year. Our aim should be to create such living conditions in the countries of origin of migrants so that they do not have to make dramatic decisions about their way to Europe. It is about providing the most basic conditions: access to drinking water, a roof over your head, access to sanitation and medical care, but also about ensuring peace.  Meanwhile, as a result of the actions of Turkish troops in Syria, the number of refugees has increased again in the last two weeks. The number of Kurds fleeing war has reached 176,000. In addition, the European Parliament and the Union as a whole should influence the already dramatic situation of the country's more than three million refugee communities, and respond adequately to Human Rights Watch's information on the destruction of temporary refugee shelters by the Lebanese military.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on opening accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania (2019/2883(RSP)). Just before I open the debate, I wish to let you know that if you want to request catch-the-eye and blue cards, it’s possible to use the standard registration and the new system, details of which are on your desk. You can register electronically, and therefore you need your voting cards, and indeed similarly with catch-the-eye, you can do so, not towards the end of the debate but perhaps at any time during the debate, please register.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, Members of Parliament, as you very well know, the progress of North Macedonia and Albania on their European path has been debated in the Council for quite some time. I know you are equally aware that the Council has not yet been able to reach an agreement on the Commission’s recommendations to open accession negotiations with the Republic of North Macedonia and with Albania. In the meantime, both countries have worked hard to advance in their reforms. The Council’s conclusions, adopted last June, tasked us to make clear and substantive decisions on both countries, at the latest in October. As the President of the General Affairs Council, I must say that I am deeply disappointed that we failed to do so in our meeting last week. Despite all efforts, the European Council was not able to do this either. I must admit that this lack of unanimity on reaching these concrete decisions can be seen as a setback for the EU’s role in the Western Balkans and for our enlargement policy, which remains a strategic investment in peace, stability and development in Europe. But it definitely does not mean that we will stop here. This just means that even more efforts are needed. I think it’s important to stress that there are no differing views in the Council regarding our commitment to the European perspective of the Western Balkans. The importance of maintaining and even strengthening the EU’s engagement in the Western Balkans is shared by all Member States. It is also clear for everyone in the EU that the region is in our courtyard and, we need to continue to do our best to help take further the necessary reform processes. The European Council had a long debate on the issue last week, and in the end, the leaders agreed to revert to the issue of enlargement before the Western Balkans Summit in Zagreb in May 2020. At the Council, we are ready to do our part. The Presidency remains committed to doing what it can in order to explore a path towards a clear and substantive outcome. I would also like to reiterate how important it is that both North Macedonia and Albania continue to make concrete progress on reforms. Reforms are needed to progress in the EU approximation, but most importantly, these are reforms that the people of both of these countries call for. It is also worth repeating that committing to European values remains essential for all partners aspiring to gain EU membership. Let me conclude by reiterating our deep appreciation for North Macedonia, for the courageous step it took with the signing of the historic Prespa Agreement and the change of the country’s name. The Presidency also welcomes the political will to move forward, which has been demonstrated constantly by the Government in Albania, despite a polarised political atmosphere. I am convinced that soon enough the time will come for these efforts to be rewarded. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, last Thursday at the European Council, EU leaders failed to live up to their commitment to open accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania. The overwhelming majority of Members States were ready to give the green light for opening negotiations. Regrettably, not all Member States were in a position to take a decision on the day. May I use the opportunity here in the European Parliament to thank in particular Minister Tuppurainen for her personal determination and efforts to find a solution a few days before at the General Affairs Council, but as we know, it was not possible. But I would like, in the presence of the Members of the European Parliament, to thank you for all your efforts, together with your team. The fact that it was not possible to get an agreement is indeed a matter of deep disappointment. Let me repeat what I said last week in Luxembourg after the first, so to say, failure: this is not a moment of glory for the European Union. We are now at an impasse. Let us not forget that there is unanimity about one thing: the Western Balkans need many more courageous decisions such as Prespa. Following our failure to deliver last week, we really have to think hard about how to answer the following questions: where are our incentives to catalyse more such breakthroughs? Where is our commitment and support to those who take the gravest political risks? The least we owe to the countries of the Western Balkans is honesty. The enlargement policy is enshrined in the Treaty, and it’s not about being nice with our neighbours; it’s about our rendezvous with history, completing the unification process that began long ago. And it’s, above all, in our geostrategic interests. European Union Member States now need to clarify how serious their commitment is to the Western Balkans’ European Union integration. North Macedonia and Albania are not to blame for this situation. Both countries did what they were asked to do – and even more, and our reports on the countries acknowledge this. Impressive reforms have been achieved in Albania and North Macedonia in the rule of law area: judicial reform, fight against corruption and organised crime. The vetting process in Albania is a particular achievement. Moreover, the Prespa Agreement was a truly extraordinary achievement based on leadership, courage and determination to overcome obstacles of the past for the sake of a bright future. And the same applies for the good neighbourly agreement between North Macedonia and Bulgaria. Our responsibility now is to stand with these countries, whose citizens are deeply disappointed. They have the right to feel short-changed but should not give up hope. Our commitment to the European Union perspective of the Western Balkans remains unchanged. Their European Union integration is, and remains, a strategic important policy goal, in our mutual interest. That’s why the European Union will revert to this issue before the European Union-Western Balkans Leaders’ Summit in Zagreb in May 2020. I continue to hope for a positive outcome then. The Commission will continue to support Albania and North Macedonia in every way it can, to ensure that the EU reforms continue to be implemented, in the interest of their citizens, and to continue to help prepare them for their future in the European Union. I think now it’s time really to stand with the citizens of these countries and of the whole region and to support them. I can fully understand their disappointment and partly their discouragement, but again, we have to assist them to overcome the situation, and from the side of the Commission we will do everything to do this.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the European People’s Party (PPE) is deeply disappointed with the inability of the Council to start negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania. We have a common understanding that the Council’s decision sends a terrible geopolitical signal that is contrary to the interests of the European Union in the region. We cannot wait until the Zagreb Summit next year and we should try to repair this mistake as soon as possible. For sure this blockage will have political consequences, not only in the two countries but also in the whole region.  The EU is not consistent in its messages. The Bulgarian Presidency put back the topic of enlargement of the EU agenda, after a gap of 15 years after the Thessaloniki Summit. Our six Western Balkan partners are European countries and it is in our own interest to integrate them today rather than tomorrow. Other geopolitical players like Russia, Turkey, China and Saudi Arabia are keen to increase their influence in the absence of a vital European perspective. The EU must regain the trust of the citizens of this region as soon as possible. Furthermore, we must invest enough funds in effective communication tools to counter the propaganda against the European Union in the Western Balkans. And yes indeed, both countries need to deliver still in many political fields, for example, the implementation of the Good Neighbourly Relations Agreement between Sofia and Skopje is unsatisfactory.  Sometimes I wonder why it is only under pressure from outside that countries are willing to wake up from decades of manipulation and falsification of historical facts and events. This is similarly valid for other bilateral issues in the region, and indeed EU integration cannot depend only on the bravery of one person to solve all long-standing problems, and if the opposition come to power, to destroy it.  We would like to urge the three countries in the Council to lift their blockage and allow the start of the EU accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania, which we know will continue for a long time and we need very soon to regain the trust of the young generation in the EU.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Kovatchev, will you accept a blue card? Just a moment please. I’m being advised – and indeed it is true – that we normally don’t take blue cards during the first round of speakers so, in order to keep with tradition, I’m going to have to refuse your request for a blue card.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, let me also welcome Mr Xhaferi, the Speaker of the North Macedonian Parliament here in our House today.  I wish I could give a different speech today. North Macedonia and Albania have worked hard over the past years to meet all the conditionality criteria and to implement difficult and necessary reforms. Both countries kept their promise and fulfilled their share. It was now time for the EU to deliver and to open accession negotiations. North Macedonia has been a candidate for a total of 14 years and the Commission has given the green light for accession talks for the past 10 years.  The toughest negotiations, on its name, led to the historic Prespa Agreement and it took real political courage and real leadership, by both North Macedonia and Greece, to put an end to a 27-year dispute. As sad as it is to say, this is exactly what European leaders did not have – or perhaps, precisely, the French President did not have. Mr Macron did not show the same leadership and the same political courage. The EU had the opportunity to finally show responsibility and political maturity but we failed, miserably, and this failure damages the image of the European Union in the Western Balkans.  The EU often raises its voice on issues where, sadly, we are unable to make a difference. The European Council made us silent on the only political choice where we could have made a difference and I’m sorry to say it but the Zagreb Summit in May 2020 is too little and too late.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, despite a huge majority of support by the Member States, for the third time in 16 months, the European Council failed to agree on whether to open accession negotiations with Albania and North Macedonia.  This is a very disappointing decision that could have the consequences of an historic mistake. We are not able to deliver on what we have promised several times already and this failure to move forward with the membership talks could undermine the EU’s credibility and destabilise the region. Moreover, following the setback, the Prime Minister of North Macedonia has called snap elections – a move that could lead to the EU losing one of its biggest allies in the region. Therefore, I urge the EU leaders to consider this decision as soon as possible. North Macedonia and Albania have continuously proved that they are part of the European family, especially during the migrant crisis, and they have fulfilled all conditions to start accession talks. Countries need to be assessed on their own merit based on objective criteria. As a Member coming from a country that had to go through the accession negotiations not that long a time ago, I well know that the process is bureaucratic and based on legal provisions, but sometimes it’s also led by political sentiments.  If you want to revise the current format for accession negotiations, it has to be done in time for the May 2020 EU-Western Balkans Summit in Zagreb, otherwise we risk losing the European dream of the region and turning the Western Balkans into the grey zone of Europe.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A famous Frenchman once said about a certain type of political decision: this is worse than a crime, that is a mistake. The Council's decision to refuse to open accession negotiations in Northern Macedonia and Albania is a mistake of historic proportions. I would like to thank Donald Tusk, Jean-Claude Juncker, Mr Hahn or Mrs Tuppurainen and all of you, ladies and gentlemen, who have spoken clearly critically. Despite all the anger at the way in which the EU has once again broken its word here, despite all the disappointment at the strategic short-sightedness, despite all the shame towards the people of Northern Macedonia and Albania, to whom the Council is destroying hope, I do not want to criticise here. I want to look ahead and address President Macron directly: Mr President, you have been very isolated on this issue, but the European Parliament is ready to build a bridge for you. If you read our resolution carefully, you will see that we are willing to participate in the reform of the accession process that you want. Let us do this together, but please correct immediately the mistake that Northern Macedonia and Albania must remain outside the door just because we have not yet completely cleaned up at home.

name: Anna BONFRISCO
text: On behalf of the ID Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union's interest in expanding relations with the countries of the Western Balkans is certainly strong, but we are all aware of the profound scars that this area is scarring and threatening the European Union: Chinese and Russian influence; the presence of large criminal organisations and potential terrorism; oligarchic policies; citizens with dual Turkish passports; more than 50 % of Muslims in Albania and Bosnia, 28% in North Macedonia and 95% in Kosovo. All this makes it clear that the instrument of enlargement and accession, as in the case of Turkey, is in a deep crisis. Perhaps, Mr Hahn, a good European trade policy would prevent us from deadlocking and disagreeing between Member States, once again each with its own foreign policy. A Europe that aspires to its own strategic autonomy has its test in its relationship with the Western Balkans. Let us try this time not to disappoint the citizens of Europe, and above all let us think of them.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, five years ago, Mr Juncker’s statement on accession and EU enlargement resulted in a real crisis in our relations with the Western Balkans. The Commissioner knows best how much effort is needed from him personally, his staff, ourselves, and the political leaders of the EU Member States, to reverse this negative process.  Both countries, Albania and North Macedonia, deserve negotiations. They have fully fulfilled all the criteria after many years of waiting. And now, at the very beginning of the next legislature, comes a slap from the Council.  I understand the same set of countries – President Macron of France, backed by the Netherlands and Denmark – pose probably the next crisis in our relationship with the Western Balkans. This crisis may be really dangerous so this decision should be reversed as soon as possible.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the Western Balkans is the most vulnerable place in Europe. It’s not by chance that the first war – the Yugoslavian war – after the end of the Second World War started there. We have to protect that part of our body – of the European body. Recently, North Macedonia took a historic step. Together with the Greek Government, they made the historic Prespa Agreement, fighting against the populists and nationalists. And instead of rewarding Mr Zaev, the Prime Minister, giving him a hand, we are throwing him into political turmoil. People are frustrated in North Macedonia. And why do we do that? Because instead of exporting European ideas, democracy, solidarity, we’re exporting our internal political problems and conflicts. There is a message to be addressed to Mr Macron – two messages. One: he should have been here to listen to almost all the parties. And the second is that we have to stop playing narrow-minded political games with small countries. Small countries need our help. They are small countries but they are decent countries.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Dear Chairman, the fact is that this institution has launched a strategy for the Western Balkans and strongly supported and promoted the alignment of measures of North Macedonia and Albania with the European acquis and explains my personal great disappointment, as well as my group's disappointment with the Council's conclusions last week.  After North Macedonia and Albania worked hard for historical compromises and met all the criteria for opening accession negotiations, we all hoped that their great efforts would be rewarded with positive signals. But instead these countries got a cold shower and block access.  In the process of complying with European Union practices, North Macedonia and Albania often had to reject the tempting promises of foreign actors. Therefore, the Council's decision not only sends a negative message to the entire region, but also opens the door for other players to fill the space left untouched by the Union.  Dear Chairman, we underline with this Resolution that this non-decision constitutes a strategic error and adversely affects the credibility of the Union and undermines the efforts made by the European Parliament in relations with the countries of South East Europe and I thank Commissioner Hahn for his efforts.  Furthermore, unfortunately, we are witnessing a lack of vision among certain members of the Council to be brave and complete the peace-building process that can only be brought by European integration, a process started by their predecessors, among them the late President Jacques Chirac, whom I personally knew, a visionary and an honorable man, 19 years ago in Zagreb.  The Croatian Presidency must play a key role and show the European Union that this is about peace and stability of the European Union in the future, which applies mainly to Croatia.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, the lack of negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania is a historic mistake of the European Union and this should be emphasised.  Once again, negotiations with these countries have been blocked due to intra-political reasons and the dilemmas of a small number of members. Especially by those who, paradoxically, want to rebuild Europe.  North Macedonia and Albania have met all the requirements we have made before them. It is remarkable that the European Union does not recognise Skopje's historical value and political courage to finally address its chronic problems with its neighbours, as well as many, above all, Tirana's judicial reforms.  The opening of accession negotiations is only the beginning of a process that has become longer and more complex with each new enlargement. It is completely unacceptable for these countries to become hostages to attempts to reform the European Union itself. So far, reforms and enlargement of the European Union have been parallel processes. The European Union's consensus on enlargement should not be renewed. What is needed is a clear vision converted into concrete action. And that's before it's too late because a lot of actors are interested in expanding their interests in this area, and those interests are not compatible with our values.  Both countries deserve membership negotiations, and the European Union can only rebuild and become globally fragile if it shows by example. First in your immediate neighborhood, then elsewhere.

name: Stéphane SÉJOURNÉ
text: Madam President, Madam Minister, I will be brief. I am in for enlargement. I am in my support that these two countries can, of course, join the European Union. But how can we add two seats today to the Council, when our same institutional modes are totally blocked? I believe in this Chamber, but I also believe that the European institutions are not eternal and that they must be protected. At some point, we must ask ourselves the question of the effectiveness of European policies and the effectiveness of our decisions in the Council before we ask ourselves the question of further enlargement.  So when you are pro-European - and I belong to a pro-European group - and I fully accept this position, I think we can ask ourselves how to reform the Council and the methods of decision-making, before asking ourselves how to add two chairs around the table. That is the position which, in my view, is a pragmatic position and which must also preserve this institution. We have to think about Europe in ten years, thirty years from now. I believe in this Europe and I do not want the peoples of Europe to become Eurosceptic because of our inefficiency in European policies.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: – Madam President, the European Council was supposed to keep its promise to North Macedonia and Albania and thereby strengthen stability and peace in the Balkan region. Instead, it delivered a hard blow to the people in the Western Balkans. The decision to start accession talks should be based on objective criteria, and the Commission is clear that the countries meet them. France, Denmark and the Netherlands, however, have acted unreliably by changing the rules in the middle of the game. As a result, arbitrary political considerations now affect the people in North Macedonian and Albania, who have pushed so hard for major reforms. The decision is short-sighted, as it threatens stability and democracy in the whole region. The message that the Council – or should I say, Macron – sends is that it does not want them to meet the criteria, irrespective of their efforts. But let us keep encouraging them and remind them that the EU institutions and most Member States are reaching out for the accession process. The Council should show that as well by reviewing the rejection as soon as possible.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Madam President, what would not be said for the beautiful eyes of countries where the average monthly salary is around 400 euros! This is the only explanation for the Commission's insistence on enlargement to Albania and Northern Macedonia. The economic argument would therefore be sufficient to obscure many shortcomings, and albania's are numerous.  Infiltrated by radical Islam, this predominantly Muslim country is part of the region of Europe with the highest concentration of jihadists. The Namazgâh Mosque, funded by Turkey to become the largest in the Balkans, is a testament to Erdogan's grip. The country is, moreover, plagued by trafficking of all kinds, Transparency International having also degraded its corruption index. Nor is Albania, nor is Albania European.  Does their people aspire to it, by the way? In Macedonia, the ridiculously low turnout in the referendum on the Prespa agreement and membership of the European Union shows that it is not. Let us therefore have the courage to close the chapter of enlargement for good and the billions of euros scandalously poured in for pre-accession aid.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, before we move to our next speaker, I want to make a welcoming address here to visitors that we have in the plenary. We have the Speaker of the Parliament of the Republic of North Macedonia, His Excellency Mr Talat Xhaferi, and we have the pleasure to welcome him in the diplomatic gallery this evening. (Applause) You’re very welcome to attend this debate on the opening of accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania. It is indeed an honour to welcome you to this debate and we wish you some very fruitful meetings here in the European Parliament.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: We now continue with the debate on the Council and Commission statements on opening accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania (2019/2883(RSP)).

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the decision, or rather, the european Council's decision not to postpone the opening of accession negotiations with Albania and North Macedonia for the umpteenth time is an historic mistake.  This is an unjustified postponement after repeated recommendations from the Commission and the position of our Parliament, embarrassing for the EU and frustrating for our partners who now have every right to question our real intentions. Albania and, above all, North Macedonia have made many sacrifices and reforms to get to this point. The Latter has even renounced its original name, reaching a historic agreement with Greece, an agreement that until a few years ago seemed simply impossible.  Ladies and gentlemen, our credibility is at stake. We promised these countries that they would be assessed individually on the basis of merit. Failure to deliver on the promises made throws an entire region into disillusionment, creates a worrying precedent and opens the doors of the Balkans to our strategic competitors, while Erdogan visits Serbia and strengthens his ties with Belgrade, North Macedonia sinks into another political crisis. To our Albanian and Macedonian friends in the north – I greet President Xhaferi, who I had the honour of meeting – I say 'courage', you are and will be part of this European family. It is an unstoppable historical process which cannot be stopped even by the Council's hesitations.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Madam President, last week’s decision in the European Council shook the foundations of one of Europe’s most successful policies. What has been a source of long-standing consensus has now become an open geopolitical problem. As the standing rapporteur for Serbia, I can tell you that the failure to open accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania is our bigger political failure to commit credibly to enlargement. A credible offer for EU membership to Western Balkan countries is in our joint and strategic European interest.  Let me respond clearly to voices from France, the Netherlands, Denmark, that question or even reject enlargement. If we want a stronger and internationally respected Union, we must try for a decisive voice and influence in our immediate neighbourhood.  The disillusionment today in the Western Balkans is enormous. The North Macedonians even changed the name of their country to get the green light from the European Union. Let’s remember, enlargement has brought unification and an unprecedented sense of security to Europe. However, our security is not a given, especially when we look at Turkey’s and Russia’s actions in our neighbourhoods. We do need successful, stable, resilient, democratic, and most of all European, Western Balkans. The success of south—eastern Europe on its path into the European Union will also be our European success. Failure is not an option.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Mr President, I cannot fail to confess my deep disappointment at the moment, the same disappointment that I know shared by the people of Albania and Northern Macedonia when they officially see their aspirations for membership of the European Union officially blocked, following the expectations created by the letter from the Commission, Parliament and the European Council.  Both countries have met the criteria necessary for the opening of talks and have complied with the implementation of the reforms that have so far been requested of them and which cannot stop. In this decision, the Council was held hostage by Mr Macron's decision-making process and urges other actors to continue their agenda in a region fundamental to the stability, security and strengthening of the European project. If the European Union is unable to show strategic vision, leadership, and to assert itself as a credible partner, it risks being dragged into disrepute. The Council has failed, but we here in Parliament will continue to fight to deliver on our promises.

name: Klemen GROŠELJ
text: – Honour President, I regret the Council's decision not to open negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania, and I am particularly disappointed that the Council has not been able to recognise and appreciate the efforts and weight of the compromises that North Macedonia has so far made on its way to the European Union.  I am saddened by the weakness of the argument that we need an overhaul of the accession process and an institutional reform of the European Union before the talks begin. Enlargement does not hinder the EU's institutional reform if there is political will in the EU. Rejecting enlargement talks in this way, on the other hand, is a clear message that the EU is now institutionally incapable of supporting countries committed to European values and vision.  This is a completely wrong message at a time of raw geopolitical dribberations in the European neighbourhood, especially in the Western Balkans, where North Macedonia is a bright exception in the region. In a region where we are witnessing a frank democratic decline and the rise of populism and nationalism. North Macedonia is a small window of opportunity through which the European Union can release a ray of European hope into the region. It is a message to the people of the region. There is a European perspective for countries that reject populism, corruption and economic stalemate.  If we, as an EU, cannot or cannot do so, then let us say it openly and at the same time prepare for the consequences of this decision.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The economy of the EU Member States is currently facing many challenges. Added to this are uncertainties over Brexit. So why should we seriously consider taking in Albania and Northern Macedonia, two of Europe's poorest economies, at this time of year? Unemployment is high in both countries and wages are low. Both suffer from fragile institutions, shortcomings in the rule of law, and cumbersome regulatory procedures. The latest Gallup global survey found that 60% of the adult population in Albania want to leave the country at a time when citizens of the current EU Member States have legitimate concerns about further immigration with all its problems. Nevertheless, I would like to pay tribute to the efforts of Northern Macedonia to hold the referendum on changing the name of the state. But these constant efforts to extend the borders of the European Union are not always good. Let us suspend these accession talks and consider what pragmatic help we can provide – for example, through structural funds, the EU Cohesion Fund – and let us return to a more coordinated policy to support these countries in the long term and to prevent the influence of third countries.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear! There is no doubt that the authority of the European Union has been takeny after the last decision. It seems that the interests of one country, France, are placed above those of the European Union. Macedonia meets the criteria for starting negotiations and all the people in Macedonia knew about it. That is why the European Union is simply behaving in no way. Well, it's kind of a disgrace. We put our own actions at risk. This is not good for the whole of the European Union. This is also not good for North Macedonia and for the Balkans. Please, Macedonia has an open path to NATO. Macedonia has fulfilled many obligations to its neighbours in order to achieve this success. Isn't it the case that there is a rematch here? Mrs Ursula von der Leyen was very much in favour of expanding the European Union, but when President Macron's candidate has not become Commissioner, perhaps this is a bad reaction. We must beware of this type of situation.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Mr President, the suffering and all that the peoples of the Balkans have suffered have certain causes. These are imperialist rivalries, NATO interventions, border changes, foreign military bases, incitement to nationalism, their interconnection with the European Union, capitalist restructuring. Experience shows that no country's membership of the European Union and NATO can be done for the benefit of the people. On the contrary, it is dictated by the interests of the major monopolistic groups. This is precisely where the debate within the European Union over the accession of Northern Macedonia, namely the fierce competition between France, Germany and other countries over who will have the upper hand in the Western Balkans, is due, against the backdrop of the tough political and economic conflict between the European Union, the United States, NATO and Russia and China in the region.  The confrontations between the countries of the European Union do not call into question the agreement of the Prespas, a Euro-Nato cut, signed with the aim of the country's accession to the European Union and NATO. The peoples of the western Balkans and the whole of Europe can live in peace, but outside the corset of the European Union, outside NATO, outside the corset of imperialist designs, rejecting nationalism, altruism, with power and the economy in their own hands.

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: – Mr President, there is no need to repeat that last week’s Council decision was wrong and bad. Very bad. And there is no need to repeat how important for the whole continent the EU’s enlargement policy was, is, and I hope will be in the future. Also there is no need to repeat how much was done and how many painful reforms were implemented, especially by the North Macedonian Government but also by Albania, and how much today they feel betrayed. Betrayed by us.  What we need to discuss today is very simple – what we need to change on our side, on the EU side, so that the whole enlargement process is not interrupted by one EU Member State. So what can we change? Before we move into enlargement reforms, we need to create a simple rule or tradition: to ask those Member States, or at least one of them, which, at Council level, are blocking enlargement to come out here and to explain openly what their arguments were for voting against. Then we would have the possibility to discuss those arguments here in the European Parliament and maybe in such a case we would be able to find a way to assist those Member States to overcome their resistance.  So today, I would say we need to be concerned not only about how to assist North Macedonia and Albania – because they deserve it – but also how to assist France to overcome its mistake – because this is a mistake not only of France, but of all of us.

name: Andreas SCHIEDER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the As Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn rightly said, this decision by the European Council is a serious mistake. The French President also bears responsibility for this serious mistake in the Council. The problem, however, is that we must all digest the consequences of this mistake together in Europe. It is important to stress that it is precisely the European Union that has to honour the commitments it has made. Especially when very important reforms have been implemented in Albania and Macedonia, and even when the name and neighbourhood issues have been resolved in northern Macedonia. I therefore hope that the European Council will make good on this mistake as soon as possible.  However, we as a Parliament must also seize every opportunity – through delegations, through bilateral contacts, through the Jean Monnet process – to establish even closer contact with northern Macedonia and Albania, in order to show that we believe this decision is wrong and want it to be made good soon.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, the European Council has to make a new and strategic decision because it was a mistake not to open the accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania. The prospect of joining the EU has been a driving force behind the changes we have seen in those countries. North Macedonia was led to believe that solving the name issue would give it the possibility to move forward with moving closer to the EU. Although ultimately countries should move forward with domestic reforms because of their own necessity, one cannot ignore the fact that future prospects of joining the EU have been a driving force for these reforms as well. I believe the EU should at least open the accession negotiations with both countries to encourage them to continue with domestic reforms, to align themselves more with the EU and its policies, and to have reliable partners in a variety of global issues. Failure to open the accession negotiations may unfortunately also contribute to the possibility of an external influence in the Western Balkan region. It is hard to see the EU succeed in a more global arena if it cannot be successful in its immediate neighbourhood.

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Mr President, EU candidacy status should only be granted to countries which have a realistic prospect of joining the Union. Albania and North Macedonia are both crime—ridden countries with problems of corruption and the rule of law. The EU has had enough trouble in absorbing Romania and Bulgaria into the Union, who were not even ready to join the Union back in 2007. We should not give false hope to countries who do not really fulfil the criteria of an EU membership candidate. The EU should stop spreading its borders ever wider when its own house is not in order.

name: Ioannis LAGOS
text: Mr President, I have just heard from some speakers that it has taken a great deal of political courage to reach the skopje agreement with my country, Greece. I would like to say here, to make it heard in this Chamber, that there was no political courage but there was the imposition of a very small minority at the expense of the will of the Greek people. More than 75 % of Greeks, up to 80 %, did not want this agreement. In the demands of the Greeks for a referendum, the Greek government categorically refused. So we have come to the then government and the current government being the biggest supporters of this traitoral agreement that has been made at the expense of our country.  And as far as all meps here are concerned, but also the inhabitants of all European countries, everyone has to come out of this fallacy: there is no North Macedonia, there is a State of Skopje, to be clear. All historians who have dealt with this issue know this and they are not words that I or some Greek nationalists say. And to close it down and to make all this very clear, here there is, on a marble slab found some time ago in my country, an inscription. This inscription says "Thessaloniki Philip queen". This inscription, after 2,000 years, I know and I read it when I am Greek. Any resident of Skopje cannot read this inscription. So let's not ask for things that don't belong to them. Macedonia is only one and it is only Greek.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen, the European perspective of the Western Balkans must remain open both because it acts as a factor of stability in the region and because it is a democratic lever for the necessary modernisation of these countries. It is also necessary for the governments in Tirana and Skopje to know that they are not treated on different criteria for the opening of accession negotiations in relation to the countries that preceded them. Albania in particular must respect the Greek minority and its rights. But the opposite is true, we have repeated violations in recent years.  As far as Northern Macedonia is concerned, we support its European perspective. The previous government, through the agreement of the Prespas, accepted the link between the application of the complex name, vis-à-vis all, erga omnes, with the opening of funds during the accession process. Accession is de facto essential for the existence of the complex name, vis-à-vis all, which was also that country's passport to NATO.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: – Mr President, the indecision of the European Council from last week sends a completely wrong message to the people of the Western Balkans, not only to the citizens of North Macedonia and Albania. The most wrong message is that the European Union cannot be trusted. Whatever sacrifice and efforts you make, you can be betrayed, not even for serious interests but for the public opinion polls at this moment in one country. Yes, the sun will keep rising in North Macedonia and Albania, but the EU’s influence as a global and regional actor will continue to set as a consequence. While we are waiting for the grand European reforms promised by Mr Macron, others will gladly fill the vacuum created by the decision of the Council. We will not renew Europe by disrespecting our own commitments and holding key EU policies as a hostage to nationalistic and egoistic political interests. Finally, we have to start repairing the damage made last week as of tomorrow.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: – Mr President, I have to say I agree with the Commissioner and many of my colleagues in saying that last week’s indecision in the Council was a grave strategic mistake and that the problem now is that the EU’s credibility internationally is being damaged. Because we profess to be the champions of the rules-based international order, and yet we have just thrown doubt on our own rules which we have created for the Western Balkan enlargement process, because the enlargement is based on conditionality, on clear objective criteria and assessment. We can certainly debate how to improve it, but we cannot just move the goalposts on a political whim. The consequences are already being felt today with the political crisis in Northern Macedonia and the blame game in in Albania. I have to say I sympathise with some of the concerns over the rule of law, given the track record of Hungary and others, but it should not be an excuse to stop enlargement. Rather, it should be an impetus to strengthen the rule of law in the Union and for the enlargement countries.

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Mr President, we are discussing today the possibility of Albania joining the European Union in the long term. But why, then, would we want to join a country that is already, in fact, if not by law, within the European Union? Yes, albanians are already in France and are taking advantage of the European market. Clandestines and mafia organizations are already circulating freely and send back to the country the money accumulated through fraudulent trafficking of all kinds in our country. Practicing "leave-it, pass" with Albania would only reinforce an already anarchic situation in which the French authorities are now overwhelmed.  Moreover, at a time when all European peoples are expressing a desire to see their identity and way of life protected, why offer them the accession of a country to distant cultural values and under the direct influence of Erdogan's Turkey? Hear the message that the people sent to you during the last European elections. The construction of Europe dies of your refusal to establish limits on the power of banks and finance, limits to the borders of our countries, but also, above all, limits to this endless enlargement and coherence that paralyzes us, at a time when the other major continental ensembles are thriving in globalisation. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Valter FLEGO
text: question he asked by picking up the blue card. Thank you for your words. I will not ask my colleague when he was last in Tirana, Bitola or Skopje because I believe he is not, but I will ask him something else in the end.  Namely, today we are talking about an absolute situation where some countries that are outside the European Union want to enter the European Union and some who are inside want to go outside. We have to put an end to it, and you know, when you make a promise to someone, then that someone expects the promise to be made because next time they won't trust you anymore.  For this reason, I am sure that this is one historical mistake, I am sure that we play with peace and stability in these areas, and I ask you: What different way of life, because you said that, have these people unlike us who are members of the European Union?

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Answer "blue card." Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am elected in France to defend the interests of the French. Therefore, I care about the well-being and interest of my people first, when you do seem to put the interests of others before the interests of our people.  As it happens, the peoples of Europe today voted overwhelmingly in the polls in the last European elections. And today, the peoples of Europe aspire to the protection of their identity, their sovereignty, the protection of democracy. However, this endless enlargement is the competition imposed on all European countries, and it is systematically the race of the less-so.

name: Miroslav RADAČOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, by the time I signed up for this one-minute speech, I had no idea that North Macedonia and Albania would be slaped the part of the European Union and that accession negotiations with these states would not be opened. This was due to the disapproval of the so-called 'big EU players', who want to decide everything and everyone. First we forced Albania to join NATO so that the American boys could play the war, then we forced the Macedonians to change the name of the state, and now we literally kicked them out. I suppose now we're going to get the Macedonians to flatten all the roofs on the houses so that american helicopters have somewhere to land before we negotiate with them. Dear Western European friends! It is not a problem for you to take several million people to Europe, from Afghanistan to Libya. However, it is a great problem for you to accept a two-million-strong Slavic Christian nation into Europe. Simply, you treat the Slavic and Christian peoples like people of the second category, thanks, of course, to the Slavic traitors and collaborators from our own ranks, who have stupidized and fallen so deeply that they wear the EU flag on their sakes instead of the flag of their homeland.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: - Dear Chairman, enlargement policy is one of the most successful policies of the European Union that has united Europe, bringing stability and development to much of Europe. That is why this blocking of the start of negotiations is completely unacceptable, especially since there was a positive recommendation from the European Commission, based on objective indicators and on the implementation of reforms.  Countries wishing to become members must be assessed solely and solely on the basis of their results, and not depending on the political climate in individual Member States, even if they are the largest countries of the European Union.  Such a huge strategic historical error strengthens the importance of other global actors in the region, but also, such a lack of accountability calls into question the credibility of the entire European Union. That is why the Croatian Presidency and the Zagreb Summit in May of next year is an opportunity to put another focus on this area and to determine a clear time perspective.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Thank you, President-in-Office, honourable colleagues! People, young people in the Western Balkans are losing hope, they do not believe us and they rightly do not believe us.  Let me remind you of the words of the French President last autumn, when he told North Macedonia, citizens before the referendum in favor of the Spanish deal: 'We are counting on you', I quote. I ask this same President Macron today whether he will take responsibility for stability in the region, or whether he will take responsibility for early elections in North Macedonia. Empty promises, that is all that is present in the European Union today when it comes to enlargement, are a knife in the back to all the citizens of North Macedonia, Albania, the Western Balkans.  It's been 10 years since North Macedonia won or won. For the first time, the European Commission promised North Macedonia that it could become a member of the European Union, and I am ashamed today that I must apologise for these actions to all citizens in the Western Balkans, and it is a serious responsibility for us to discuss how we will decide on enlargement to the region in the future, and to apologise and start correcting our mistakes tomorrow.  (The speaker agrees to answer the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: question he asked by picking up the blue card. – I agree with the vast majority of Mp Fajon's speeches, however, what I want to ask her is: Why did she not react with the same consistency and did not support Croatia's entry into the Schengen area after, likewise, the Green Light of the European Commission, which, also as in the enlargement process, is based on objective indicators?

name: Tanja FAJON
text: The answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – Thank you colleague for your question, although it is not an evening topic of discussion on enlargement to North Macedonia and Albania, on which the debate and vote are very crucial.  As far as Schengen is concerned, I very much support the integration of Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria into Schengen when Schengen is ready for this and Croatia also fulfils all the technical and legal conditions, especially when it comes to the issue of the return of refugees and the treatment of refugees at the border between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Council has established a momentary De profundis for the costly process of enlarging the Union.  President Macron has vetoed it, we have not understood whether it is for the too many Albanian citizens applying for asylum in France, or whether it is a repicca linked to Mrs Goulard's rejection.  Ladies and gentlemen, for years we have witnessed the creation of a giant with feet of clay. On the one hand, the Eu ropean Union squandered European taxpayers' money, ignoring the opinions and reminders of the Court of Auditors; on the other hand, the candidate countries were under the illusion that Brussels was the panacea for all their problems. Albania, we cannot forget that albania is part of the Organisation of the Islamic Conference, while European taxpayers' money disappeared into inefficiencies, the OCI financed Koranic schools. With regard to so-called North Macedonia, we are violating the history of a people, because Makedonia is Thessaloniki is not Skopje. I will end, Mr President, with a bitter observation: there is a lot of talk about enlargement as a key to curbing Russian or Chinese influence in the Balkans, but when the Chinese bought half of Greece nobody spoke.

name: Alexander ALEXANDROV YORDANOV
text: – Dear Mr President, France is not a country that makes accidental mistakes. France is a country that we assume knows what it is doing, but this decision clearly serves Russian interests in the Balkan region, and Russia, as we know, is an opponent of the European and Euro-Atlantic integration of the Western Balkan countries and has been fighting a hybrid war in this direction for many years. The result of Mr Macron's mistake is that early elections will be held in North Macedonia, but the European Council should not wait for their result and the Zagreb meeting in May, because it is possible then for Mr Macron to say "Let's wait for the first steps of the new Macedonian government and then make a decision", thus entering a dangerous political spiral. I would recommend fewer backstage games of Paris with Moscow and Belgrade. Thank you.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced that the European Council's halt to the negotiations with Albania and North Macedonia was a serious mistake. Today we see these countries working seriously for eu membership, as demonstrated by the 2018 Prespa Agreement between Greece and North Macedonia and the reforms carried out by Albania in recent years to comply with the requirements of the Union. The reopening of negotiations is an important step towards opening a new phase. The progress made in recent years must be taken seriously, not least so as not to disappoint the hopes of those young people and citizens who look forward to these negotiations, including so many citizens from these countries who also live with their families in my country, Italy.  There is certainly a need to reform the Union, which is not working well today. We have to do it, we will, I hope in these years. There is a real need to change the functioning of the institutions, but this cannot be a justification for blocking everything. Let us strive to make the European Union stronger by continuing to unite the peoples of our continent.

name: Andor DELI
text: - Commissioner, Madam Secretary, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. What happened at the EU summit last week only achieved that the EU's credibility and credibility with regard to enlargement policy had been ethiced. At the same time, the EU has lost the right to hold the candidate countries of the Western Balkans to account, since it has not consistently kept its commitments. We know that candidates must strive for reforms, but we also need to recognise that the political relationship between countries is not a one-way street. It would be good for all European leaders to finally realen up that the EU is not a victim of the enlargement process, but one of the stakeholders. Doubters talk about the need to first implement internal institutional reform of the European Union before further enlargement, but it would be unfair to expect the Western Balkan countries to wait patiently for the end of such a deep and divisive internal EU debate. Mr Hahn, thank you for your work, and the new European Commission must make this an outstanding task.

name: Sven MIKSER
text: – Mr President, the Council decision not to open talks with North Macedonia and Albania was highly regrettable. More than that, it was plain wrong. Much has been said about what this failure could mean to the EU’s credibility, not just in those two aspirant countries but far beyond, and how it could destabilise the whole region. What makes it particularly shameful is the fact that the refusal to open talks was motivated by domestic political consideration or, to put it more directly, by poll figures in a certain EU Member State. It was not the result of any failure by the aspirants to live up to their end of the bargain. In fact, quite the opposite was the case. The leaders of North Macedonia especially have displayed admirable courage and taken significant political risks to resolve a longstanding disagreement with a neighbour. I believe the Council decision from last week runs counter to the vision of Europe whole and free. It is crucial that the mistake be corrected before irreparable damage is done to our credibility and to our common European security interest.

name: Arba KOKALARI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr President Macron stood in this chamber over a year ago talking about the fact that he wants to see European democracy, that it is our best chance and that if we give up democracy, we are on the wrong track. I agree with him. It is therefore incredibly regrettable that he vetoed the accession process for Albania and North Macedonia. Worst of all, the whole enlargement policy – enlargement, which is the EU's most successful tool for promoting democratic reforms and human rights and freedoms – is now being called into question. We cannot turn our backs on those countries that are making an effort to become strong democracies, but we must encourage them to do more. If the EU is not in the Western Balkans, then Russia is there, then China is there, and Saudi Arabia and Turkey. Let us not betray the dream of a united Europe, of a united East and a West. The European Commission must act more now.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I am very glad that the majority of colleagues here have said a clear position that the Council's decision is wrong. We have debated many times in this House about the need to integrate the countries of the Western Balkans. Any other decision is wrong, because it will lead to Russia strengthening its influence in this area. That is what colleagues here have said. The European Union will weaken in the region. What is it possible to say to the citizens of these two states today when the European Union has thrown them overboard? That's an objective fact. Commissioner, we have debated many times here that, from the point of view of the interest of the European Union, not just these states, accession talks need to be continued. Those colleagues who are sceptical here that these countries are not ready to join the EU, I say to them: this is about starting accession talks, not about accession itself. These talks may take years, but they give clear hope and a chance for these states to join the European Union one day. So I'm like, let's rethink this, let's put pressure on the Council, on France, on Macron. This decision is detrimental to the European Union.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, as a friend of the Western Balkans, I have no doubt that Albania and North Macedonia will eventually join the EU. You have indeed taken important and successful steps so far to become a member, and the recent act of sabotage in the Council by France, Denmark and the Netherlands is regrettable. In many ways, Albania and North Macedonia are ahead of some EU Member States. For example, both countries have ratified the Istanbul Convention, whilst my own country, the UK, is dragging its heels and Bulgaria prevaricates. I call on all leaders of the European Council to put this back on their agenda and grant agreement for the opening of the accession talks. The image of the EU will be affected in the whole of the Western Balkans region and across the EU if we don’t demonstrate political integrity and openness. I am convinced that the future of the Western Balkans lies in Europe and the future of Europe lies in unity with the Western Balkans.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, are we giving up the promise of Europe whole, free and at peace? Enlargement proved to be the best available instrument to assist and to encourage neighbouring countries to pursue democratic reforms, to develop market economies, to improve the well-being of citizens and, most importantly, to achieve regional cooperation and stability. Via action plans and partnership agreements we are raising tough criteria for our neighbours, but somehow we forget to uphold our end of the deal. This is unjustifiable. The candidate countries might not be ready for membership today, but we must take a long-term perspective. We need to counterbalance the efforts of such countries as Russia. Their luxurious proposals offer only short—term gains, while the EU enlargement perspective is about the highest available quality of life, fundamental freedoms and peace. To achieve this, bureaucratic arguments must be replaced by a visionary policy of EU enlargement.

name: Viola VON CRAMON-TAUBADEL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which What we saw at the last summit is indeed a historic mistake. Keeping the door to the EU closed before Albania and Northern Macedonia is an affront not only to the governments of these countries, but above all to the younger generation. It is a fatal signal for this whole region. In the past, generations in the Balkans have often grown up without prospects or real progress. This has led many people, often the brightest minds, to leave their countries. With the prospect of accession, everyone had bet that the next young generation would have a real, honest opportunity in their countries. But with this decision not to open up accession, despite the criteria already met, these opportunities for economic transformation and domestic reforms remain on hold. Others will therefore not wait long to fill the gaps in the Western Balkans left by the EU. In particular, Russia, Turkey, China, Qatar and even Saudi Arabia are working very hard for political cooperation in the region. That can hardly be in our interest.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, I am pleased that the Council has blocked Albania's accession negotiations to the European Union. Albania is, in fact, of public knowledge, a state plagued by endemic corruption that suffocates its own society. One in three young people are unemployed, according to World Bank figures.  While justice reform has been under way for some years, its results are very worrying. An independent commission, made up of international experts, eliminated corrupt judges. As a result, of the seventeen judges on the Supreme Court, only two remained, and of the nine judges of the Constitutional Court, only one remained. These figures show the extent of corruption. We have to face the fact that Albania does not deserve to join the Union. It is, even today, as the Belgian newspaper Le Soir headlined, on June 28, 2019, a narco-state under the influence of traffickers.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, in a few hours' time, the plenary of the European Parliament will vote overwhelmingly, I believe, on a resolution by almost all the political groups asking the Council to correct this historic mistake immediately. We welcome the historic agreement of the Prespas and send a message, we from the European Parliament, to the peoples of Northern Macedonia and Albania, that the European Union is neither dishonest nor unreliable. We are also sending a message to President Emmanuel Macron that his 'no' vote, which must be corrected quickly, does not play the game of stability and democracy and does not serve European interests - it serves the interests of nationalists, Erdoğan, Putin and reinforces instability in both Europe and the Balkans, which is why the far right in the Chamber applauds him.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank everyone in this Chamber very warmly for the overwhelming support for a credible accession process and, in particular, for giving the two countries of Northern Macedonia and Albania the green light to start accession negotiations. We are not talking about them joining tomorrow or the day after tomorrow, but we are talking about a multi-year process. It sometimes takes years to build credibility, and it can only take a few minutes or hours to destroy that credibility.
