This has happened to some extent in the Western Balkans, but I will tell you, not just in the Western Balkans. With this decision, we in the European Union have lost a great deal of credibility, reliability and predictability, which we stand for, which we stand for and fight for all over the world. I say this against the background that a whole series of problems are re-emerging in our immediate neighbourhood right now. Look at Lebanon, I do not need to talk about the Middle East, in Tunisia the political situation is highly fragile, in Algeria there is an unclear political situation. I can only hope that those responsible for this current situation were unaware of this decision, which means that the European Union's standing at global level, and particularly in the neighbourhood, means that they have lost their ability to solve, to have had influence, to have lost their assertiveness. It will not be easy to recover that. I am inclined – because I am a member of the half-full glass party – to believe that things are turning for the better, and I am also prepared to take seriously the various arguments that have been put forward in recent months to justify why the negotiations are not already opening. I also confess, however, that I sometimes felt that arguments were being put forward which actually have the character of a pretext for not having to say clearly and clearly: I am against enlargement. One of these arguments that we have heard from France, but also from one country or another, was that we need a deepening, an improvement in our form of cooperation, of decision-making and cetera before the next enlargement. Personally, I say: yes, I have a great deal of sympathy for this, but I do not understand that these processes take place one after the other, but it is quite possible, sensible, realistic and pragmatic, to conduct these processes in parallel, because both will take years. But if we talk first about deepening and then about further accessions, then these countries have an accession perspective that is located in the 1930s, and I believe that we agree that there is no prospect in this context. I can also assure you, ladies and gentlemen, that my services – myself and, I assume, my successor – will be very committed to looking at the methodology of the accession process. Nobody is perfect. There are always possibilities for improvement, but much of what I have heard so far already exists, and it already exists: the emphasis on the rule of law, the possibility of suspending negotiations, and no negotiation leads to accession 'necessarily', but this process is also reversible. So that is what we are going to do, and I hope that we will be involved in this issue with the commitment that has also raised this issue. Finally, I would like to tell you a small story that is much shorter than it sounds: in 2013, as Regional Commissioner in Brussels, I organised a small seminar with civil representatives from Northern Ireland who presented their various examples, projects and case studies, such as how they organised, conducted and promoted reconciliation in Northern Ireland. I can tell you that 90% of the participants in 2013 were representatives of the countries of the former Yugoslavia. And they will know exactly why they took part. Because they are fully aware that peace, stability and prosperity in the Western Balkans region can only be achieved by embedding it in a larger whole, namely the European Union. I would like to thank you once again for this strong signal of hope, which you will also send out tomorrow with the relevant decision, and I should like to wish the President of the North Macedonian Parliament all the best and i would also like to thank him personally for the many initiatives he has taken in recent months to open up the country to Europe.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, President of the Assembly of North Macedonia, honourable Members of Parliament, I would like to thank you for this discussion. I would also like to take the opportunity to thank Commissioner Hahn for his enduring commitment to the enlargement process. This discussion has further convinced me that our support for the Western Balkans, our support for their European perspective, is solid and enduring. In the light of the European Council statement, they will revert to the issue of enlargement before the Western Balkans Summit in Zagreb in May 2020. It means that the work in the Council continues, so we shall not give up the work.  Let me also recall that an agreement to open accession negotiations is only the first step in a very long process and, no matter how disappointed and frustrated I am personally, I would like to state that now is not the time to dwell on what happened last week. No matter how tempting it is, it is useless to point fingers and name and shame anyone, because now we must move forward. We must take further steps. We must now carefully consider the next steps in order to succeed in a process, which, in any case, is going to be long and require a lot of hard work from everyone. We, as the Presidency, are now carefully taking stock of the situation, and then we will move forward.  I would like to remain optimistic and hopeful, yet of course realistic as to the prospect in the next couple of months. I have full respect for the work accomplished by the two candidate countries, North Macedonia and Albania, so far. I would like to encourage them to continue in the same spirit and to deliver on reforms for the sake of their citizens. What is good for them, will be good – and is good – for Europe. Thank you very much for this discussion and for your attention.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn, Ms Tuppurainen and also the Speaker of the Parliament of the Republic of North Macedonia, who joined us in the discussion as well. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 24 October 2019. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: In writing, it is regrettable that at last week's European Council, despite the support expressed by the majority of EU Member States, they did not vote to open the EU accession negotiations between North Macedonia and Albania, even though the two countries have shown that they are ready to start negotiations.  This move has undermined the prestige of the European Union and discredited the two Balkan member states and many EU member states that support the accession process. This step threatens the stability of the Western Balkans, can lead to conflicts and at the same time has an impact on the security of the European Union, which also has an interest in enlargement.  I hope that soon the leaders of the Member States will be able to adopt a unified position on the opening of negotiations, as this is also in the interest of the European Union.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Writing. – The European Union is founded on the principle of peace, stability and, above all, international cooperation, which we should support in the future. For this reason, the rejection of negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania is a great disappointment both for us and, above all, for the countries themselves, especially after the considerable efforts made by both sides to move closer to the European Union. The Council's decision damages the international credibility of the European Union and causes a loss of confidence among the citizens of these countries. Both countries have demonstrated their willingness to integrate into the European Union and meet the criteria we have set, and therefore we are harming ourselves by refusing further negotiations.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, the Member States of the European Union have not been able to reach an agreement on the opening of eu accession negotiations between Albania and North Macedonia. These are countries in unstable conditions, which also have high expectations for the European Union. It is important not to lose the trust of the peoples of the region in the Union. They have fulfilled their obligations, the Union must also deliver on its promises and give the green light to Skopje and Tirana as soon as possible to start accession negotiations. This postponement will call into question the credibility of the Union in the Western Balkans, which will have long-term negative consequences.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – The suitability of North Macedonia and Albania for the opening of accession negotiations is beyond dispute. I therefore consider the Decision of the European Council to postpone the process to be a significant strategic mistake. At the same time, this step risks the credibility of the Union, the political stability of the region and sends a negative message to the other candidate countries. Furthermore, there is a risk that, following the decision, the activity of other geopolitically important players in the region will increase.  I stress that the Western Balkans region is of paramount importance to the European Union. Therefore, instead of procrastinating, accession negotiations need to be accelerated, both for North Macedonia and Albania, as well as for Serbia and Montenegro. The EU is not a victim of the enlargement process, but one of the stakeholders. Therefore, by desiling the decision, the Union is self-harming, which is unacceptable to me as an MEP.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Adhering to the idea of the European project, the Western Balkans are continuously making efforts to get closer to the EU. Throughout the years, Albania and North Macedonia have achieved a significant progress with reforms which eventually led to a positive outcome by the European Commission, calling Member States to agree to start pre-accession negotiations. The Council had the key role in moving on to the next step – to greenlight the opening of the pre-accession talks with the two countries from the Western Balkan Region.  Nevertheless, the lack of unanimity in the Council led to a decision, which can be considered as a mistake for the EU. The refusal of opening the negotiations, also discouraged the pro-European society in the Western Balkans, by showing that such serious decisions can be blocked easily.  The economic, social and geopolitical consequences of closing the door to the Western Balkans are too high. For that reason we must show publicly and vocally that we continue to support and work towards a European future for the region.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: in writing. – The decision of the European Council to postpone, once more, the opening of the negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania is deeply disappointing. First and foremost for these countries. They have made considerable efforts to comply with the conditions we set, and yet they are again left waiting. It is equally disappointing for pro-European reformists, in the Western Balkans and beyond. For instance in the Republic of Moldova, where the new government is conducting ambitious reforms that will make more tangible the country’s European perspective. Yes, we need clear criteria for enlargement and we need mechanisms to ensure they are fulfilled. But, for some Member States, the accession process was a cornerstone of democratisation and of a strong reform of the justice system, in full compliance with the rule of law. It was also an open gateway to building citizens’ trust in the European Union and adherence to its values. Therefore, we must not shut doors. The dilemma ‘deepening of the Union versus its enlargement’ is not new. But it should not be a pretext not to deliver on our promises, and it should not be used in a way that stifles the efforts of pro-European forces in our neighbourhood.

name: László TRÓCSÁNYI
text: Writing. – At the General Affairs Council of 15 October, the Member States failed to agree on the opening of accession negotiations between Albania and North Macedonia. This is a serious setback. Some leaders of western European countries are irresponsibly delaying the accession process to the European Union because of their domestic political considerations. It is feared that if the countries of the Western Balkans do not receive substantial support from the Union on enlargement, geopolitically significant countries will gain influence in the region that do not set any conditions for the countries of the region. This could pose a serious threat to the future of the Union.  The politicians of North Macedonia and Albania, regardless of their party acrelia, have done their best to start accession negotiations. Painful reforms have been carried out in both countries, with North Macedonia even going through a name change in order to start accession negotiations after 14 years of waiting. Albania and North Macedonia have met the required conditions, so it is incomprehensible why the two countries have not been given the green light to open negotiations. This underlines the credibility of the Union.  In the reform process on the future of Europe, particular emphasis should be placed on the legal framework for enlargement and neighbourhood policy. Accession negotiations with Serbia and Montenegro need to be accelerated, as any further postponing threatens the political unification of the Western Balkans with the European Union. The EU will only be stronger if we are attractive to our neighbours and support their development.

name: Monika VANA
text: Writing. – France's opposition to the accession talks with Albania and Northern Macedonia is very regrettable. EU enlargement, and in this case stability in the Balkans, should not be undermined by a single Member State. As early as 2018, the Commission has certified that both countries have carried out all the necessary reforms to start accession negotiations. Both countries must step up efforts to achieve more rule of law as quickly as possible, but the EU could also help. Accession to the EU would be very popular with the populations of both countries, especially since both governments are pro-European. However, we must also learn from previous enlargements. It is not only the economic key figures that are important, but also the 'social acquis', equality and human rights are also a prerequisite for accession. Respect for the rule of law must play a key role, as must greater attention to social cohesion. The EU must not create a strategic vacuum in the Western Balkans, but must aim at European integration.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Iraq, in particular the violent suppression of young people’s and students’ protests (2019/2884(RSP)).

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President and honourable Members of Parliament, at the beginning of October protests erupted in Baghdad, and later spread to other parts of Iraq. The demonstrations escalated into violent clashes with the security forces, resulting in over 110 deaths and more than 6 000 wounded. A curfew was imposed and the internet was shut down for several days. There have been reports of attacks against press agencies and television stations, but also of unknown armed individuals attacking protesters.  The European Union made it immediately clear, already on 3 October, that we expect the security forces to exercise maximum restraint in the handling of protests, and we expect credible and swift investigations of the events.  We are encouraged by the prompt statements from Iraq’s highest authorities, who have reaffirmed their commitment to guaranteeing freedom of expression and security for all Iraqi citizens as well as the freedom of the press. The Iraqi people’s demands cannot be met with repression. Their requests must be listened to and addressed in earnest.  The protests seem to have initiated spontaneously, driven by young people asking for access to basic services, better opportunities and an end to corruption. Their aspirations and grievances are legitimate and should not be underestimated. In fact, young people across the Middle East are taking to the streets with the same demands.  At the same time, the challenges that Iraq is facing are unique. The country is finally coming out of a long conflict. It needs reconciliation and reconstruction; but it also needs to deliver on its people’s aspirations to a better life and better opportunities for all. These expectations need to be fulfilled if Iraq is to be stabilised in the long term.  Credible and effective structural economic reforms cannot be postponed. Corruption needs to be tackled effectively. This is crucial to building the country’s resilience with effective State institutions and strong democracy. The current government of Iraq has put forward an ambitious reform agenda, which must now be implemented as a matter of urgency. The High Representative was in Baghdad over the summer and already then she offered to support the government’s reform agenda and to focus on providing services to the population.  In these years, we have always been on the side of the Iraqi people, and their work to rebuild and reconcile the country. In early 2018, we co-hosted in Kuwait an international conference for the reconstruction of Iraq, and we are now delivering on the pledges made at the conference. EUR 300 million has been mobilised in the last two years to support reforms and promote sustainable job creation, particularly for the youngest generation – the one that has been at the forefront of the recent protests. In these years we have demined the country’s hospitals and universities, so that the people of Iraq could finally have a normal life. We have worked with the Iraqi Government to support national reconciliation and we have established a civilian advisory mission to assist with security sector reform. This is also to make security forces more compliant with basic human rights and fundamental freedoms.  We cannot forget that Iraq has made significant progress in the past two years. After the territorial defeat of Daesh, the 2018 elections were followed by a peaceful transfer of power. Meanwhile, relations between the central government and the Kurdistan Regional Government have also improved. We Europeans have always said that we want to help the people of Iraq win peace. This is what the people of Iraq are asking right now, so we will continue to be at their side and to accompany Iraq on its path towards a stronger more inclusive and more just democracy.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, we have a crisis between Iran and Saudi Arabia, unrest in Lebanon, an invasion in Syria and other developments that underline the importance of a stable Iraq in a complex and volatile region. Iraq’s economy is recovering from 20 years of armed conflict that include the years of presence of the so-called Islamic State in its territory. The potential of the country is huge. Iraq is already the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries’ (OPEC) second biggest producer with the production of 4.6 million barrels a day. Economists predict 3.6% growth in 2019 and 4% in 2020.  We should therefore ask the government of Iraq to use the economic potential of the country to address the grievances of the population that led to the recent social unrest. The government lost control of the situation and the security forces. We should exert our influence in favour of the implementation of the 13-point reform programme announced by the government and in favour of an independent investigation into who is responsible for the death of more than 100 protesting citizens.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this month, tens of thousands took to the streets across the Shia majority regions of Iraq. Protests were clearly spontaneous and protesters were unarmed. In no way did they pose a security threat, and yet the crackdown by the authorities was brutal and deadly. At least 110 were killed, thousands were injured and thrown in prison, and paramilitary snipers shot dead dozens from the rooftops in Baghdad. Colleagues, let me be very clear: these actions are blatant and unacceptable human rights violations and must be condemned in the strongest terms. The protesters’ concerns are legitimate and urgent. Similar protests have been ongoing for months. A quarter of the young people are unemployed; basic public services are absent; corruption is endemic. Concerns about Iran are growing, and the actions taken by the government are of the deepest concern and simply do not deliver. These protests are not over. Nothing has been resolved; rather the contrary. 25 October is the government deadline to bring to justice those responsible for shooting civilians. On this very day, people again will go to the streets. We cannot allow their legitimate demands to again be met with violence. Iraq needs structural, social and economic reforms and revision of its patronage networks. This takes political courage. The EU and its parliaments stand by all Iraqi people, and we are ready to assist the authorities if they want to invest genuinely, decisively and inclusively in the country’s social and economic reforms. We are ready to demonstrate that the EU is a fair and trustworthy partner in the region.

name: Abir AL-SAHLANI
text: behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I will be speaking in Swedish, but let me first greet the Iraqi people in Arabic.  (The speaker says a few words of greeting in Arabic) – 109 people died in the space of four days and over 3,500 are injured, shot either in the head or in the chest. In other words, whoever was holding the guns shot to kill; innocent civilians, carrying the Iraqi flag and demanding their civil rights. The right to end corruption, to have equal opportunities for work, education, a life of dignity, a future. (Words in Arabic) shouted the demonstrators, "We want a homeland".  Unfortunately, the inquiry set up by the Prime Minister was not enough. It did not touch on the fundamental problems that exist in the country, such as a non-functioning electoral law, the contested paragraphs of the Constitution, an end to corruption. The investigation did not point to a single minister responsible for this violence who met the demonstrators who were out on the streets, or at those who did not belong to the official security apparatus in Iraq and who shot, vandalised the headquarters of other parties, who entered the houses of media outlets and smashed those who were going to report what was happening. Iraq has paid a heavy price for its freedom. First it was Saddam. Then came the American invasion. Then came al-Qaeda and last now it was ISIS. It is a war fought by the Iraqi people and all its minorities and their army, also on our behalf here in Europe. Iraq must come to an agreement on the fundamental problems I talked about earlier. Here we and the European Union can and must lead and make a difference. I am disappointed that this evening we do not have a resolution, but I hope that we are ready to monitor the demonstrations taking place in less than 48 hours and act politically. The Iraqi people deserve a life of dignity. The Iraqi people deserve our respect and gratitude.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very It is the right of the people of Iraq to take to the streets and protest. Nevertheless, more than a hundred of them were killed by gunshots, more than four thousand were injured, journalists were prevented from filming the protests, the Internet was blocked. The reports from human rights organisations are very clear: it was also Iraqi security forces who fired at the unarmed demonstrators. The Iraqi government has announced an investigation into the incidents, but it has not responded. Instead, more and more activists are threatened or disappear into custody, and new protests are announced for this Friday. What worries me as a Member of this Parliament is that for two years we have had an EU consultative mission in the Ministry of the Interior of Iraq. It is responsible for security sector reform. Last year, we increased the mission from 50 to 95 people. This mission is advising the very people responsible for the excessive and deadly violence of recent weeks. Hence my question to you, Mrs Tuppurainen: what consequences will the EU mission in Iraq draw from this disaster? How can an impartial investigation of the incidents be guaranteed? Above all, how do you intend to ensure that human rights violations by the EU-advised ministry and its authorities do not occur again next Friday? It is time for us to finally discuss our missions abroad in plenary.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Mr President, Iraq is a wounded country, wounded by sectarian hatreds, but especially by the US operation of 2003. A country wounded by the abuses of the so-called Islamic State, which ravaged the Nineveh Plain, the provinces of Al-Anbar or Salah ad-Din. A country that is ravaged by numerous violations of its sovereignty by the United States and Turkey. 5,200 U.S. troops are stationed in Iraq. The thousands of men withdrawn by Donald Trump from Syria joined them.  At the Brussels summit in June 2018, NATO pledged to carry out so-called mission to consolidate Iraqi power. The protests that shook the country in October, even as the country is hosting the Arbain pilgrimage, which brings together nearly 20 million Shiites, are of course reprehensible.  This Iraqi government is caught between its regional alliances, religious leaders who demand the government accede to the protesters' demands, and the preservation of the various components of Iraqi society. We are right to talk about this repression of demonstrations in the country, which we condemn, but we intervened in 2003 without thinking about the next day, without thinking of this youth deprived of a future, because we destroyed our country.  Sixteen years after the Western intervention, the West is a destroyed country, and we bear a great deal of responsibility for it.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, there has been a period of hope in Iraq after the crushing of ISIS, despite difficulties and now massive demonstrations against corruption, unemployment and poor public services. The reaction of the Iraqi Government was probably excessive, causing many casualties, with a trace of provocation as well: allegedly, an Iran—backed militia with snipers was deployed from the rooftops, causing more and more casualties, with young people killed and over 6 000 wounded.  We have to engage heavily in support of the Government of Prime Minister Adil Abdul—Mahdi, but we also have to request that all actions necessary be taken to curb the possibility of further violations.

name: Clare DALY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this time last year we were in Iraq. Three weeks ago, the young man who brought us around was shot. His friend, aged 19, just engaged, was killed in the protests. Do you know what upset them the most, and our friends back in Ireland who are Iraqi friends? It was the fact that nobody in the world seemed to care. Over a hundred people dead, thousands injured; it didn’t even merit a headline. When you compare it to the coverage on Hong Kong – we’ve got so used to the decimation of that country. Young people looking for simple things – electricity, water, jobs – they can’t get them. Why? Because it’s a legacy of the US illegal invasion; the privatisation of Iraqi assets; the theft of their natural resources exacerbated by corruption. It’s an appalling indictment. I find it very interesting that the present government, whilst predominantly pro-US, is being pragmatic, is being a little bit open to Syria, a little bit friendly to Iraq. I want an investigation into who was responsible for the shooting, because I don’t think it’s clear, and I do think that agents provocateurs are operating in that region.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the protests that have shaken Iraq have no ethnic or sectarian lines, involving young Sunnis, Shiites and young Kurds. Denouncing corruption, chronic unemployment and poor public services, protests intensified to call for a complete overhaul of the political system.  The response of the authorities was unjustified, terrible and brutal: 149 civilians died as a result of the indiscriminate use of force by the authorities themselves. This Friday, demonstrations are expected to resume. Ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to call on the Iraqi Government to ensure that the fundamental freedoms of its people are fully guaranteed. Not only is there a protest in Iraq against political systems that work for the few and not for the many: Chile, Lebanon, Egypt, Bolivia and Sudan are some examples of what can now be called a global trend and it is not the only country where these protests have been followed by anti-democratic measures such as the shutdown of the Internet, the repression of the media and violence by public authorities. Unrestrained globalisation and ever-increasing social inequality have exacerbated tensions between and within countries. Only with growth models based on social inclusion and putting people at the center can we give answers.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Mr President, Iraq, we all know, is not only the cradle of our civilization, but it is also surely one of the few liberal democratic projects, or attempts at democratic projects, in the Middle East. That is why I believe that, as such a project, it deserves all the political, diplomatic and even financial support of the European Union.  Having said that, it is clear that what has happened in recent weeks is quite unacceptable. It must be condemned by the European Union; we have to hold accountable; we need to get to the bottom of these deaths—more than 150 deaths—caused by police shootings at unarmed protesters, who were protesting by calling for, of course, social and economic improvements in Iraq. That is why I believe that we must reaffirm our commitment to Iraqis, both in their social welfare and in defending their human rights.

name: José Ramón BAUZÁ DÍAZ
text: – Mr President, my speech will be in Spanish, obviously addressing Mrs Mogherini, as it cannot be otherwise.  Iraq has been trapped for years in a constant cycle of sectarian violence, discontent and frustration that the European Union must help reverse. Recently— and already talked about throughout this session — thousands of young Iraqis have taken to the streets to protest corruption, against the lack of the most basic services, and against unemployment, as has also been said. Legitimate demands that have been answered with the cutting of internet connections, harassment of journalists and an unusual level of violence on the part of the Government.  That is why we must strongly condemn this unjustified use of force, which has so far claimed the lives of more than 157 protesters and left thousands of people injured. Victims, therefore, must be compensated and the responsibilities of those involved, duly purged.  This cycle of violence and discontent will continue as long as the main governance issues in Iraq continue, which we all know are: corruption, clientelism, and a political system that aggravates the country's most sectarian division.  Therefore, first of all, the European Union must demand that the Government of Iraq fulfil international commitments, the end of violence and remind it of its duty to guarantee the rights of freedom of expression, assembly and press of the Iraqi population.  Ladies and gentlemen, that is our obligation and therefore those must be our demands.

name: Isabella TOVAGLIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Baghdad and other Iraqi cities there is a brutal repression of unemployed students and young people who have been demonstrating for weeks against corruption and rampant misery.  Young people make up 60 % of the population and four out of ten are out of work and with no future. Special forces shoot demonstrators point-blank, causing deaths, injuries and arbitrary arrests. With the complicity of a corrupt political age, the country is reduced to exhaustion, in a perennial state of war masquerading as the need to fight terrorism.  The situation of the Christian population and women is particularly serious. In many parts of Iraq, Isis massacres Christians on a daily basis and imposes barbaric infibulation on Iraqi women.  Europe has a duty to take action to respect human rights in Iraq, because what is at stake is the credibility of our values and the risk of new mass migrations of refugees and desperate people to EU countries.

name: Pernando BARRENA ARZA
text: – Mr President, since the beginning of October, protesters in Iraq demanding a better life, better public services and an end to rampant corruption have been met with a hail of bullets and water cannon by the authoritarian regime. Such lethal force has murdered at least 105 people and wounded over 4 000. The Iraqi authorities must stop. We in the European Parliament must demand that the Government in Baghdad listen to its people and rein in its security forces. We must also ensure Iraqis’ right to freedom of speech, and that also includes the free use of the internet. The Iraqi Government is obligated under international human rights law to protect the right to free expression and peaceful assembly. The authorities should release all protestors who have not been charged with a recognisable criminal offence.  Lastly, we should also raise our concern about collective punishment measures being deployed by the Iraqi authorities against its own citizens thought to have relatives who joined Daesh. Those measures are illegal and risk starting a new wave of violence in Iraq.

name: Pietro BARTOLO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, hundreds have now been killed and thousands injured in Baghdad and adjacent areas as part of the spiral of violence that has been going on in the country for several weeks.  These phenomena of violence, it should be stressed, do not come from nowhere, but are the result of equally serious socio-economic problems, which for years have plagued a country that has long been trying to emerge from a war that has brought it to its knees. The discontent that leads thousands of young students and ordinary citizens to pour into the squares of Iraq's major cities is the result of rampant corruption, which hinders development and prevents the country from modernising. All this is linked to an alarming rate of youth unemployment and an increase in the cost of living and the lack of essential services, and creates the perfect conditions for the outbreak of a new social conflict.  In this context, the right to protest peacefully must be recognised. The Iraqi Government must guarantee freedom of expression and, even in the event of a protest, the security forces must act with the utmost respect for life and human rights.  The European Union must condemn all forms of violence and remain vigilant about future developments in the area. We must continue to work towards the political, social and economic stability of the country and the region.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Mr President, I must admit that I am outraged and terrified. Outraged and terrified, because I did not imagine that in the 21st century such barbaric forms of violence could be used. I am a doctor, an emergency doctor in Iaşi, at the "Nicolae Oblu" Emergency Clinical Hospital, and when I see so much violence unleashed against people who have nothing to protect themselves with, I think what a diabolical mind this can do.  Secondly, I am still outraged and appalled, because the right of expression, a fundamental right of every citizen in this world, is knowingly violated in the 21st century, a century that we want otherwise. But let us also look to the left, and to the right, and to the inside, and outside the European Union – because such situations are repeated in many places in the world, and perhaps we all put ourselves at a table, the Council of Europe, the European Commission, the elected Europeans, to make a reactive situation simulation in such a circumstance, so that such abominable acts do not happen again.  I am outraged and terrified and I ask all of you who have endured until this hour in the courtroom to find a common attitude so that such things do not happen again.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, the conclusions of the Iraqi Government's Commission of Inquiry are clear. Security forces are to blame for the deaths of 157 people in recent anti-government demonstrations. The brutality of the security forces is reprehensible at all times.  If "Help and Protect" becomes the beating and killing of unarmed protesters who demand better living conditions, democracy is under threat. It is true, of course, that the US military brought about as much stability to the region as the plague, but we all certainly hoped that Iraq would be in better shape. But if the response to protests against corruption and unemployment and poorly functioning services is a scathing one, we know that Iraq is not in good shape and democracy is moving away. The brutality of the security forces must always be condemned everywhere. Both in Iraq and Catalonia, but what most Members do not want to talk about, for which you are ashamed.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, (off microphone) incident, thousands of protesters, mostly young people have demonstrated across Iraq against corruption and unemployment, demanding accountable governance and improved public services. They have been met by Iraqi security forces using excessive and lethal force, killing more than 100 and wounding over 4 000. There must be a transparent investigation and proper accountability for these killings and human rights abuses. The authorities must immediately release all protesters who have not been charged with a legitimate criminal offence. Those arrested and detained solely for exercising their right to participate in demonstrations or criticise the government are not criminals, and the media blackout in the ensuing crackdown against protesters by silencing their voices cannot continue. We remind the Iraqi Government that it is obligated under international law to protect the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and freedom of expression.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, Iraq is a broken country. It’s hardly surprising that people are protesting. It’s hardly surprising that the government is pretty useless. The damage that’s been done to this country – Iraq – have we ever seen anything as bad in the last 30 years? It’s incredible, and sadly the European states are not innocent. Of course, it was all driven by the Americans; of course it was about resources; it was about regime change.  The hardship that this approach has inflicted on a people. Over a million people have been killed in the place, and when someone is killed there now, it’s irrelevant! Look at how many MEPs are here. They were far more interested in bombing the place than they are now in doing anything for the people. What can we do? Actually, I don’t know. It’s so hard for the Western powers to actually help a country without financially abusing it and raping it of its resources.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, allow me to say that this exchange of views was very useful and of course very timely. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the honourable Members for their interventions, comments and suggestions. From this debate, I conclude that we all need to continue monitoring closely the developments in Iraq and reflect on the country’s shift from stabilisation to reconstruction, coupled with good governance, human rights and prosperity.  I would also like to say that we should use all opportunities in our bilateral and multilateral contacts to re-emphasise the urgency of meeting the needs and aspirations of the Iraqi people, and of addressing the regional challenges affecting the country.  In the coming months, the first dialogues will take place under the Iraq-EU Partnership and Cooperation Agreement since it entered into force, and this debate will surely inform its context. Allow me therefore to express my appreciation for your attention and support in maintaining this important file at the top of our agenda.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on the Statement by the Council and the Commission on the UNITED Nations High-Level Political Declaration on Universal Health Coverage (2019/2861(SDR)).

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, if you allow me, I might remark that speaking about health at such a late hour is a bit contradictory. Having been at this very plenary since 9.00 this morning, I think we all should be resting already at this point – if we think about our health. Nevertheless, however, it is a pleasure to discuss with you the recent high-level event that took place on 23 September in the context of the United Nations General Assembly on Universal Health Coverage: Moving Together to Build a Healthier World. That event brought together heads of states, political and health leaders, policy makers and universal health coverage champions, to advocate for better health for all. Universal health coverage means that all people, including the most vulnerable – or should I say, especially the most vulnerable – have access to the health care they need, when and where they need it, without facing financial hardship. The aim was to harness financial and political commitments to sustain health investments, with the focus on accelerating progress towards universal health coverage, including access to essential health services, a skilled health workforce, financial risk protection and access to safe, quality, effective and affordable medicines and vaccines for all. This ambitious aim was achieved in the form of an action-oriented political declaration on universal health coverage endorsed by heads of states representing the entire United Nations membership. This is all the more remarkable as this was our last opportunity before 2023 – the midway point, to reach the sustainable development goals by 2030 – to mobilise the highest levels of political support, to bring the entire health agenda under the umbrella of universal health coverage. The declaration is accompanied by a concrete global action plan for healthy lives and well-being that will serve as a blueprint for global health and development agencies as well as national governments to meet health needs. We are all aware, of course, that big question marks still remain concerning the significant financing needed now until 2030 in order to live up to our ambitious commitments. This will have to be secured through a mix of domestic financing based on individual country contexts, and international aid-funding mechanisms. This is no doubt our main task ahead. It is daunting, but our credibility will be at stake if we fail. Finally, I would like to stress the leadership role that the EU and its Member States must continue to play on the issue of universal health coverage, in the multilateral context that is so dear to us but which we should not take for granted. 2020 will be a test year in that regard, with the 25th anniversary reviews of the 1994 Cairo International Conference on Population and Development and the 1995 Beijing Platform for Action. The EU and its Member States will need to position themselves at the forefront to protect the progress achieved 25 years ago and ensure that there is no stepping back. Such European leadership was demonstrated once again during the high-level event on universal health coverage, and I wish to commend Minister Kaag of the Netherlands for leading a strong coalition of 58 countries in support of sexual and reproductive health and rights. These are part and parcel of the 2030 agenda and a cornerstone of a universal health coverage. Investing in sexual and reproductive health and rights is affordable and cost-saving and can make health coverage truly universal, in line with our key promise under the 2030 agenda: that we shall leave no one behind. I want to stress that the Presidency will spare no effort to continue to promote universal access to health care, which all human beings, in particular the most vulnerable, need, when and where they need it, in line with the ‘economy of well-being’ approach introduced by our Finnish Presidency.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, on 23 September heads of states, governments and health ministers convened on the margins of the United Nations General Assembly for the first time ever for a high—level meeting on universal health coverage. They endorsed a landmark political declaration – universal health coverage moving to build a healthier world.  The Commission welcomes this historical event at which the United Nations member states recognised that universal health coverage implies access for everyone to promotable, preventive, curative, rehabilitative and palliative essential health services, and access to effective medicines and vaccines.  The United Nations member states committed to invest in primary health care, to ensure financially affordable health care, to protect women and children’s health and to strengthen the health workforce and reinforce government health capacity. Regrettably, the declaration also demonstrated the visible division among UN Member States on sexual and reproductive health and rights. The Netherlands delivered a statement on behalf of 54 countries strongly supporting universal health coverage for sexual and reproductive health and rights. The United States, along with 19 other countries, dissociated from the relevant paragraph in the declaration, in a call to roll back on sexual and reproductive health and rights. Commissioner Andriukaitis, speaking on behalf of the European Union, stressed the EU’s commitment to the sustainable development goals, and to the protection and promotion of everyone’s right to enjoy the highest attainable standard of physical and mental health. Health is essential for achieving stable and prosperous societies, economic and social well—being and security. To address health comprehensively, along with the rights—based approach already used through the implementation of the European pillar of social rights, we need a ‘health in all policies’ approach going beyond the boundaries of the health sector alone. Working in parallel on gender equality, water and sanitation, education, food and nutritional security, decent work and social protection, environment and security, could bring us the tangible results we aim at. In that vein, the European Union should remain committed to the promotion, protection and fulfilment of all human rights, including sexual and reproductive health rights, and continue the full and effective implementation of the Beijing Platform for Action, as agreed in the new consensus on development.  The upcoming Nairobi Summit in November will also celebrate and reinforce the commitments made with the programme of action from the International Conference on Population and Development adopted 25 years ago. I am pleased that a delegation of the European Parliament will attend this high—level meeting. The Union’s actions have produced impressive results. Between 2013 and 2017, the European Union contributed to over 19 million births attended by skilled health personnel. More than 13 million children were fully immunised. 57 million women were supported to use contraception. Eleven million people were put on life—saving treatment for HIV and 600 million bed nets were distributed for malaria protection and prevention.  We also support the World Health Organisation (WHO). Just recently, the Union signed an agreement with the WHO for an EUR 102 million partnership programme prioritising strengthening health systems and universal health coverage. As a global leader, the European Union will continue supporting partner countries in their efforts to build strong, good quality and resilient healthcare systems by providing equitable access to medical services and universal health coverage. As such, we will strive to reach our ambitious goal of universal health coverage for all by 2030.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, we have made great progress in combating the world's leading causes of death and disease: life expectancy has increased exponentially, child and maternal mortality rates have declined, we have positively changed the course of HIV, and malaria mortality has halved.  However, progress in the world has been uneven. There is still a thirty-one-year gap between countries with the shortest and longest life expectancy. Four hundred million people do not have access to basic health services. Every two seconds someone between the ages of thirty-seven dies prematurely from noncommunicable diseases. And one in three women has experienced physical or sexual violence at some point in their lives.  The facts therefore show us that universal health coverage gives us better life expectancy, but it is also an engine of economic and social growth for all societies of the world. One of the great examples of success, of course, is Europe, where we have the best public national system in the world; where we invest in health prevention and promotion from primary care; where we research the most advanced treatments; where we train to have the best healthcare professionals; and where above all we have quality and universality in care and access to treatments. Therefore, this political statement in the end what it is looking for is to comply globally with the third Sustainable Development Goal. In Europe we have two great instruments, which are our strength, to be able to meet the objectives. The first instrument we have is our European model of health care and the second is our model of international cooperation.  I therefore call on the Finnish Presidency and the Commission to further promote the cross-sectoral partnerships of our public health systems with those of other countries around the world to share knowledge, research and access to treatment.  And since we are world leaders in international cooperation in Europe and devote more than 72 billion euros a year — and many of the programmes funded are health — let us prioritize international cooperation programmes for health programmes, such as those that force health prevention and promotion, which starts with nutrition and primary care; and let us prioritise that our cooperation programmes should be aimed primarily at reducing the global maternal and child mortality rate, also reducing premature mortality from noncommunicable diseases, and ending epidemics of communicable diseases. Only in this way, with these great instruments that Europe has, and with our leadership, we will be able to ensure that in 2030 all corners of the world have universal coverage.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Thank you, Mr President, there was a technical problem with the timing, so let us say that you have overrun a little, but of course there was a problem of ours, I understand that it was difficult for you to actually observe where you were in your speech.  I would like to point out to Mr Pereira, who asked for a 'blue card', that we have, in practice, established that in the first round, the round of speeches by the political groups, we tend as Vice-Presidents not to grant the 'blue card' in accordance with agreed practice.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We Social Democrats welcome the UN's political declaration. We do this because we want to achieve the sustainability goal of achieving universal health care for all. It is important to strengthen human health in the world. For us Social Democrats, access to health care is a fundamental human right. All people should be able to get safe and good care when they need it, and no matter where they live, whether you are male or female, whether you are young or old and regardless of social class: No one should be left out.  Unfortunately, we see today that people in different parts of the world do not have access to good care. This also applies to the right to good and safe sexual and reproductive health care. In many parts of the world, women are today deprived of this right. That is totally unacceptable. The EU and, above all, its Member States, in their leadership, have a huge responsibility to stand up for the right to abortion for all women. It is a fundamental right that every person should be able to decide over his own body. We Social Democrats will continue to fight for the equal rights and values of all people and for the right to good and safe health care.

name: Véronique TRILLET-LENOIR
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, the UN General Assembly's statement on universal health coverage recognises the major impact of environmental conditions on human health. Air pollution is responsible for 400,000 premature deaths a year in Europe and many cancers. Contamination of food and water by toxic agents can lead to reproductive problems. Global warming is promoting the proliferation of mosquito-borne infections. These epidemics are currently spreading in Europe: two cases of indigenous Zika virus have been detected in my country, France, today.  The fight against climate change is therefore one of the axes in its own right of universal health coverage. Well aware of this reality and the leadership role that the European Union must play, as you have pointed out, Madam, the European Parliament and the European Commission are making the Green New Deal a top priority. The Paris Agreement also reminds us that the right to health is one of the fundamental rights of human beings. The main objective of the Green New Deal must ultimately remain human health, and more generally global health, which refers to the virtuous circle linking human health, animal health and environmental health.  In our fight against global warming, we will have to focus on educating citizens in order to avoid generating new health inequalities that lie ahead for the most vulnerable. Finally, the inseparable link between environment and health should lead us to evaluate environmental policies using healthy life expectancy criteria. This will be the best indicator of the green new deal's effectiveness.

name: Petra DE SUTTER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I welcome the speech by Commissioner Andriukaitis at the High—Level Meeting on universal health coverage, stating that the EU will continue its efforts to ensure universal health coverage becomes a reality in EU countries, as well as in our partner countries. In particular, I appreciate that he stressed the need for a ‘health in all policies’ approach, as well as highlighting the EU’s commitment to a rights—based approach. However, these words and commitments should also put be put into action, and only by investing in the health rights of all people and ensuring equal access to health care can we make universal health coverage truly universal. I want to speak about something quite particular. As the Chair of the European Parliamentary Forum for Sexual and Reproductive Rights, I am very concerned that several governments, including some European ones, opposed sexual and reproductive health and rights and gender equality in the High—Level Meeting outcome document. Fortunately, a strong alliance of progressive countries was able to ensure that standards on sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) and women’s rights were included in the final political declaration. In line with its rights—based approach, the EU should continue to stand united to defend the rights of women and girls within the EU and at the global level. It is clear that there will be no universal health coverage without universal access to sexual and reproductive health, and I want to thank Commissioner Mimica and Minister Tuppurainen for their commitment in this domain.

name: Simona BALDASSARRE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party(Democrats) and European Democrats, i.e. to guarantee all citizens of the world the opportunity to receive quality health care and adequate care, regardless of census and birth, as part of the fundamental rights of the individual: that is what universal health coverage means.  Unfortunately, to date, more than half of the world's population does not enjoy essential health services and every year more than a hundred million people fall into extreme poverty to cover personal health costs. The main economic resource lies in the savings that would result from an adequate culture of prevention.  Three points to achieve the objectives: allocating financial resources to national systems, raising public awareness of the adhesion of prevention screenings aimed at early diagnostics to avoid devastating diseases and investing in research and innovation.  So, in Europe, let us focus on funding for research and prevention, and in the poorest countries, let us focus on social and economic reforms in order to protect the right to a dignified life.  I will conclude, in the awareness of representing our Italy, which is at the top of the WHO ranking for the quality and universality of the care provided. An example, that of Italian public health that can still be improved, but which in many respects, can be guiding for its principles and characteristics.

name: João FERREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, at least half of the world's population does not have full coverage of essential health services. The United Nations has proposed to achieve universal health coverage in eleven years. If everything goes on like this is it, we'll hardly get it. The universal health care regime means that all individuals and communities receive the health services they need, prevention, treatment, rehabilitation, palliative care, without having to suffer financial difficulties. The right to health is a fundamental and universal human right. As we can do in practice, it will certainly not be through the increasing commercialization of health or through the disinvestment in public health services that we have seen in several countries. It is necessary to look inward, to look at the setbacks that have been observed here in the European Union. Health is a right, it can't be a business. We also need to look out and step up our efforts in the field of development cooperation. It is necessary to look and it is necessary to act. That is very much what must be done and we therefore regret that the main political groups in this Parliament have refused to involve a resolution in this debate with recommendations from this Parliament on the way forward.

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is good that we are having a debate on universal health care here today. Indeed, there are still a lot of people around the world who do not have access to health care. Even within the EU, there are still too many people who, for financial reasons, do not have access to the care they need and are entitled to. The UN political statement is rightly based on the approach to 'health in all policy areas' and sustainability objectives. I would like to address a number of things. First, the environmental factors. We cannot talk about health without talking about a healthy living environment and protection against harmful substances. This also applies to health in the workplace, because too many workers worldwide are still not protected from toxic substances. The health gap is also one of my pet peeves. Arm makes sick and sick makes poor. Still too many people don't get the necessary worries for financial reasons. That is unacceptable. We have an immense responsibility in vaccination policy, not only in Europe but also internationally. Not vaccinating is a danger to the entire population. We must also focus on mental health care, including on our own continent. The total cost of this is estimated at EUR 600 billion in the Union. We need to move not one but two gears higher. There has rightly been a great deal of support here on the issue of sexual and reproductive health care. I agree with that, too. Ladies and gentlemen, the ambitions are high: universal health care by 2030. In order to achieve our objectives – and i am therefore finalized – we will have to monitor this closely and provide the necessary budgetary space.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: – Mr President, primary health care is the most efficient and cost-effective way to achieve universal health coverage. But in order to achieve sustainable development goals by 2030, we need to accelerate the step. When we look at the concentration of human resources in health, this is high in large urban areas, causing a shortage of resources in more distant areas. Madeira and Porto Santo, as islands of an outermost region, are an example of this reality, where only 64% of the inhabitants have a family doctor assigned, leaving a third of the population without a doctor responsible for managing their health. We need mechanisms from the European Union that support Member States in the creation and implementation of health-promoting policies, with greater investment in all areas of health, from socio-economic and environmental determinants to healthcare services. It is necessary to encourage more support to retain health professionals in the most deprived and remote places, thus improving accessibility and quality health. Since, ultimately, health is a political choice, we can make that decision. If we don't invest in health, we're disinvesting in our society. (The speaker agrees to answer a question posed under the "blue card" procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: question he asked by picking up the blue card. – Colleagues Cerdas, I am glad that you mentioned as one of the problems that really still exists, which is the difference in the possibility of access to health care within the European Union, so, here, I would like to know which european policies can contribute the most to solving this problem, specifically I mean cohesion policy.  Do you think cohesion policy can be an adequate instrument so that these problems that exist in Madeira, but also in other parts of Europe, especially Central Eastern, can be solved?

name: Sara CERDAS
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, colleague, for your question. It is important that Member States receive the necessary support to tackle these constraints they have in providing health care. And human resources for health is, without a doubt, one of the main problems we have that will allow citizens to receive and get access to proper healthcare.  If we have remote areas that don’t have the proper human resources for health, that means our citizens are not getting access to the healthcare they deserve.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Mr President, health is a fundamental human right – we all agree on that. But how can we make sure that people can actually exercise their fundamental rights? Today we have way too many unmet needs and unequal experiences in our European Member States. As a medical doctor, I can tell you that access to high quality healthcare in my home country, Hungary, is not a fundamental right but rather a privilege. Life expectancy is among the lowest in the EU, with unbelievably high health inequalities based on the place of residence or social status. Access to care often only depends on the ability to pay, instead of needs. Human capital is the core of any well-functioning healthcare system – let’s acknowledge that. We absolutely have to make sure that doctors and nurses are properly valued, as they are the strongest pillars of a healthy society. Guaranteeing high-quality health care is a key objective of social protection and should be the priority of Member States. We have to fight to ensure that EU cohesion policy could better serve the health of our citizens. We need to put pressure on governments to make sure that all citizens can exercise their fundamental right to health care and enjoy good health, regardless of their age, sex or social status.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, some of you may still remember that in 2017 I became one of the faces of the campaign to create a road plan for achieving universal health insurance for all by 2030, created by the European Patient Forum.  At the time, we jointly called on the EU institutions and the Member States to recognise that patients anywhere in the EU, regardless of their country of origin, have the right to fair access to high-quality care, to commit to sustainable investment in healthcare or to ensure that medicines, medical devices and services are truly available to all. It is also necessary to put an end to the discrimination and stigma that patients face and to ensure that they are not removed from society. It should be added that none of these calls have been answered by the Member States. While it is nice that world leaders, including those from the EU, have patted each other on the back of what smugglers are like in the declaration under way, they should first do their own homework at home.  We could start directly with the HTA regulation, where, as Parliament, we have called for greater patient involvement and which are quite deliberately blocked by the Member States.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Chairman, we know, and this is seen in this debate, that there is indeed a consensus that the right to health care is a universal human right. However, the fact is that this universal human right still cannot be realised in large parts of the world.  However, what I would certainly point out is, and this has been said in some of the previous discussions, that large differences and problems with the availability of health care exist within the European Union itself. And indeed we can see differences between individual parts of the urban centres of western parts in relation to rural areas, in relation to areas of Central Eastern Europe and islands and other distant areas that are much less accessible.  Unfortunately, the European Union has also contributed to problems related to the availability of health care through austerity policies, and draconian austerity in many situations during the economic crisis. I am glad that this policy is changing, I am glad that my political grouping, it is the European People's Party, has recognized the moment, that it has placed the right to health care at the top of the priorities of the European Union and I really think that we should all stand up in this sense to solve these problems as soon as possible.  The European Union has several instruments that can address inadequate access to health care, and one of these instruments is cohesion policy. Cohesion policy exists based on the principle of solidarity so that those less developed parts can catch up with those more developed in every sense, and this also applies to access to health care.  So, let's strengthen cohesion policy, put health care at the top of the Priorities of the European Union and really help make this universal human right as much as possible.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Mr President, I will try to be brief, but when I talk about health, especially as I am a doctor, an emergency doctor, I have told you before, in Iasi, at the Nicolae Oblu Emergency Clinical Hospital, where a hospital, a collective, a city make emergencies and neurosurgery at European level, it is very difficult to do so.  But on the other hand, yes, let us talk about health as a fundamental right, and then there are two barriers that are opposed to this desire: education and economic. And, as far as I'm concerned, health education has to be taught from school – let each of us know what we need to do to promote a healthy lifestyle, and I'm not just talking about the environment. On the other hand, the economic barrier is causing us great problems, and perhaps we should think today, together with the European Commission, with the Council of Europe, to introduce that European standard of quality in health – so that I can be treated in Iasi as in Brussels, Strasbourg, Paris and Rome. At least with regard to a European women's health programme for the early diagnosis and treatment of the most common forms of cancer, such as cervical, breast, a European programme for reproductive health and free analysis for the mother and newborn, a European cancer control programme and the European Civil Protection Mechanism.  I'll still talk, but look at the fact that there are only ten people in this room even though we're talking about health.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last September, by adopting a political declaration on universal health coverage, the United Nations made an important, solemn commitment. However, it will not be obvious to give concrete and tangible shape to this goal. Health for all is, in fact, a right that should be indisputable, but we know that this is not always the case and achieving effective universal health coverage means guaranteeing everyone access to quality essential health services, the availability of safe and effective essential medicines and vaccines, the availability of nurses, doctors and even social workers. It means making a commitment not to leave anyone behind and for this we need a radical reversal in some contexts and always and in any case a significant investment. It's not a cost, it's an investment.  This banal principle, I think we must always be able to reaffirm it with our behaviors and choices, to ensure the physical and mental well-being of women and men.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague, you mentioned several things that you think should be done to solve this problem. Now, I am interested, we know that it is the Member States that are primarily responsible for health care issues in the European Union, but the European Union has a growing and greater role.  So I ask you very specifically: Do you think that the European Union should have even greater competences in the field of health, should it get more resources to act on the health policies of the Member States and can we contribute more through joint action of the European Union than only through the actions of individual countries?

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr Sokol, I am convinced that you do. The European Union must invest resources and I am told that the European Union must be consistent with itself. After all, the social pillar already sees important principles and choices. The theme is not to consider all this the moment dedicated to the most fragile, to be added to the policies of austerity.  Today's debate should affect the overall policies of the European Union, and I think that this Parliament must fight with determination in this direction.

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: – Mr President, the United Nations declaration is a big step forward.  Look: in 1986, a hero of Spanish, socialist, Catalan democracy, Ernest Lluch, launched the Health Law that institutes universal coverage in our country. Twenty-five years later, a People's Party government was withdrawing it, breaking one of the basic principles of our health system, health justice.  This decision resulted in hundreds of thousands of people running out of coverage, increasing epidemiological risks and causing thousands of young people, who had migrated from the crisis, to run out of health care. In 2018, another socialist government, by Pedro Sánchez, restored universal coverage.  Why this brief trace of Spain's health history? Well, it serves to show that only the statements are not enough. We must be vigilant to our right so as not to remain merely intended and for the temptation of health cuts to return to Europe.  The right to health protection does not understand race, sex, color, condition, borders. It is an effort, but it is the investment with the highest return on progress that our countries can aspire to. To always defend him.  (He agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: "blue card" question. – Spain has never ceased to have universal and free health for all Spaniards. You lied.

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: "blue card" response. – I have to reply to Mrs Montserrat, who has been Minister of Health of my country, who did, that they made a decree withdrawing the universality of health.  She says, "for all Spaniards." It is true; because a minister, prior to her, tried to discriminate against those who were not Spaniards or those young Spaniards who left the country for more than three months and were left without the right to health care; like some young people who wanted to come and give birth to our country and couldn't because the PP had withdrawn their health rights.  I know you weren't the one who took that measure, but you're responsible for it. In addition, today, the Community of Madrid is also trying to do the same in these health policies — because in Spain they are transferred to the regions.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I am proud to be from the political party that created the National Health Service. The Labour Party made it a universal right for everyone, from cradle to grave, that they should be entitled to healthcare that is free at the point of use, and we did this just after the Second World War when rationing was still in place.  We are a party that wants a truly universal health service, by scrapping prescription charges, taking on Big Pharma and delivering free personal care, so that our healthcare system puts public health ahead of private wealth and people before profit.  This is a basic human right, but sadly, not everyone has such a vital safety net. However, I am proud that the EU has supported 57 million women to use contraception, immunised 13 million children, given 11 million life-saving treatments for HIV and distributed 600 million bed nets for malaria prevention. We must work towards the 2030 agenda of universal healthcare for all, and make sure that we continue with the commitment of not leaving anybody behind.

name: Julie WARD
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Madam Minister, honourable Members, thank you for your lively and most useful debate. I believe that it has come out very clearly that we all share the values of universality, quality and equity of access to health care that underpin the goal of universal health coverage and that all health systems in the European Union are built on. The adoption of the UN Declaration is an important achievement, as it promotes key EU values. But we need to make sure that the important commitments made by the UN member states will now turn into concrete actions across the globe. In that vein, we welcome the fact that the declaration includes a formal review mechanism that allows us to take stock of the progress made in 2020 and 2022. The results should serve as a basis to adapt our approach and efforts before reconvening for another high-level meeting in 2023 for a comprehensive review of the implementation of the commitments made. The European Union will continue supporting all countries willing to make progress towards universal health coverage through our external actions, including the external side of relevant EU policies and our international partnerships at country, regional and global level.

name: Julie WARD
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, to conclude, I wish to thank the honourable Members for the very useful debate and assure you that this Presidency of Finland will spare no effort to continue to promote universal access to health care, which all human beings need, in particular the most vulnerable, when and where they need it. This is also in line with the so-called economy of well-being approach introduced by the Finnish Presidency. In our thinking, universal health coverage is a sustainable investment. Particular attention should – and will – be devoted to the needs and rights of women and girls, including sexual and reproductive health and rights. The EU and its Member States, as key supporters of multilateralism with the United Nations at its heart, together with the European Parliament, will promote and protect those rights in the context of the review of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform in Action in 2020. So thank you very much again for your attention, and now I think it’s time to say goodnight and sleep well. It is good for our health.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. – Mr President, the UN High-Level Political Declaration on Universal Health Care is an important step towards achieving the SDC. Universal health care means that everyone, especially the most vulnerable, has access to essential health care. SDI Sub-objective 3.8 is to "achieve universal health care, including security from financial risks, access to high-quality and essential health services, and safe, effective, high-quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccinations for all."  The EU must play a leading role in moving universal health care forward, both for its citizens and internationally. There is still much to be done here, including within the EU. There is particular concern about the attitude of some Member States to sexual and reproductive health and rights.
